PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986[COGNATE BILLS:EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL 1986CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 April, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering this Bill, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1986 and the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1986

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Porter Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills that we are debating include the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986. It is that Bill to which I wish to address my comments, particularly to part 6 of that Bill, which refers to amendments to the Spirits Act of 1906. The proposal in its generality is to remove the requirement for a two-year maturation period to apply to brandy, whisky and rum. The Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Mr Barry Jones), in his second reading speech, identified the reasons why the Government wants to remove that two-year maturation requirement. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government's examination of the issue, which involved in particular health and quality standards, revealed a significant divergence of industry opinion on the question of compulsory maturation. Firms with a tradition of producing matured spirits favoured retention while other interests suggested that the market, and not government regulation, should be the determining factor.

The Government considers that removal of compulsory maturation will allow producers to prepare unmatured products if the market dictates such a requirement. Production of matured products could continue, commanding whatever price the market would pay. Removal of the requirement is also consistent with the Government's policy to remove unnecessary business regulation. It should be noted, however, that States and Territories, which are currently responsible for food and beverage standards in Australia, still require maturation under State and Territory law.

We on this side of the House would be the last ones to want to delay the removal of unnecessary regulation. But let me test the claims made by the Government for the removal of this requirement in the face of the divided industry opinion and without putting in place, firstly, appropriate arrangements to protect domestic manufacturers from unfair import competition and, secondly, appropriate labelling provisions to ensure that consumers are informed of the nature of the product they are purchasing if no maturation is required.

A number of arguments have been put forward against this proposal. The Australian Wine and Brandy Producers Association is in favour of maintaining the current two-year maturation requirement. In relation to brandy, it says there is considerable concern amongst existing producers that by dropping the maturation requirements the existing quality brandy market will be subject to a flood of inferior quality product which could destroy the market altogether. There is also concern that the effect on the grape growing industry of dropping the maturation period could be serious as apparently there is some four years of maturing stock at present and the industry claims that little, if any, brandy would be produced for around three years if this change were implemented.

There are other factors which, in my view, also ought to be taken into account. The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in the other place, who has charge of this legislation, said in the Senate:
I believe that there are very few countries where maturation under regulation is required as it has been required in Australia in the past.

On the advice I have received the Minister is quite wrong. I am told that, for example, in France the maturation period varies from between 12 months and three to four years, depending on the district and some other factors which are part of the requirements in that country. I believe that in South Africa the maturation period requirement is one year. I believe that in California the maturation period is two years. In addition, a number of countries do not allow the import of brandy unless it has been matured, I think for at least three years. I believe that that restriction applies to countries in our region, such as Singapore, Hong Kong, Malaysia and New Zealand. So not only is the Minister wrong in relation to maturation requirements in countries of production-that is, countries of origin-but also he is wrong in relation to maturation requirements in importing countries.

Another matter of concern to me which has not been addressed by the Government in its bland statement in support of abandoning the maturation period is the impact that this will have on our domestic producers of all the products considered, that is, brandy, rum and whisky. As I understand it, the removal of the Commonwealth regulation is not being undertaken in co-operation with the States which also have maturation requirements. The outcome, therefore, of this pre-emptory Commonwealth Government move could be to open up the domestic market to exploitation by overseas producers of unmatured products and, whilst the State controls remain, Australian producers would not be able to match that overseas competition, that is, import competition from those countries producing unmatured product. My concern, therefore, is that the failure of the Government properly to think this issue through could result in the decimation of the domestic brandy, whisky and rum industry by not ensuring that our producers could compete on a fair basis with the imported product because of the State government controls.

Finally, I point out that the Government's proposal is in conflict with the National Health and Medical Research Council's model food Act which, in June last year, approved a two-year maturation period and that period was specified in that model food Act. There is one other major shortcoming with this proposal which I shall come to in a moment. What then are the arguments for the removal of the maturation period? As I understand it, the arguments of the Wine and Brandy Co-operative Producers Association of Australia is that, by doing away with the maturation period, cheaper brandy, for example, could be produced and new marketing opportunities could be provided. Nevertheless, in a telex to me, that Association stated:
We believe, however, that most brandy sold in the foreseeable future will be matured brandy.

I cannot understand why the Association believes that the matured brandy market will not be affected by unmatured brandy if the regulations are removed. Others have suggested that in countries such as Germany blending is allowed whereby aged brandy is blended with brandy matured six to 12 months; and they would like to try that process in Australia. That is really the nub of the case. It appears that some producers would like to try marketing different types of brandy in this country. The Opposition and I see no reason why consumers should not have a choice between different types of brandy as long as they are advised of what they are buying. In my view this is the most important point at issue in this debate. There is no doubt that in relation to brandy, for example, people are used to a quality product which has been matured. If the maturation period is to be dropped, the labelling requirements ought to be such as to properly inform the consumer of what he is buying. Whilst the proposal relates to brandy, whisky and rum, let me stick for a moment with brandy. If people want to market an unmatured brandy they should be allowed to do so but should be required to label it as such rather than pretend the product is something which it is not. This has been the thrust of the action taken in the United States where it is possible to market an unmatured brandy, that is, brandy that has not been matured for two years, but the requirement is that it be labelled as such-as unmatured brandy.

Last night when this point was raised by my colleague the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) the Minister, by way of interjection, suggested that the existing Act-I think he referred to section 9-would deal with this problem. In my view, it goes nowhere near dealing with the problem. It deals with very old labelling requirements. The section was implemented in 1906, which gives an indication of the sort of historical context in which labels were being applied. It talks about labels such as `pure Australian standard brandy'. How many people have seen that on a bottle of brandy recently? I am sure that all my colleagues are great consumers of Australian brandy and rum, especially as winter sets in. These old labelling requirements are so out of date they are not even used any more. For the Government to use them as an excuse is a farce.

It seems obvious to me that if the Government had sat down with the domestic producers of these products some workable arrangement could be achieved whereby the market is opened up to those who want to try to produce and market alternative unmatured products, provided they meet fair and reasonable labelling requirements. We do not have any in principle opposition to this proposal, but we have clear and unequivocal opposition to the introduction of this measure without detailed consultation with the industry to resolve problems of unfair competition from imports and to establish appropriate labelling requirements. This is a half-baked proposal which the Government has not properly thought through. Regrettably, this Government has no knowledge of these industries and, in relation to the brandy industry in particular, this Government, just like the Whitlam Government, has failed to recognise the existing problems confronting the wine and grape growing producers in bringing this proposition to the Parliament without sewing up the loose ends. The result could be devastating for the whole industry. We oppose this Government's sloppy administration and we say to the Government: `Get your act together. Consult with the industry and industry associations. Stop wasting the time of this Parliament and, more importantly, stop unduly worrying growers and producers by creating uncertainty and concern in these industries'. I repeat: We will look very positively at a proposal which is properly thought through but we will not support this half-baked scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this cognate debate on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill and the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, but in the main my comments will be restricted to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill. Obviously the Government has thought these Bills through. It was very interesting to listen to the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) talk about rum and brandy. Those on the other side of the House would be much more familiar with the finished product than those on this side, who tend to drink more refined products.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, my comments in the main will be confined to one Bill which proposes various amendments to customs and excise laws to implement Government decisions which, in particular, alter the arrangements relating to concessions on goods reimported after they have been repaired or renovated, provides for the termination of compulsory maturation for brandy, whisky and rum and removes a sex discrimination provision in the Excise Act. Sex discrimination comes up everywhere, does it not, Madam Speaker? The Government is here removing the sex discrimination provision in the Excise Act.

A number of other amendments of a technical or administrative nature have been included in the Bill and it is on these that I now wish to make some comments. I refer specially to Part II of the Bill which deals with the Coal Excise Act. As we were informed by the Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Mr Barry Jones) in his second reading speech, Part II of the Bill amends the Coal Excise Act to provide that the excise duty imposed by that Act will be paid on the amount of coal sold by a producer as shown on the invoice document provided by him to the purchaser. Currently the legislation requires the excise to be paid on the quantity of coal produced and removed from a mine. In today's operations some producers have difficulty in complying with this requirement since beneficiation of raw coal to meet higher quality standards often takes place at locations remote from the producer's mine. This contrasts with the situation in the industry at the time the excise was imposed in 1949 when practically no beneficiation took place. The amendment will align the Act with current industry practice and will have no effect on the amount of duty paid by the producers.

In recent years in the development of the coal industry we have seen greater and greater reliance on stockpiles. I have seen some very big stockpiles in my area and also larger port facilities. In the past producers had to pay the excise on the coal as it left the mine. In future they will not have to pay that money and that means that the producers will not have money tied up because they will not have to pay excise on the coal that is in stockpiles. I believe that this measure will be of great benefit to the producer. It should also assist Australia's greatest export earner, and that, of course, is coal.

I turn now to Part 3 of the Bill, in which I have taken an interest. I am pleased to see the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment (Mr Cohen) in the chamber because the proposed amendments in Part 3 of the Bill will amend the Customs Act as a consequence of the introduction of the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill. This Bill proposes to protect Australia's heritage of cultural objects and extend certain forms of protection to the cultural heritage of other nations so as to enable Australia to accede to the 1970 United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation Convention on the Means of Prohibiting and Preventing the Illicit Import, Export and Transfer of Ownership of Cultural Property. Regulations under the protection of movable cultural heritage legislation will specify the material to be controlled.

The amendments now proposed to the Customs Act provide the necessary authority for Customs officers to seize cultural objects as notified by the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment when those objects are subject to the control of Customs. Clauses 13, 14 and 15 of the Bill before the House represent in part a general tidying up of a number of pieces of legislation in order to make more effective the protection of movable cultural heritage legislation. The aim of course is to cover all eventualities and to close all loopholes. At present we have a Customs Act the schedules and regulations of which have been developed over many years, often as ad hoc responses to particular situations and incidents. For example, several years ago a Victorian Cross was put up for auction and it looked as though it would be taken out of the country. Fortunately the Returned Services League stepped in and bought it. Following this incident Customs Act regulations were amended to prohibit the export of such items.

Despite or perhaps because of this ad hoc approach Customs Act schedules and regulations do not cover all categories of important cultural material. Under clause 13 of the legislation before the House a new control list will be established and the present regulations will be amended as necessary. All categories to be included in the control list will be prescribed by regulation and thus subject to parliamentary scrutiny. This national cultural heritage list will take some months to be drawn up because there are many categories to be considered. There also needs to be developed a number of criteria by which export controls will be developed. These criteria will include the age of the object, its rarity, its quality and condition, its monetary value and the extent to which it is already represented in public collections.

The Government, in establishing tighter controls on the export of cultural objects, is not seeking to stop the movement of all such material. Its prime concern is to ensure that those objects, the export of which would amount to an irreparable loss to our cultural heritage, remain in Australia. In drawing up the control list a distinction will be made between class A objects, which are objects so rare and important as to be considered inalienable, and class B objects, which in certain circumstances may be given an export permit. In certain cases there will be some difficulty in classifying objects of cultural value. For example, how rare does an Australian postage stamp have to be before it is listed as a class A object totally prohibited from being exported, rather than being listed as a Class B object and therefore becoming a legal export once an export permit has been granted?

Consider the case of Aboriginal artefacts. At present it is lawful to export any Aboriginal artefacts once an export permit has been granted. I venture to suggest that had this legislation been in place we would not have had today a collection of rare and significant Aboriginal artefacts in the Vatican museum. Under the new legislation, however, certain artefacts, by reason of rarity or sacred or ceremonial significance, will be listed as class A cultural objects and be totally prohibited from export. Contemporary artefacts made for sale to tourists, on the other hand, will receive a class B listing and may be exported once an export permit has been granted. In this area there will no doubt be some difficulty in deciding, presumably in consultation with Aboriginal representatives wherever possible, whether or not a particular object has a sacred significance.

Old Australian coins dating back beyond 1901 are genuinely significantly rare and of such historical value as to warrant being listed as class A objects, and again there may be exceptions which could be given a class B listing. The same could be said for early Australian documents. As I have already stated, the aim of clause 13 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill is not to stop all trade in such objects as early Australian coins and postage stamps or in Aboriginal artefacts, but rather to control it in such a way that Australia suffers no further irreparable loss of its cultural heritage.

The legislation will also make it possible for the prohibition of the export of objects which at the moment could not be covered by existing schedules and regulations of the Customs Act. These include items such as very old machinery-for example, nineteenth century steam engines which may be exported without the necessity of first getting an export permit. Not so long ago another piece of machinery, in this case a World War II Messerschmidt fighter, was illegally exported to England. It has proved impossible to get this aeroplane back to Australia. Once the Bill now before the House passes into law, however, together with the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill, it will become much more difficult to illegally export objects of cultural significance, and anything illegally exported will be subject to forfeiture to the Crown. Should the illegally exported object be found in a country which, like Australia, is party to the 1970 United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation convention controlling the illicit import, export and transfer of ownership of cultural property-as Australia will be once the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill becomes law-then Australia will be able to seek the return of that object through official channels.

An example of items that could be regarded as items that should be seized by Customs is-and I am not speaking about members of the National Party-fossil deposits. My attention to this was drawn by a paleontologist friend, Mr Russel Hannah, who informed me about the fossil remains at Riversleigh in north Queensland. According to Russel Hannah, paleontologists have known about the Riversleigh site since 1901, but it was not until 1983 that they realised they had struck one of the most incredible scientific laboratories in the world. I thought that this place was that, but apparently it is at Riversleigh. But it is not only Australian paleontologists who are awestruck by the Ravensworth find, but the world paleontological community. We must ensure that these fossil remains stay in Australia and are not swooped on by other countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Cockies Corner.
—Yes, in Cockies Corner, as the honourable member for Chifley says. People go there and take them as souvenirs. Tourists go in and take these rare things.
—It is not the easiest place in the world to get to.

—No, but tourists are going there and, according to one source, individuals and teams from Japan, the United States and Europe are known to have come to the Riversleigh site in the last couple of years without any permission and simply returned with bags of fossils. These fossils are really part of the cultural heritage of Australia and as such they should be protected and, of course, they will be protected. I know that the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, who is seated at the table, will instruct the Australian Customs Service that any fossils leaving this country-unless they are members of the National Party-are to be impounded and, therefore, will be protected by this Bill. I commend these Bills to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill, and in particular the provision dealing with bounty payments on high alloy steel products. There are two types of high alloy steel products produced in Australia, namely, bar products and flat products, the latter consisting mainly of stainless steel. Under the present system bounties are paid on a sliding scale whereby the more the companies produce the less percentage of bounty is paid, and conversely the less produced the more percentage of bounty is paid.

SPEECH.PARA: When bounties were first brought in Commonwealth Steel Co. Ltd-Comsteel-was the major producer of both. But now we have a situation where most of the high alloy bar steel and most of the high alloy flat steel are produced by two different companies, Comsteel and Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd Coated Products Division, though it must be said that Atlas Steels (Australia) Pty Ltd and Overall Forge Pty Ltd produce small amount of bar products. Because the production of high alloy flat products has been relatively buoyant, bounty payments to Comsteel, which produces bar products, have been lower than they otherwise would. This legislation proposes to split the bounty payments of $9m between the two steel producers roughly on a pro rata basis so that the low-producing bar steel producer Comsteel will not be averaged up and therefore miss out on bounty payments.

At first blush that may seem a reasonable proposition. However, when one looks closer a number of important points of principle emerge that make me, for one, object to what is happening. Not the least of these is the fact that it will cost taxpayers more money. However, we should first look at the companies involved. Bar steel products are produced mainly by Comsteel, which is located at Waratah, Newcastle. That company is 38 per cent owned by BHP, 38 per cent by Vickers (UK) and the remaining 24 per cent is owned by the public. That company produces bar steel which is used in tool and die production, in car manufacture, the aircraft industry, the defence industry and in the mining and oil industries. The flat steel products, which consist mainly of strip sheet and plate, are made by BHP Coated Products Division. That is 100 per cent owned by BHP; it was formally the Lysaght company. It produces the product down at Unanderra, Port Kembla, near Wollongong. The flat stainless steel is used mainly in the car industry, the building industry, in containers, in the furniture industry and also in white goods and domestic appliances.

In the financial impact statement which is retrospective to 1 July 1985, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) has told us that bounty payments would increase from $3.5m to $4.3m, an increase of $800,000 to taxpayers-in other words, this legislation will cost more. The Comsteel Special Steels Division is concerned not only with high alloy steel but also with carbon steel production, with low alloy steel production, medium alloy steel production, although it is only high alloy steel that is eligible for the bounty that we are dealing with today. The high alloy steel makes up something less than 50 per cent of the plant's output.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Will the honourable member tell me which one of the Bills he is speaking to?
—The Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill.
—The House is dealing with a group of three Bills dealing with Customs and excise tariff and Customs administration. The House is debating the three Bills cognately.
—I refer to the Minister's second reading speech, which deals with the bounty relating to high alloy steel production in clause 5 of the Bill.
—There is not a bounty Bill before the House at the moment. To which second reading speech is the honourable member referring?
—The Bill that was presented to the Parliament on 17 April, the Bounty and Subsidy Legislation Amendment Bill.
—The honourable member should resume his seat. I will call him again later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I am very honoured to have been deferred to in this way and called on early. I am very much honoured. To assist the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) who seems to be a little confused--
—Order! The honourable member for Parkes will have leave to speak later.

—I just thought that I would run through what we are actually debating. We are actually debating three Bills: The Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill and the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill. I have some sympathy for those who suggest that this is a rather dry package of Bills to discuss. However, I will firstly comment on a few of the remarks of the two shadow Ministers, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) and the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), who have already spoken in this debate. In fact, I think they have been commenting rather adversely on the proposed changes to maturation for whisky, rum and brandy.

SPEECH.PARA: The impact of the Bill will be in 1990 when it becomes operational. Much has been said about what the Bills will do, but all speakers opposite have ignored the fact that there are overriding State labelling requirements, and the traditional two, five and 10-year labelling will still be a requirement under State and Territory legislation. However, the proposed amending Bill will remove unnecessary regulation, and I would have thought that Opposition members would have been supportive of that. The Bills also allow customers or consumers, should they be given the choice, to make the decisions, rather than it being done through government legislation. I find it rather extraordinary that two shadow Ministers opposite can object to the fact that unnecessary regulation is being taken away, and also that consumers should be denied freedom of choice about their purchases.

TALK.START.PARA: —There's nothing to be surprised about on that side.

—I am not as experienced and as learned as my honourable colleague. I must say that it came as a surprise to me to hear two shadow Ministers speak like that. In their remarks they overlooked the impact of State and Territory legislation and I believe attempted to seriously cloud the issue for honourable members and for the listening public of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I would also like to talk about the provisions of the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. I remind the House that in the autumn session last year we established, by a legislative package, an independent customs service, which was proclaimed to operate on 10 June 1985. Essentially, the bulk of this legislation allows the Comptroller-General of Customs to be responsible for the day-to-day operation of the Customs Service. I believe that that is a very sound administrative approach which I would have thought would not have been questioned by the shadow Minister. However, let me just say that, in the earlier legislation, we delegated some 75 per cent of the powers of the Minister, and there remained 25 per cent that the Minister was required to exercise personally.

I am pleased that this legislation encompasses a review not only of the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Minister's Department, but also the Australian Customs Service with the benefit of advice from the Attorney-General. As a result of that, a further 15 per cent of powers has been delegated to the Comptroller-General, leaving the Minister essentially with about 10 per cent. I might add that in one case one power has been taken away from the Comptroller-General and returned to the Minister. However, this allows the Minister and the Secretary to the Department greater opportunity to concentrate on the major and complex issues facing industry in this country. The Minister, for example, still retains the power and responsibility in terms of extension or variation of bounty assistance, the proposing of Customs tariff alterations, the formulation of schemes for calling and dealing with tenders for the right to import goods, and numerous other powers under the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act relating to import, dumping and countervailing duties.

I should comment a little about the Australian Customs Service, as the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore), was in some doubt about the rectitude of the changes made last year and the establishment of an independent service. In fact, he called upon the Minister to give some report about the success of it. I will take up that point because I thought it was a little disappointing that the shadow Minister, being a Queenslander, did not comment about the trial that had been undertaken in Queensland. He certainly did not talk about the inland revenue risk management scheme which was trialled in Queensland. This was a result of the Public Accounts Committee Customs inquiry. There was a report to the Parliament. The Committee was assisted by the Customs Service. Essentially, the features of the risk management system are that it has clearly understood components; concentrates on rating risks; allows flexible allocation of resources; measures the result of all activities; and is uniform in its application amongst collectorates. That trial has been successfully concluded in Queensland and will be extended throughout Australia.

What is the role and responsibility of the Australian Customs Service-this new, independent organisation that was established last year and to which we are delegating additional powers? Firstly, it is responsible for exercising effective control over the movement of goods, people, ships and aircraft into and out of Australia. This involves a number of activities: Industry assistance, for example, tariffs and quotas; and enforcement of community protection requirements, for example, areas such as quarantine, narcotics and prohibited imports. The second responsibility in that area concerns the collection of revenue, for example, revenue on imported goods. Some 15 per cent of all government revenue is collected by this independent Australian Customs Service. The third main role of the Service is non-barrier assistance programs-that is, bounties and diesel fuel. Of course, the Customs Service acts on behalf of other departments in its barrier role, for example, in quarantine, fauna protection, immigration and, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) would say, the protection of Australian fossils. I believe it has been a successful move, and one that should be supported.

I am very pleased to see that the Service, in addressing its role, has adopted four main priorities. One is to measure achievement by result. I think it is very important in the Public Service that we have this task and target orientation and measurement by results. Secondly, to apply benefits of computer support as widely as practi- cable. I am very pleased that it is expanding its computer network and proposing to upgrade it. I notice that the level of expenditure will not be sufficiently high to attract the attention of the Public Accounts Committee, more is the pity. Thirdly, to invest heavily in training and development of staff. Lastly, to improve industrial relations in the Customs Service.

As a former trade union official in the Public Service, I can say that there has been improvement in this regard on a service-wide basis, but we still have a long way to go. I can well recall a chief manager who flatly refused-and he was physically repelled by the thought-to meet trade union officials. Also, there is the classic case, which I am sure we all know about, that, under Public Service guidelines, because there is not a dispute, a State or regional manager refuses to meet the union. That shows a clear lack of understanding of the concept of preventative industrial relations. In the training and development of staff, I think it is true not only in the Public Service-I am sure it is in the Australian Customs Service-but also in private enterprise that the most valuable commodity or resource that an organisation possesses is its staff or people working for it. An investment in training and development is richly rewarded. I have some difficulty because I believe that the Public Ser-vice Board should spell out more clearly the desirability for staff to undertake tertiary studies. Whilst an assistance program is in operation and whilst, apart from specialist positions, mandatory tertiary degrees are not stipulated, I believe that the Public Service Board could do much more to encourage public servants to undertake relevant courses.

The last item that I want to speak about concerns the provisions of clauses 16 and 18 of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill which follow on the Government's accep-tance of recommendations contained in the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on re-import concessions dated 16 November 1984. The IAC, in its conclusions in that report, listed five main questions that it felt that the report should address. Those were: Is the concessional entry of re-imports consistent with Australia's policies for assistance to industry; in particular, should re-imports continue to enter duty free and should overseas repairs continue to receive concessional entry? Should Australia have a general system of overseas assembly packages? What, if anything, should Australia do about the use of the Australian content provision in the rules of origin for determining eligibility or preferential tariff rates as a de facto system of OAPs? A number of problems have been identified in relation to Customs administration of the re-import concessions; how should these problems be tackled? Lastly, although Australia is a contracting party to the International Convention on Simplification and Harmonisation of Customs Procedure, known as the Kyoto Convention, it has not acceded to the two annexes dealing with re-import concessions under reference in this inquiry; therefore, should Australia cede to these arrangements?

The bulk of the IAC's recommendations were picked up in legislation on 22 November 1985 but the Government has not acted in relation to overseas assembly provisions. In fact, reading from a Press release from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, the provisions would provide a duty concession for imported goods according to the extent of material or components of Australian origin. The Government has decided not to introduce a general system of overseas assembly packages at this time because of administrative costs and the issue of whether it would benefit Australia. But I am pleased to say that the Government is still keeping open its options and adopting a flexible attitude because enactment of those sorts of provisions could benefit certain industries.

The provisions of this Bill generally complete the re-import package by authorising the Comptroller-General of Customs to make a commercial tariff concession order which will permit duty free entry of goods re-imported after repair or renovation if it is established that repair or renovation is not capable of being performed in Australia in the normal course of business.

To conclude, I certainly support the three Bills. I have not gone into all the details of the three Bills. I find it rather disappointing that the Opposition has, if I may say so, tried to cloud the issue of one of the provisions and to entrench unnecessary regulation to entrench the denial of consumer preference. That is rather disappointing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1986 and the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 are being dealt with cognately. Not surprisingly, these Bills have attracted a good deal of interest because of the focus they have on the brandy and spirits industry. I was a little amused to come into the House and hear the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) make reference to just how little the honourable members on his side of the House know about the spirits industry because of their tendency to be beer rather than spirit drinkers. The honourable member for Throsby, in a rather uncharitable way, implied that only on his side of the House was there really an egalitarian approach to the consumption of various beverages. In my opening remarks to this debate I must therefore remind the honourable member for Throsby that it was the egalitarian Curtin Government that applied approximately the same taxation rates to beer and to spirits. Subsequently, I note, governments dominated by conservative parties have been the governments that, along with this Government, have reached the point at which spirits currently attract tax at almost twice the rate levied on beer.

SPEECH.PARA: With that little digression, I wish to refer specifically to the brandy industry because of the impact that that industry has on my electorate. I must say that too little is known and appreciated in this House about just what a modern, up to date and effective industry the brandy industry is and about the level of innovation that currently occurs in the wine producing and brandy industries across this nation. Too many people happen to have some odd view about the wine and brandy industries-a view that they are some sort of peasant industries, a view that clouds them in romance, a view that imagines that all people involved in the wine and brandy industries are somehow caught up in a Grapes of Wrath sort of mentality in which a setting sun disappears behind rows of vineyards and people walk hand in hand down those same rows.

In fact, the industries are innovative. Whether one looks at them in the vineyard or in the distillery, modern techniques that are being implemented anywhere in the world are already being used in Australia. Much of what is used in innovative grape growing and distillation in the world had its historic origins in the industry in Australia. But the industry is an industry that, as a result of the impact of governments, particularly governments of the political persuasion of the honourable members opposite, has had a very sorry saga.

The brandy industry as a component of the wine industry in Australia has a unique characteristic. It has the capacity to be a sponge that in years of surpluses soaks up the surpluses and does not necessarily need to be supplied in years in which there may be a short supply of wine grapes. So the brandy industry has historically been used to level out the supply of grapes available to the wine producers within the grape growing industry. It is also fair to say that it has been a very important sponge in levelling out the supply of grapes available to the dried fruits industry, which has been every bit as unpredictable in terms of its market opportunities. As a result of the impact on the brandy industry of excise measures, particularly by the Whitlam Government, the Australian brandy industry has all but disappeared and this capacity to absorb surpluses has all but disappeared, so we have a grape growing industry that is adversely affected by the absence of an Australian brandy industry.

I must make the point that never has the brandy industry been as disadvantaged as it has been following the period of the Whitlam Government. At the start of the Whitlam Government's period of office the customs duty on brandy was $3.8 per litre of alcohol and the customs duty on whisky was $4.93 per litre of alcohol-a differential between brandy and whisky of almost 60 per cent. At the end of the Whitlam Government's period of office the customs duty on whisky was $10.75 per litre of alcohol and the excise duty on brandy was $10.21 per litre of alcohol, a differential between brandy and whisky which had fallen from 60 per cent to 5 per cent. That proved to have a disastrous impact on the Australian brandy industry. At the same time, the average spirits duty rate had been sharply increased to about one and a half times the duty rate for beer, as I intimated earlier.

The results of these legislative decisions were that Australian brandy production fell from 4,484 kilolitres of alcohol in 1971-72 to 1,784 kilolitres of alcohol in 1974-75-a reduction in the area of brandy production of 2,700 kilolitres of alcohol. Furthermore the Australian brandy market's share was down from 35.1 per cent to 26.9 per cent, which is a decrease of 8.2 per cent, while imported whisky in the period of the Whitlam Administration rose, supplementing the brandy industry's market share, from 47.6 per cent to 59.1 per cent, an increase of 11.5 per cent.

As if the history of the Whitlam Government were not disastrous enough for the brandy industry, we had the additional offence of the Hawke Government coming into office and further loading the imposts that the wine industry in Australia generally was carrying. The end result of the Hawke Government's broken election promise not to tax wine, when it ultimately did so, was that the imported whisky share had grown to 74.6 per cent and the Australian brandy share had fallen to 17.2 per cent. So the capacity of the Australian brandy industry to level out the peaks and troughs of vineyard production had been absolutely annihilated by both the Whitlam and Hawke governments.

The specific implications of the legislation before the House, which are to remove the two-year maturation provision, have already been adequately addressed by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and quite eloquently by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), who mentioned his particular concern for the wine and grape growers in his electorate and pointed to the implications of the removal of this two-year maturation period. I must restate what the honourable member for Barker has so eloquently said, that is, that the Opposition is not opposed in principle to the removal of this two-year maturation period. The Opposition is opposed to the removal of that provision at this time before certain other steps are taken by the Government to ensure that any adverse reaction to the removal can be insulated against by other legislative moves. We, in the Opposition, applaud the action of the Government in moving in a deregulatory fashion. It suits us. We would like to be supportive of it but we believe it to be premature for the Government to take such steps unless it can assure the Opposition that, by 1990, when the two-year provision has been removed, other steps have been taken to ensure that imports maintain some minimum standard and that labelling provisions have been introduced.

As the honourable member for Barker has said, we recognise the particular advantages of removing the two-year maturation provision. We recognise that the removal could substantially reduce some of the production costs currently being faced by the Australian brandy industry. We recognise that the removal of the two-year provision could lead to new product opportunities. We recognise, from our conversations with people involved in the brandy industry, the great advances that could be made in brandy marketing if there were opportunities for brandy producers to blend mature brandies with immature brandies and so produce a brandy that suits the palate of a particular market. We were among the first to recognise that the move in the brandy industry from pot stills to continuous stills-the innovation I referred to earlier in my speech-means that the brandy industry no longer has this mandatory need for a maturation period. To remove the maturation period without putting in place certain other legislative safeguards we believe would put the Australian brandy industry at risk. I must say that it is in recognition of these concerns that we have suggested that the legislation before the House is not in error but premature.

One of the real fears that the Opposition has is that, by removing this two-year maturation period, we could open up the Australian spirits market to inferior overseas product. We fear that the quality of the Australian product may slip and we fear that any downturn in the qua-lity of the Australian product could lead to a further impact on the Australian market of immature overseas spirits, brandy in particular. I point out to the House the very sad experience of the Italian wine producing industry where the adulteration of wines and spirits of Italian origin has led to a major reduction in the sale of Italian spirits on the American market. As the honourable member for Barker has said, it is quite in error for the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to indicate that the removal of this maturation period only matches what is being done overseas. The Minister, in response to a question from Senator Jessop in the other chamber, said:
I believe that there are very few countries where matu-ration under regulation is required as it has been required in Australia in the past.

The Minister was in fact wrong. In an inquiry into the Wine and Brandy Producers Association I discovered that, at least in the United States of America, the European Economic Community, Singapore, Malaysia and Canada, a minimum two-year maturation period is required. One of the concerns that the Opposition has about what we see as the premature removal of this provision is the impact that this could have on adulterated wine flowing into Australia and its consequent impact on the health provisions that would affect every Australian. On 14 November last year I asked the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) a number of questions, one of which was:
Will he also . . . require that each consignment to Australia-
this was of wines or spirits from overseas-

is accompanied by a guarantee from the government of the exporting country that the consignment is free from any adulteration and . . . provide an Australian import inspection regime similar to that which the European Economic Community applies to Australian exports of alcoholic beverages as interim measures until a list of eligible export establishments is approved and published.
The Minister, in response to that question, replied:

No. Within Australia, the States and Territories have responsibility for administering domestic food laws including ensuring that imported food complies with domestic standards. Apart from the application of Quarantine Regulations and Customs . . . Regulations, there are no comprehensive Commonwealth inspection arrangements for imported foods either at the place of manufacture or point of entry. Commonwealth involvement is largely limited to the administration of quarantine control, tariffs and prohibited imports.
As if that were not reason enough for concern, he then went on to say:

My major concern at present is to achieve uniformity of food Acts, Regulations and Standards as they apply to all foods sold in Australia, whether of domestic or imported origin. The question of reviewing manufactu-ring conditions for food and beverages in overseas countries exporting to Australia is not at this time seen as a practicable alternative.

There rests my case. The Opposition does not believe that the removal of this two-year matu-ration period is unwise; it believes that it is unwise at present and it is unwise until the Minister for Health has taken the trouble and used this opportunity to sort out the way in which we police those products flowing into this country from overseas and the way in which we achieve uniformity of our food legislation and labelling. If the Minister could assure us that we will have some sort of import control and some sort of import inspection of overseas goods by 1990 and that we will have some sort of uniform food Acts across Australia by 1990, the Opposition will be able to look at this piece of legislation from a very different point of view.

I note that the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) was anxious to use the red herring of State labelling as a reason to favour deregulation and the phasing out of Commonwealth maturation provisions. The State maturation provisions are policed largely by Customs officers. The existence of Commonwealth maturation provisions has meant that the State provisions have scarcely been used. I cannot believe that the removal of the Commonwealth Customs policing which has made the State provisions ineffective will mean that the State provisions will automatically become effective. I would have thought that the end result of this legislation would be to encourage the States to phase out their maturation requirements. The Opposition would not be opposed to that if it could be assured that steps were being taken to ensure that imports into Australia meet minimum standards, that those standards would be policed and paid for by the importing country. Furthermore, uniform food legislation would ensure that no Australian was placed at risk as a result of the legislation before the House today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Let me respond to a number of points that were made in the debate on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1986 and the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 last night and today. I thank all honourable members who contributed to the debate. A number of points were made by the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore). I deal with those points together because they encompass a number of points that were made, for example, by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew). The first issue has just been discussed by the honourable member for Wakefield and concerns removal of the requirement for the maturation of brandy, whisky and rum. I repeat: The Government announced on 4 May 1984 that, following a review of regulations applicable to spirituous beverages, the requirement for the maturation of brandy, whisky and rum would be retained at that time but that further examination of the continued need for compulsory maturation would be made.

SPEECH.PARA: The examination revealed two major points. From the health viewpoint, the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) advised that compulsory maturation was unnecessary. On the matter of quality, where there are no health considerations, the examination revealed that the market itself, and not government regulation, should determine what is to be produced and sold. The examination found that there were no quality grounds for the retention of compulsory maturation. Removal of the maturation requirement from the Spirits Act is also consistent with the Government's overall desire to remove unnecessary regulation of business and encourage efficient, long term growth of the industry. This legislation underlies the commitment of the Hawke Government to the freeing up of the market. It also highlights the curious embarrassment of Opposition members-theoretical free marketeers, but actually interventionists when it suits them.

The Government also believes that Customs legislation is no longer the appropriate medium for this type of control. The States and Territories have responsibility for food standards and, in the Government's view, this is where any maturation control-if it is required and if the market mechanism does not cover it-should rest. For the information of honourable members, Victoria, South Australia, Queensland and Tasmania require in their food standards a two-year maturation period with the `old' and `very old' labelling requirement. Western Australia has similar legislation yet to be proclaimed and New South Wales has such legislation before its Parliament.

The question of uniformity of food laws would not be dealt with by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) under the Customs laws. At the Commonwealth level it would be the responsibility of the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) who has responsibility for consumer affairs matters. I will refer the speech of the honourable member for Ryan to the Attorney-General. I know that he reads the honourable member's speeches as a matter of course. Without trying to put words in the Attorney's mouth, I think that basically the uniformity of food laws is a State responsibility. If the States were disposed to move towards a uniform national law it could be only at State instigation and with the agreement of all six States. Because these regulations will not come into effect until 1990 there is time to look at this matter, but I will refer the matter to the Attorney-General who will, I hope, reply to the honourable member directly.

In regard to the matter of labelling raised by the honourable member for Ryan, the National Health and Medical Research Council model food standard provides that there shall not be included in a label words, firstly, which describe spirits as matured unless the spirit has been matured by storage in wood for a period of not less than two years, secondly, which describe spirits as old unless the spirit has been matured by storage in wood for a period of not less than five years and, thirdly, which describe spirits as very old unless the spirit has been matured by being stored in wood for a period of not less than 10 years. These standards are being progressively incorporated in State legislation. Several honourable members, including the honourable member for Ryan, raised the question of the day to day responsibility for the Australian Customs Service moving away from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce towards the Comptroller-General. It must be stressed that under our system the Minister retains portfolio responsibility for the Customs Service and for the overall political direction for getting legislation through, handling correspondence and so on. In this legislation the Government is proposing a completion of the exercise of transferring only administrative powers involving the day to day operation of the Customs Service. By arrangement the Comptroller-General of Customs and the Minister meet weekly for the Comptroller to inform the Minister of current Customs operations. As Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, I have been quite heavily involved in that procedure. The transfer of some ministerial powers last year to the Comptroller-General has been of considerable benefit already. The Minister can devote much more time and effort, as he wants, to the major policy issues facing industry. He has not been required to be involved in day to day Customs administration functions. The Comptroller-General, on the other hand, has been able to devote his entire attention to running the system, the Customs Service.

Before the establishment of Customs as a separate entity, the Comptroller-General and the Secretary to the Department of Industry and Commerce, as it then was, were the same person. The powers mentioned by the honourable member for Ryan, that is, anti-dumping and tariff powers, are not being transferred to the Comptroller-General. These powers are in the major policy arena and, in the Government's view, are not suitable for transfer. The powers that already have been transferred and that are now proposed for transfer are purely administrative and, as I say, involve the day to day running of the Customs Service.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 24-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 25 to 27-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition wishes to oppose these three clauses which will remove the maturation requirement of two years, particularly in view of the arguments put forward by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), both of whom very adequately put the case that the removal of the maturation requirement would lead to lower standards within the industry and would not give the local industry the operational opportunities that undoubtedly exist. On top of that I would like to express the view of the rum industry, which feels particularly disadvantaged by this move.
—Particularly Bundaberg rum.

—I know that the honourable member for Dawson has a keen interest in that area. The Opposition is particularly concerned that a reduction in the maturation period for brandy, rum and whisky will impinge on Australian production. Thus, the Opposition will oppose these three clauses.

—I rise to support the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) and to restate the case I made earlier in the debate. I note that the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), in his second reading reply, suggested that the Opposition could reasonably be accused of being interventionist. Once again I must state for the Minister's benefit, as I did in my earlier speech, that the Opposition is not opposed to the removal of this two-year provision; it would simply like to see, first, some assurance that Australians will not be disadvantaged in terms of the quality of the product that is put on the market. We recognise that the maturation provisions can be policed by both the States and Territories. Currently they are not being policed by the States and Territories because the Commonwealth has taken over that role. Unless there is some indication that the particular concerns we have about uniform health food requirements are being addressed by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) or the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), we feel that we would be acting less than responsibly if we allowed this two-year provision to disappear until other safeguards are in place to ensure that Australian consumers are not disadvantaged. I must restate that the Opposition is not standing here in some dog in the manger pose; it is not asserting that the legislation before the Committee is in error, but that it is premature.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already given the reason why the Government cannot accept the proposal put forward by the Opposition and there is little point in restating it except to say that the termination will not take place until 1 April 1990. We regard this as a matter entirely appropriate for State regulation as part of the consumer affairs responsibilities of the States rather than something that historically evolved out of the Customs powers. As the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) pointed out last night, the Customs Act 1901 is one of the oldest Acts and has one of the broadest heads of Commonwealth power, the result being that anything was dragged into it. It is a bit of an historical anomaly; it does not appear to be particularly appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I should also point out-I did not say this earlier-that when the Government was examining the issue earlier it found a significant divergence of industry opinion on the question of compulsory maturation. Firms with a tradition of producing matured spirits favoured its retention while other interests suggested that the market, not government regulations, should be the determining factor.

It could hardly be said that the Government is rushing into this provision. In effect there will be virtually a four-year period so that the legislation can be given an opportunity to mature-not, of course, in wood! If there are problems, they can be appropriately dealt with at the State level, and, if it is necessary to refer to the Commonwealth to make sure there is national legislation, that ought to be taken up by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen). As I have said, I will refer the points raised in the debate to the Attorney-General. We just do not believe that it is an appropriate exercise of the Customs power.
Clauses agreed to.
Title agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Oil Companies (Stock Loss Reimbursement) Bill 1986 would not have been required had the Government heeded the advice of the coalition to deregulate the oil market as recently as last year. It is government regulation which has placed the oil industry in a cost-price squeeze and government regulation which forced oil refiners to suffer the stock losses that have occurred. Under normal market conditions oil companies would have been able to limit stock losses and delay price reductions on sales. However, the compulsory allocation system and wholesale price controls prevent this normal commercial action. Further, because the price of crude oil is regulated and adjusted only at regular periods price movements are reflected only with a lag and occur more suddenly and dramatically than under normal market conditions.

SPEECH.PARA: The import parity price set on 1 January 1986 was $A43.71 per barrel. Refiners were required to take supplies of domestic crude oil at this price during January and February despite the rapid plunge in comparative world crude oil prices. On 1 March 1986 the Government lowered the price of domestic crude oil supplies to be allocated to refiners to $A27.09 per barrel, a fall of $A16.62 per barrel. On 1 April 1986 prices were again adjusted downwards by a further $A6.10 per barrel. These price falls were equivalent in real terms to both of the oil shocks of 1973 and 1979. The stock losses subsequently incurred by the oil industry have been estimated at between $A575m to $A600m.

The Government has agreed with this legislation to partially reimburse refiners for stock losses by, firstly, a payment for stock purchased in February, but not January-the Government had argued that refiners took supplies at acceptable risk conditions under the allocation system-and, secondly, less the value of sales from those stocks between the 1 March import parity pricing adjustment and the subsequent Prices Surveillance Authority wholesale price reduction on 14 March.

Given that oil companies have a legitimate claim for compensation for these stock losses suffered as a result of government regulation and that compensation is to be paid from Consolidated Revenue, the coalition supports the Bill. However, the coalition is concerned that the oil industry will not be fully compensated and that the Government will continue to pass the buck for oil market regulation on to consumers; that is, ordinary, overtaxed Australians. In fact, we have to ask the questions: How heavily will this change in price fall on the shoulders of consumers? I understand that as recently as yesterday the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) was criticised in the Senate for asking, as a lead issue, where the price reduction was on home heating oil. I believe he was unfairly criticised in that House because he is a person who has had a interest in the oil industry, including refining, for quite a number of years. It was a legitimate question, yet he came under severe criticism in that place.

I ask the further question: How much longer will consumers be asked to pay higher prices for plastics, fertilisers, tyres and other products of oil refining? There is no evidence of any benefit to consumers in the market-place at the moment, and I believe that that is a legitimate complaint of people who are suffering the on-costs of the regulation of fuel prices now that the import parity pricing levy has been reduced. When will they see the benefit? I can understand that there is a lag, as evidenced here, but it would appear to me that, as is the case with home heating oil, consumers will be asked to make up this cost in relation to all these other final products, such as plastics, fertilisers, chemicals and tyres, ad infinitum. Passing on costs to consumers is just one way the refining industry can reconcile its loss.

The coalition is also concerned that the Government has not moved to deregulate the oil market, despite the recent problems which have led to this legislation, and is apparently unwilling to deregulate and avoid similar problems in the future. Let us take each of these points in turn. The value of stock holdings in February was estimated at $210.6m less sales of $85.8m, leaving a payment of $124.8m to be distributed on the basis of allocation of shares. What about the remaining $300m which the Government accepts the oil industry has lost in January and since March? The Government has argued that the earlier losses may be made up if prices increase. The Government has also argued that companies will be able to recoup effectively nearly half of any remaining losses via company tax deductions. This does not appear to be the most economic equaliser in a situation where there is so much doubt expressed by the Government, on both the fall of the price of oil and now on its recovery. Given no price recoupment the companies will therefore increase company tax deductions by a further $150m to $200m.

This is little comfort for the oil industry, which will be forced to wait for compensation which may not occur, and if it does, will occur only after a lengthy period in which substantial damage will have been done to company results, shareholders' returns and share prices. So it has an implication right down the line. The Government apparently does not want to think about the commercial reality of its decisions. Further, while the Government indicated that the $124.8m payment would be tax free, it has stated that company tax deductions will be reduced by this amount to prevent double dipping.

TALK.START.PARA: —By what amount?

—By $124.8m. That is to be tax free, but it has other effects on company arrangements. Some oil companies had assumed that they would pay no tax on the $124.8m and would maintain full tax deductions for stock losses, effectively increasing the value of the compensation payment. The Government has refused to alter these tax conditions despite the perilous financial position of these oil companies. Given the revenue to be derived from the massive increase in petrol tax, this is a very hard-nosed decision by the Government. What about stock losses suffered after February and any future stock losses? The Government has refused outright to bear the burden of regulation and provide compensation out of Consolidated Revenue. Instead it indicated that consumers should be forced to pay this compensation. The Prices Surveillance Authority has already introduced a wholesale surcharge of 0.45c per litre to account for stock losses which occurred as a result of the 1 April import parity pricing adjustment.

SPEECH.PARA: The surcharge is supposed to last for seven months. Given the revenue greed of this Government and its attempts to renege on the commitment to reduce the new tax on petrol as world oil prices increase, the coalition doubts whether the surcharge will ever be lifted. Indeed, it is likely that the Government will increase and extend the new tax and keep the revenue for itself rather than pass it back to the oil companies and consumers and will rely on the convenient memories of the consumers and the refiners to help it through this situation.

The Government has indicated it does not support any further tax increases via the PSA surcharge. How, then, will it compensate oil refiners now that oil prices have fallen again? The Government should indicate its position on this matter immediately. It has shown a lack of judgment in forecasting the collapse in world prices and letting consumers pay, but it is now quite prepared to gamble on an upturn to provide compensation to the refiners. One wonders where this situation will eventually end. The Government has also indicated that it will not provide any compensation to retailers who may have suffered stock losses, because, firstly, retailers are not required to take stock, they may limit stock exposure by delaying purchases; and, secondly, they are not subject to formal retail price controls and may recoup such losses by delaying price reductions.

However, while this may apply in theory, retailers on average have enough storage capacity to hold only about three to seven days stock, or nine to 10 days stock in country areas. As such, those retailers would have been forced to take higher priced stock. Further, the Government neglects the effect of persuasion, particularly by State governments who have retail price control powers, and the effect of consumer expectations of price reductions which, when combined with the high level of retail competition, shown by extensive discounting, limit the ability of retailers to maintain high prices. Some retailers, particularly those in areas where discounting is heavy or those who were required to take larger stock purchases, particularly in rural areas, would obviously have suffered stock losses. Yet the Government has turned its back on them. Once again the Government does not understand commercial reality, once again it has dumped the problem in the too hard basket and once again it has passed the buck on to somebody else.

This Government must be prepared to compensate fully the oil industry out of Consolidated Revenue without any recoupment by tax or price increases. Consumers have suffered enough from the high taxes of this Government, and they too must have some relief. This high spending Government must be forced to accept fiscal limits. It must be forced to make expenditure cuts so that it can afford to reduce petrol taxes and compensate the oil industry and consumers. This Hawke Labor Government must be forced to get its own Budget and its own house in order but it has indicated a clear reluctance to come to terms with galloping expenditure, as evidenced by its three record deficits. Despite clear indications that world oil prices were going to fall quite dramatically and could stay at low levels for some time, the Government has consistently refused to make the necessary policy adjustments to permit a more flexible response to the oil crisis. The Government has had plenty of time to adjust policy; however, it is unwilling to do so.

While maintaining the principle of import parity pricing, world pricing of our energy resources, and making some changes to the IPP formula to reflect the growth of the non-Organisation for Petroleum Exporting Countries spot market which has in part led to the current crisis, the Government refused to deregulate fully pricing and allocation arrangements. Deregulation would have enabled the oil industry to adjust more flexibly and efficiently to recent price movements and market changes. Unfortunately, the Hawke Government seems unwilling or unable to pursue actively deregulation initiatives in the oil market. I suspect that the Government has been heavily influenced by the union movement and sections of the oil industry which have sought to portray self-interest as the national interest.

The efficient development of all our resources will not occur where we underprice or overprice our energy resources. Misallocation of resources and hidden costs can only result from this. The oil industry today is large and diverse and much more mature than the infant industry of 10 to 20 years ago. It must be able to stand on its own feet. This cannot be done while the oil industry is overregulated and overtaxed, particularly while the oil market is in crisis. As such, the coalition supports assistance where sudden policy changes jeopardise investments, particularly where government regulation imposes added costs and constraints on the ability to compete and adjust to market changes rapidly and efficiently. Given the importance of maintaining adequate oil exploration and development incentives and the need for equity in government policy, the coalition also supports appropriate tax relief for oil explorers and producers, both as a short term assistance measure and as the necessary corollary to deregulation of the oil market in the longer term.

Increased and new taxes on oil exploration and development under the Hawke Government have been major disincentives. In particular I refer to the resource rent tax, the new oil levy and the cash bonus bidding. The coalition has opposed and will continue to oppose these new taxes on the oil industry and will review them when elected to government. In a recent speech to the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) indicated that a fundamental principle of coalition policy was that the taxation regime provide adequate incentive for continued oil exploration and development. I believe this is in the national interest. In the present climate of low oil prices there is a strong case for immediate tax relief to assist continued oil exploration and development to offset the adverse effects of the oil crisis.

Again, the Leader of the Opposition has indicated that the coalition would only move to a totally free market following a phasing in process to allow producers to gain access to markets with provision for some small producers to remain in a residual allocation system as a form of adjustment assistance. The coalition is not wedded to this particular form of adjustment assistance and is willing to receive advice on the most appropriate form of assistance required. Of course, it is unfortunate that the coalition is not in a position to implement such measures now. That responsibility clearly rests with the government of the day. However, it would be a disaster if nothing were done until the next coalition government. It will bring further chaos if nothing is done in an already chaotic economic situation.

The coalition supports this Bill but maintains that the Government should provide proper compensation to the oil industry, pass on to consumers the full drop in world oil prices, not half of it, provide immediate tax relief for oil exploration and development, and fully deregulate the oil market with further fundamental tax reform to lower community and industry costs and increase industry efficiency and competitiveness.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to rise to speak on the Oil Companies (Stock Loss Reimbursement) Bill. While it gives me great pleasure to speak, I am certain it will not give the oil cartel pleasure to listen to or read this speech in the future. My dislike for the oil cartel in Australia goes back many years. I have watched it effectively carve up an industry that generated work for many Australians. The cartel has systematically gone about the business of forcing service stations to close and blackmailing the operators of the few remaining owner-operated stations to manage their business. These multinationals dictate with the threat that their leases will not be renewed. These are the sorts of threats that many of these multinationals use on service station proprietors.

SPEECH.PARA: BP Australia Ltd would have to be one of the greatest exponents of forcing service station operators to toe the line. In March 1984 I called BP the quiet deceiver and I am glad to say that others are using this phrase. I think, of all the oil companies involved in this nasty business, it would have to be the worst. It is the hit man of the industry-a company that has made millions from Australia, a company which in 1984 and 1985 made world-wide profits of $6.21 billion or $62m per week over two years. That is approximately $8.9m profit per day. Yes, that is correct-$8.9m per day profit.

Let me tell honourable members a few things about the quiet achiever-some of the things it has done, that is, besides pulling down the refinery at Hastings and swallowing up Australia's own refinery, COR. On the program The Investigators the following discussion took place:

Reporter: Recall a couple of weeks ago we featured a report on Frank Farrelley, the BP proprietor at Cronulla in Sydney's south. Now, after close to 20 years in the business, Frank's been given his marching orders. BP says his lease won't be renewed and that the site will no longer be used as a petrol station. Sadly for Frank the news came just a couple of weeks after he'd arranged to sell his business for more than $100,000. First up BP didn't offer Farrelley a brass razoo, not a single solitary cent. Then an offer of $25,000 which a fortnight ago it upped by another $10,000. Now, whether that offer still remains open is uncertain.
Frank Farrelley also received a lot of support from many people in the Australian community. One from Western Australia writes:

Thank God for the Frank Farrelley story. Only those who have been under the thumb of one of the major oil companies know how true his story is. Unfortunately, I must ask that you not use my name or in any way identify me, as I am still surviving in the business and can't afford my supplier to find out that I have spoken out of turn.
This is the sort of fear that BP and other oil companies engender in their proprietors. The report continues:

Well, one person who's not perturbed about being identified or speaking out of turn is Kel Gouch . . . He's launched a scathing attack on BP following what he describes as the company's jackboot tactics . . . Now the breach, according to Kel Gouch, is that he was late, 12 days late, in paying his December account.
