Now, that's not the $150,000 in cash he pays BP every month for petrol, but rather an oil bill for $800. For this the quiet achiever saw fit to warn him that a repeat breach could see his lease terminated and BP would throw him out . . . Strong stuff, but Mr Gouch doesn't stop there. The apparent desire, he says, by BP to resort to bullying, harassment and baseball bat tactics designed to engender fear and compliance on the part of its dealers could be said to strongly resemble the approach adopted by dictators in days gone by.
I agree with that. It goes on in the report to refer to `shades of the quiet deceiver'. I am glad to see that others are using this phrase that I used to describe BP several years ago.

One of the other things I would like to mention is the profit of the oil companies. The profit of Ampol, Shell, Mobil, BP, Caltex and Esso in 1984 was $574m. In 1985 it was $307.6m. This figure does not include Esso which, in the year before, made a profit of $412m. I hasten to add that they handed over to their US masters a dividend of $280m. I have picked out BP for special treatment here, but it is typical of all companies. They make huge profits out of our resources which they believe they own because they have found them. I strongly believe that resources in Australia are the property of all Australians-not overseas companies which, at the moment, dictate to us. In the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday, 18 February 1986 was the headline `Refiners stop loading Bass Strait crude'. The article began:

Australian oil-refining companies have baulked at loading further shipments of Bass Strait crude oil at existing prices until the Federal Government gives an undertaking that the companies will be protected from a potential combined inventory loss of $480 million.

Australian refineries are compelled to take a minimum 350,000 barrels a day of crude from Bass Strait. A continuation of the companies' refusal to load the oil may result in a partial `shut-in' of production in Bass Strait, while effectively increasing pressure on the Government to respond quickly to the fall in international crude oil prices.
Later the article continued:

Oil company spokesmen said that the Australian refinery industry has never before been confronted with losses as large as those it was forecast would result from a drop in indigenous crude oil prices under the IPP system. They said that unless the Government moved to protect the companies, the impact on their profitability would be devastating.

In other words, it states that unless the Government gives the oil companies $480m, they will not proceed to load Bass Strait oil and therefore shut down production and create chaos within Australia. These greedy companies have incurred a loss on the stock they held in their tank farms. What did they do some months ago when the prices went up? Did they sell their stock that was in these huge tanks at lower prices, the prices at which they purchased it? No, they made huge profits and kept very quiet. Did they pass on to the public the profits their companies made because of the huge amount of petrol storage they have at company-owned service stations? No, the money went straight to their parent companies and their pockets. Oil companies without any shadow of doubt are the ugliest and most avaricious of any sector of industry within Australia. The answer to curbing the greed of this cartel is in section of the Australian Labor Party Platform, which states:

With the exception of the United States, all of the oil exporting nations and every oil importing country of consequence have established government companies for active involvement in the oil and gas industry. Public participation in the oil industry provides a means for the nation to share fully in the benefits of its own oil and gas reserves without impeding a healthy level of private oil and gas activity. Only through participation can government acquire its own direct knowledge of the industry. Government enterprise can enhance the nation's energy independence whilst providing other benefits as an integrated public oil company.
It states that the Australian Labor Party will:
Establish a public corporation, responsible to the Commonwealth Government, to participate in the development of Australia's oil and gas resources, such that the corporation-
(a) will have strategic as well as commercial objectives;
(b) may, with the approval of the Government, engage in any of the activities of an integrated oil company;
(c) may operate independently or in joint venture with private or other enterprise;

(d) will act commercially when participating with private companies, but may explore and locate reserves without seeking to develop them immediately, in the national strategic interest, when acting solely;
(e) will be funded as appropriate by Commonwealth grants and loans and by public borrowings, provided that its commercial operations incorporation provides a satisfactory return to its investors.

This is a part of the Australian Labor Party policy that I feel we should implement immediately. Why should these companies dictate to this Government the orders of some faceless overseas board? I believe that the Government has been blackmailed into giving the oil cartel a $125m handout. We must make certain that it never happens again. I also take this opportunity to join with the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck)-I do not join with him too often but I do so on this occasion-in calling for an inquiry or a joint parliamentary committee to look into the oil industry. He has made this call several times in the past, and I am very happy to put my name to the call for some inquiry to find out what is going on in this industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened intently to the speech of the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Chynoweth) on the Oil Companies (Stock Loss Reimbursement) Bill in which he continued his attack on the oil companies. Sometimes some of his criticisms are most valid, but the oil industry is ever changing, and indeed has changed dramatically in the last 15 years. I suppose the oil companies have to make a buck in the market-place. They temper changes with the ultimate aim of making a profit for their shareholders. It is beholden upon governments that if they want to change the oil industry they have to be prepared to put their hands into the barrel of oil and have a good look at these changes.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill has caused me a fair bit of concern because it will provide a windfall for the oil companies of $125m of taxpayers' money. I can understand that if one has stock on hand and there is a variation in the price one has paid for that stock, one will be in trouble if one cannot get something back in subsidy because of reasons that are beyond comprehension and beyond reality. Some assistance must be given to such people. But regrettably the people of Australia today are looking very closely at the oil industry. They are making comparisons in the price of petrol as well as comparisons State to State. When they see a printed maximum wholesale price indicated in their State and a printed wholesale maximum price in another State but discover that quite frequently petrol is being sold below that wholesale price, they start to wonder why there is a windfall for the oil companies. Then, regrettably, in the next breath the companies drop the price, which may be to the detriment of many Australians.

We hear continually in this House that the price of petrol and petroleum products has a flow-through into the economy. If the price increases, great problems are created in the rural sector. This also creates great problems for the ordinary Australian who uses his car to go from point A to point B and in his ability to be able to get to work. We all know that it is a terribly high price at the moment. In my State of Tasmania the price of petrol varies between 52c and 54c a litre. Let us take a person who lives 20 miles from his work place and needs to travel 40 miles a day to get to and from work. I do not use the new measures but the old, because a lot of people have been hoodwinked by the price of petrol. They think that the price refers to gallons, dollars and cents, but in fact it costs about $3 a day for some people to go backwards and forwards to work.

We all know that governments can win or lose in the hip-pocket nerve. Sometimes it is argued that a difference of $3 in pension can create great hardships. In fact, I repeat that it now costs about $3 for some people to get to work. I hate to go over the same ground, and I have said this before, but I would emphasise that the people on the lowest incomes cannot afford the most modern car. They have the car that they can afford to pay for, and usually it is a bigger car that uses the greatest amount of petrol. Those people are being penalised all the way. I agree with the honourable member for Dunkley. I have spent a lifetime in the oil industry dealing with oil companies and I know them to a certain degree. I know that there are pressures on the companies with higher wages, strikes and goodness knows what, and in getting money for their shareholders. I understand all that, but if they ask for a windfall from this Government, they must play the game fairly.

I would hate to see a repetition of what happened before. One can go back in history to ACTU-Solo and we can talk about Ampol and Mobil and their involvement. We can also talk about the decline of the industry in Victoria as a result of discounting, where poor proprietors on one corner were buying at one price and on another corner it was being sold at that same price. We understand discrimination, market forces and goodness knows what. If one cannot buy at a competitive price, one goes to the wall, and a lot of those poor devils went to the wall while we all stood back and watched. We have had a report by Mr Justice Collins of the Royal Commission on Petroleum, and there has been about one speech in this House since 1975 on the oil industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was you.
—I did not take credit for the home heating oil reduction, and I was criticised in the other place by my friend Senator Evans following a question from a senator, whose name I do not remember.
—Coates.
—Yes, Senator Coates. He criticised me for taking a bit of credit for home heating oil reductions in Australia. If the credit is due, I will take a bit of it.
—It is due to me.

—The honourable member for Canberra copied my speech the next night; I heard her on Canberra radio. I could give the honourable member the works, but she is a lady and I cannot attack her too much. I heard her on Canberra radio; it was a rerun of my speech, but not as good. I will leave that aside. I rang Canberra, and I did my homework. I asked for the price of home heating oil in Canberra and I was told that it was 48c a litre. My poor people in Tasmania were paying 54c a litre. The distributors were delivering the oil right at the peak of winter at the old price. One poor lady rang me and she said: `Bruce, I have just paid 54c a litre'. I said: `Ring them and tell them that there was a reduction'. She said: `Bruce, they have told me that on the 16th they charged 54c and on the 18th they charged 46c a litre'.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of Australia are starting to realise that this oil industry needs looking at, and we are the ones to look at it. The honourable member for Dunkley made a suggestion: Yes, we sometimes twiddle our thumbs up here when we could be doing some intelligent looking at the price of petrol in Australia. We could start liaising with the oil companies instead of standing back and shooting cannons at them. We should start getting involved. The honourable member for Canberra said that the poor people of Canberra are so disadvantaged. I have good eyes. I came to work today and saw that petrol is 48c a litre in Canberra; it is 54c a litre in Hobart. I would say that the people of Canberra with their roads and cars are far better off than the people of Tasmania. The people of Canberra have a $17m bus service, which runs at a loss, so they do not really need their cars. The honourable member for Canberra should not make comparisons with me. I have given her a good go, but she should not make comparisons. I have done my homework on this subject and I have done the comparisons, and the people of Canberra are far better off than my people in Hobart.

If we go a bit further, we find that petrol is selling at 43c a litre. It upsets me when these people get a windfall. We have to play the game fairly today. All right, we have had a reduction in home heating oil. However, it is the end of the barrel; it is the cheap stuff. The people who kept their oil heaters in can least afford these prices. I refer to the elderly, the sick and the needy, although a couple of modern ones also kept in their oil heaters. However, most people I know took them out when we went to import parity pricing. This oil is the cheap part of the barrel; the price should have been reduced. In Tasmania we pay nearly twice as much for LPG.

TALK.START.PARA: —Scandalous!

—It is scandalous and we must have a good, sensible and constructive look at it, and we as politicians need to get involved and make certain we can change this industry for the betterment of everyone, for the people who work in the industry in overalls, for the people who work for the oil companies, for the oil companies and their shareholders, and for the consumers of Australia, most importantly, who need to be aware that we are going to do something to make it fair for everyone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker-
—Don't copy his speech again.
—Don't repeat him verbatim.

—I am really very concerned that maybe I have been in this Parliament for too long, because I actually agree with some of the points just made by the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) and particularly those in relation to the irregularities of the retail price of petrol and the home heating oil pricing structure. Let me take the Australian Capital Territory as an example where we can see a considerable variation in the price of petrol. Petrol is cheaper in Canberra than Tasmania, as the honourable member for Franklin said. I suppose one reason for that is that the people of Canberra have an effective local member who is out there fighting for them so that the impact is felt at the bowser. However, there is still the price variation: It is 49.9c at Hawker, closer to the city it is about 45.9c, and at Fyshwick it is 44.9c; yet on the Hume Highway in Sydney it is 39.9c, and New South Wales motorists are also paying the State petrol tax which we do not pay in the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it totally confusing when there is the same source of supply. Transport costs do not make up that sort of difference, because motorists in Sydney are also paying the State petrol tax. In fact, what is happening is that the consumers in the Australian Capital Territory are subsidising the discount war that is going on in the major metropolitan areas. That has been the situation for a very long time. I think it is quite unfair that those people in provincial towns and in country towns must subsidise this competition in the metropolitan areas. This Bill really is not about retail pricing; it is about the wholesale pricing and about compensation for the oil companies. It is a one-off Bill which will compensate the oil companies for inventory losses they incurred as a result of the sudden fall in oil prices. Without this legislation consumers really would be worse off; they could now be facing increases in oil prices and they would definitely be faced with huge job losses on the oil fields.

The basis of the payment to the oil companies is the stock losses incurred by refiners in respect of their lifting of indigenous crude oil during February. These were not recouped by sales in March prior to the Prices Surveillance Auth- ority's determination of the net maximum wholesale price of petroleum. In other words, oil companies bought locally produced Bass Strait crude, because of the voluntary agreement they had, at $43.71 a barrel in February. The price fell to $27.09 a barrel on 1 March, and on 1 April it fell a further $6.10, so that oil companies lost considerably from the time they purchased the oil until the time it was sold at the bowser.

Why is the oil company case so special? Surely this practice of buying at one price and selling at another is normal commercial activity. The oil companies, in normal business practice, without any constraints on them at all, would have simply bought the cheapest oil. That was not the Bass Strait indigenous crude oil but the Middle East surplus. This would have dramatically affected local oil products, employment and, very importantly, government revenues. The Government, if it had not acted, would have put at risk for the month of February $350m in revenue from its crude oil excise and also put the whole crude oil absorption policy in jeopardy. The Government was not prepared to take that risk.

Why is it that only the oil companies are compensated and not the petrol retailers? The position of retailers is very different from that of the oil refining companies. Unlike the refiners, the retailers were not obligated under the crude oil allocation scheme to lift high priced product in February. Retailers had the option of running stocks down in anticipation of the price fall and, of course, many of them did that. The extent retailers could deplete their stocks depended on their commercial judgments about the timing of deliveries of lower priced products and the consequences of running out of supplies entirely. To comply with the crude oil allocation scheme, refiners were not free to exercise their commercial judgment. In February they had to lift 350,000 barrels a day of Bass Strait crude together with the total produce from all the other smaller domestic oil fields, which was about another 75,000 barrels a day, in full knowledge that the price of oil would fall dramatically in March. So, is it any wonder that we have to have this legislation before us today? There is no way, without this legislation, that that agreement would have been kept in place.

The size of stocks held by refiners and retailers is very different. For normal operation refiners need to hold 50 to 60 days' stock. City retailers', stock levels are only three to seven days and in country areas they are about nine to 10 days. The retailers' exposure to inventory losses is therefore very much less than that for refiners. Also, a very significant fact is that petrol retailers are not bound by the decision of the Prices Surveillance Authority. That is something that I regret because the Prices Surveillance Authority only sets the maximum wholesale price of petrol. It is my view that it should also set the maximum retail price, but I cannot get unanimous agreement for that point of view. Retailers are able to dispose of oil stock at the retail price they consider appropriate, given market forces prevailing at the time. As can be seen from the remarks I made regarding Australian Capital Territory prices and the figures cited by the honourable member for Franklin, prices vary considerably.

At this point I make reference to the Opposition's policy regarding the oil industry. The honourable member for Franklin seems to have adopted a unique position in the Opposition. I am pleased that the Opposition supports this legislation, but there have been considerable differences of emphasis in the Opposition's position on the oil industry. Senator Durack, who, I understand, is the Opposition spokesman in this area, says that he intends to introduce a free market for the petroleum industry if the Opposition wins office. In the Age of 26 June 1985 Senator Durack claimed:
The non-decision on deregulation of the oil industry demonstrates a lack of direction by the Hawke Government and a lack of nerve by Senator Evans.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.
—Hear, hear!
—Presumably that means that the National Party of Australia supports the view that there should be deregulation of the oil industry.
—Hear, hear!
—I am glad to see that National Party members support that policy. The views espoused by the Opposition-particularly by the National Party-are not supported by the general community.
—What nonsense!
—They are not supported by the trade union movement, the oil producers or the oil refiners. Senator Durack and the National Party are on their own.

SPEECH.PARA: What does the industry say about the Opposition's policy? At the twenty-sixth annual general meeting of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, Mr Ted Harris, Managing Director of Ampol Exploration Ltd, as reported in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 9 April 1986, stated:
If cheap petrol is (the Opposition's) predominant objective, then we can fix that very quickly.
He can fix it quickly, all right. But what is the impact of that? Mr Harris continues:

We will simply have a milk run of tankers bringing petroleum products into Australia from huge surpluses available from the Middle East . . . and to hell with exploration and efficient refinery capacity and employment and capital investment.

So Mr Harris said: `We can bring it in from the Middle East. That is no problem at all. We can get cheaper oil. But to hell with exploration and efficient refinery capacity and employment and capital investment'. He continued:
Need I really say more?

Need anyone really say more about the Opposition's policy of deregulation in the oil industry? Mr Harris says that he supports the concept of deregulation, but he conceded that it would never work in Australia. That sums up the Opposition's policy. When will honourable members opposite ever learn that if they want to return to the treasury bench they will have to get their heads out of first-year economic texts and look at the real debates and the complexities of the Australian economy? Their rigid belief in the remedies of the free market will continue to ensure that they remain on the periphery of the political spectrum.

I will make some further comments about the industry locally, particularly the point referred to by the honourable member for Franklin concerning home heating oil and kerosene prices. Canberra is subject to a very harsh climate. This means that the average Canberran must spend a fairly large proportion of his income on home heating. Many of the homes in Canberra still have oil heating because it is only in the last couple of years that natural gas has been connected. With winter approaching-in fact, many people visiting Canberra would believe that it is here now-I would have expected that the 40 per cent fall in crude oil prices would have had an impact on heating oil and kerosene prices. But that has not happened. There is considerable variation in home heating oil prices, from about 48c a litre to 54.5c a litre.

I took up this matter with the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). I have been given a commitment that this matter will be referred to the Prices Surveillance Authority. I hope the Prices Surveillance Authority takes up this matter because it is ludicrous that the ordinary home user of heating oil should be providing compensation to the oil companies because they bought their crude at February high prices. This legislation is supposed to cover that. It seems to me that there is no justification for them to keep the price of home heating oil substantially higher than petrol prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are all for the oil companies.
—We are not all for the oil companies.

—Order! The honourable member for Maranoa and the honourable member for Gippsland are listed to speak on this Bill. If they persist in their interjections they may find, when it is time for them to speak, that they are out of gas.

—That gas is considerably cheaper than heating oil! I conclude by saying that the Government is not supporting or opposing the oil companies. We want to give the oil companies the opportunity to operate without being severely disadvantaged, which is what would have happened if they had had to buy oil, under a voluntary arrangement, at a price so much higher than that for oil from the Middle East. As the Government has given the oil companies a fair go in relation to the purchase of their crude and a considerable amount of support is going to the oil companies, in return they should be fair to Australian consumers, particularly in the selling of domestic heating oil. I hope that as a result of this debate they review their pricing structure for heating oil so that the consumers of Australia who are using heating oil are not subsidising either motorists in the metropolitan areas or the oil companies. I think that the pricing situation, particularly as it applies in the Australian Capital Territory, should not continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my pleasure to speak to the Oil Companies (Stock Loss Reimbursement) Bill 1986. I am rather sad that my speech will not be broadcast because, of course, fuel has such a tremendous effect on primary producers throughout Australia. My electorate of Maranoa covers so many--
—They sniff it.

—Unfortunately, the only people sniffing petrol are the Aborigines in central Australia. I will have more to say about that problem when I speak to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Amendment Bill tomorrow. It is of tremendous concern to me that petrol is being used in this manner.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill, of course, is to take $124.8m of taxpayers' funds out of Consolidated Revenue and pay it to the oil companies. I find this a rather dramatic way of going about things. I say to people in Australia that this is a classic example of why we should not have import parity pricing. We have placed ourselves in such a position that we have to pay funds out of Consolidated Revenue-tax-free funds to the tune of $124.8m. Although these funds will be added on and taxed, initially they are being given to oil companies as tax-free funds. If we double that amount, $250m is being given to oil companies for 12 months. The taxing arrangements are to take place at the end of their financial year. In the meantime, they may have had that money invested at 20 per cent. With the sorts of interest rates that the guys opposite have imposed, that sort of money could be invested for 12 months at 16 per cent on call and one would be doing pretty well out of it. Those are the arrangements that this Government has got us into.

I have never supported parity pricing. I always felt that it would work against us economically, and that is what has happened. I have been proven 100 per cent correct in the last three months. I predicted that the oil price would fall to $15 a barrel. Once it reached that price, I predicted it would go to $10 a barrel. It is now between $10 and $12 and will go even lower.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing on the back bench, then?

—One of the reasons I am on the back bench is that I was very critical of Malcolm Fraser and Doug Anthony for introducing parity pricing when they led the Government of Australia. I thought it was a disgrace. It still is a disgrace that the guys opposite continue with it. I wish to hell they would get the hell out of it. There is no reason for us to be taxing--
—They are like us-they are getting a few dollars from it.

—That is right. They are getting too much money from it and the economy depends on it. They have turned around and moved all the taxing arrangements from well-head to excise, which is an even bigger criminal offence than the original one. It is a total rip-off now. Not only are we being taxed at the excise point, being ripped off at the bowser, but also the Government has indexed excise taxes to inflation. We have had a 2 per cent increase in inflation in the last quarter so there is a roll forward in the amount of money that the Government will collect from people using petrol. Most of the funds are going into Consolidated Revenue. Initially, these taxes on petrol were to be spent on roads. But we are spending about $1 billion a year on roads and collecting about $9 billion. It is a ridiculous set of circumstances. It is a total distortion of our economic well-being and a total distortion of the taxation system when not only this Government but previous governments rely on the amount of money collected from oil. It is supertaxing one particular industry. Of course, the whole industry has fallen through a hole. What has happened is that the Government has scrambled out of well-head taxing arrangements into excise and is still ripping off the users of petrol.

SPEECH.PARA: I have always argued that this is a very poor and wrong form of taxation and that we ought to move right out of it and free up the oil market. There are two industries that are totally regulated in this country. One is broadcasting; the number of Acts dealing with communications in this country is something horrific. The other is the oil industry. The deeper one digs into the oil industry, the more hide-bound it is. The number of Bills and regulations is unbelievable. I cannot understand why this is the case.

We are self-sufficient in oil. We are actually exporting $2 billion worth of oil. There is the great cry that we are running out of oil. If we are so desperate for oil, why do we allow the Bass Strait oil producers-they produce 90 per cent of our oil needs-to export up to $2 billion of oil a year? We cannot be so short of oil if that sort of thing is going on. It is great for our balance of payments. It is worth two-thirds of the amount that we earn from the wheat crop. We earn about $3 billion in export income from wheat. We now depend on the export of oil yet the pundits and the oil companies tell us that we are running out of the stuff. It is a lot of nonsense. The whole world is awash with crude oil. What is wrong with our importing a bit of oil? We already import heavy crude oil. We need to do so; we do not produce heavy crude oil. We have to import 20 per cent of our oil needs. The only oil that we export is light crude oil. It competes on the world market. The companies are able to produce and sell it, obviously at a profit; otherwise they would not be exporting it. It is high time that governments got out of the supertaxing of the oil industry.

I will now explain some other reasons why I feel that primary producers in particular in this country are being overtaxed with fuel. Not only is $124.8m being given by this Government from Consolidated Revenue; in addition, the Prices Surveillance Authority authorised a 0.45c per litre surcharge for seven months, to account for further stock losses, which the consumers will have to pay. So not only are taxpayers being ripped off from Consolidated Revenue; every time they go to the bowser to buy some fuel, they are also being ripped off because 0.45c a litre goes straight to the oil companies.

Another thing I say to the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science (Mr Barry Jones), is that yesterday I tried to find out from our side of the fence the sorts of profits that oil companies made when the price was going up. No one seems to think that they made any profits when the price was going up. No one seems to think that they might have bought in oil at $25 or $30 a barrel and kept it in stock. At one stage the parity pricing arrangement was adjusted only once every six months. This now happens every month because the price has tumbled so quickly; we have run off to the oil companies to help them out of their problems. But what was happening when the price was going up and the companies had enormous stocks that they had bought in at the cheaper price? At the end of six months the Government sat around a table and a formula on the dollar was set for the light Arabian crude oil. Obviously, while the price of imported oil went up, so did the price of our oil. But no consideration has been given to the fact that the oil companies may have had a few tankers around the coastline full of 40,000 or 50,000 tonnes of crude oil bought at the cheaper rate which was then sold to the refineries at a higher rate. That situation does not seem to have been taken into consideration. I say to the Minister that in business we know that what goes up must come down. I understand the formula and why we are forced to subsidise oil companies to this extent. But I say that it is bad economics and bad management that governments put themselves in the position of having to do that.

As we know, the retailers do not get any compensation, and nor should they. There is no fixed retail price. I do not agree with honourable member for Canberra (Mrs Kelly). I do not believe in socialisation. The Government is involved enough with the wholesale price; it has fixed the wholesale price of oil at the refineries. Of course, many people think that we should fix the retail price. I believe that we should free up the wholesale price and let the oil companies compete. Then we may see some reductions in the retail price. The only way to get the retail price down is to have a bit of competition at the wholesale level. There is nothing wrong with a bit of competition.

We introduced the fuel freight subsidy scheme to help people who lived in isolated areas to compete because, obviously, where there is not much competition in rural Australia, retailers are more inclined to jack up the price. That is why prices are higher out in rural Australia than they are in the cities; the volume sold is much greater in the cities. The farm community in Australia consumes about 15 per cent of the total diesel used and about 5 per cent of the petrol used. That is not a large amount compared with what the rest of Australia is using. One has only to fly into Sydney and see the number of cars crawling around the streets to understand that that is where all the fuel is used, that is, in the capital cities. The previous Government had a fuel freight scheme but the Labor Government saw fit to pull it out at a cost of $24m to rural producers in Australia. Hawke flies around the world and tries to kid us that he is a friend to the farmers. It is absolute nonsense. That measure has cost the retailers between $500m and $600m and I guess it will not be the retailers who will wear the loss; it will be the consumers. The retailers will hold up their prices at the bowser until they have recouped their losses. Then, hopefully, we will see a slight fall in the price of petrol and diesel that we have to pay.

The import parity price has dropped from $43 in February 1986 to $27.09 in March 1986, to $20.99 in April 1986 and to $18.90 in May 1986. The price has fallen by $24 since February 1986. That gives everybody an idea of just how rapidly the price of crude has fallen. Of course, the price could not stay high. The Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries is probably the biggest cartel ever formed in history. But no cartel ever survives because there is always someone who wants to sell his product a bit cheaper than the other guys. While there was a bit of a shortage in the market the OPEC cartel survived. But, as soon as overproduction set in, down she went. The cartel is not worth a bumper now. The nations involved are selling their oil at the best price they can get and undercutting each other.

The Arabs have already stated that they can produce and sell oil for $1 a barrel and still make a profit. Arab farmers pay 4c a litre for their fuel; we pay 44c. The Arabs have enormous supplies. They have about 60 per cent of world crude oil reserves and they are able to produce oil and will produce oil for practically nothing to force a number of countries out of the market. Australia will find it difficult to survive in some of these markets. That is one of the problems we are having, particularly in my electorate and in the electorate of the honour- able member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) who represents the Bass Strait producers.

My electorate of Maranoa has the Cooper Basin in the far south-west. We have had articles in the newspapers. Recently, in the Sunday Mail there was an article about Roma. Roma is one of the towns in my electorate where the first oil and gas discoveries were made and it has always been the centre of oil exploration. But, of course, with the downturn in the price it is much dearer for these producers-Delhi-Santos and the other companies involved in the Cooper Basin-to produce on-shore because they do not have the enormous reserves that producers have in the Bass Strait. But these areas in my electorate are contributing. The Jackson oilfield is the only on-shore oil field paying royalties and the well-head tax to the Government. As I have said previously, I believe that that is a tax that we should get right out of to allow these companies some breathing space. Now that the price has dropped we have to get out of taxing these companies. The indirect taxes on companies and producers are killing this country and that is why we are going bankrupt. We cannot compete against the rest of the world if we have to pay these exorbitant taxes that are placed upon us.

The Richter Drilling company, which is one of the biggest on-shore drilling companies based at Roma, has recently put off 50 people. Dick Warner, the charter operator there, has had to sell three aeroplanes. He has built up a fleet of eight or nine aeroplanes to service these outback rigs. Richter Drilling employs an enormous number of people in the oil search and the seismic work that goes on. More people are actually employed in looking for oil than there are when they actually find it. Once the oil is found, using today's technology, a walking beam, or what is called a donkey, is put on to pump the oil, and big platforms are built in the Gippsland basin. Once these platforms are all set up not many people are involved in operating them. They just push a few buttons and the oil gushes out of the ground. But an awful lot of people are involved in looking for oil, maintaining the platforms and doing all the seismic work and they are the people who are first affected and affected markedly.

We have to get out of these taxing arrangements and allow these exploration companies to continue to look for oil because we have not stopped using it. We are still using it and the cheaper it gets the more we will use. Now that the price has dropped we will obviously want more oil and we will have to find more of it if we are to remain self-sufficient in it. Oil is enormously important to Australia. As bad as our balance of payments is, if we had to import all our oil as some countries do we would be in a horrendous state. We would be bankrupt. We are only half bankrupt now but we would be totally bankrupt if we were paying the import bills that we would have to pay as against what we are exporting, which is practically nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't want to be dependent on the Arabs, do we?

—We do not want to be dependent on any nation if we can help it. We have only to look at the sort of fuss that has blown up in the last week with Indonesia, which is one of the biggest oil producers in the world. In past years we have purchased a lot of oil from Indonesia but it could turn off that tap. It just has to have a bit of a row with us about a couple of our journalists or something-it is pretty touchy-and it will say: `We will not supply you with any oil'. That is what happens with these countries. In places such as Injune, which is north of Roma, the Denison Trough gas project which was to be developed has been put on ice. That project, which was worth $270m, will not go ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: Fuel prices still represent a big cost to the farmers. Of course, this Labor Government tries to make out that it is being kind to farmers. In actual fact farmers are paying more in fuel taxes now than they ever did. I mentioned earlier the amount of fuel that farmers use. Diesel is exempt from excise tax and we are obviously grateful to the Government for that. There is now a 19c a litre rebate for diesel but farmers are still paying well-head taxes. I see that the Minister is shaking his head in disagreement. I will run through a few figures for him. Because we are still paying well-head taxes on crude oil, last year-1984-85-the farming community paid $420m. It is estimated that farmers will pay $440m in 1985-86 and even with the drop in the price of oil I estimate that the farming community will still have to pay $220m in well-head taxes. Indirectly we are paying these horrific taxes. It means that we cannot compete on world markets. This Government makes out that it is being friendly to the farmers but it is not the only group that is getting a rebate on the diesel excise. Farmers get 19.2c a litre now. Miners, stationary engines and power generators are getting 16.3c a litre and old age homes, hospitals and other medical facilities are getting a 13c a litre rebate. So the farmers are not the only group that is getting a rebate.

Forty per cent of on farm fuel used is petrol. This is another figure that the Government does not seem to understand. It is estimated that, before the Government's supposed fuel price fall, the old excise rate of 10c a litre meant that farmers were paying about $89m in fuel excise on petrol. With the Government increasing the petrol excise to 19.2c per litre farmers are now paying an extra $78m. If we add those two figures we have an on-farm indirect taxation figure of $156m in a given year for excise on petrol. The figure for well-head taxes is $220m and the Government is now taxing oils and greases which are used on farms, which means that farmers will be paying $3.25m a year. The freight subsidy scheme, which the Government withdrew, is costing the farming community $25m a year. At present there is a total indirect cost to farmers of $404m a year for fuel, yet this Government seems to think that we are paying less tax now than we ever did. That is absolute nonsense. We are paying more tax now than we ever did.

I just point out to the House-surely there is no need for me to point out to the Minister and the people involved on the Labor side of politics-how hard the farming community and other people in primary industry are finding things. They do not all come to Canberra and demonstrate because they have fun doing it. They come to Canberra for a reason: They are finding it very difficult to survive. One of the main reasons is the high cost of fuel. The other problem farmers have is the fuel rebate scheme. It so happens that a lot of farmers are not using it because the Government is forcing people to fill out the forms themselves. They are damn busy people. Of the 156,000 people claiming the rebate 125,000 are primary producers but there happens to be 250,000 primary producers registered. Two hundred and fifty thousand people put in a tax return and claim to be primary producers yet only 125,000 people are claiming the diesel rebate. That is great for Treasury because when it adopts these schemes it forces people to put in returns. Half the primary producers in Australia are not putting in returns. That is great for Treasury because it means it is not returning the rebate to them. I suggest to the Minister that, if he wants to help the farming community, he should look at this problem and at the fact that a lot of people are not getting the diesel rebate mainly because at the end of 12 months the scheme runs out and farmers are very busy and do not have the time to do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Oil Company (Stock Loss Reimbursement) Bill is only the latest example of the utter inappropriateness of the Government's import parity pricing formula. Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be only too well aware that that policy is that Australian produced crude oils are priced at the cost of their replacement with imported crude oil and consequently sold to Australian refiners under the crude oil allocation scheme. I must say, though, that I take issue with my colleague and friend the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron) when he maintained that the import parity pricing was incorrect from the very start. I believe that the decision taken by the then Fraser-Anthony Government was a very courageous one. It was extremely appropriate at the time and led to creating a climate of conservation as well as an economic climate for further exploration and production. However, that was several years ago; that was in 1978. Though the objectives of the import parity pricing formula were achieved over a passage of time it is very clear that, in the last few years, the policy has been disadvantageous to the Australian economy, specifically consumers and particularly primary producers.

SPEECH.PARA: First, the policy was expressed in American dollars as applied to Saudi Arabian light crude. As the American dollar appreciated we were not just paying world parity price; we were paying far above it. So the pricing policy was inaccurate. We thought that we were paying only the world price, but we were not. We were paying far above what properly could be termed the world price. Secondly, under the pricing formula, savings to consumers as the world price tumbled were not passed on. So the pricing formula was dated several years ago. The Government, because of its extraordinary reliance on the revenue raised under the policy, has refused accurately to reflect its policy.

I find it curious that under this legislation the Government intends to compensate oil refiners for any loss incurred in a change of the rules of the game. I find it curious because there is no consistency in the Government's approach. Sadly, the Government has not shown the same respect for consumers when it comes to the rules of the game. On the one hand, the Government is prepared to compensate oil refiners for any loss suffered under the rigid application of the import parity pricing, yet it is not prepared to pass on to consumers their entitlement under the same pricing formula. I find the Government's action hypocritical and curious, to say the least. I stress that I find myself unable to oppose the measure before the House. I very much regret that we are in our current position. We would not be in this position but for the Government's adherence to the import parity pricing formula and its refusal to deregulate the marketing and price arrangements. If it had done so, as is the Opposition's policy, we certainly would not have the compensation problem we now have. In other words, the Government has no one to blame but itself for having to pay out of Consolidated Revenue the extraordinary sum of $124,800,000.

I have been approached several times in my electorate, as no doubt many honourable members have, by members of the public who are unable to understand why out of Consolidated Revenue-taxpayers' funds-and at a loss to other programs, oil refiners or companies must receive this amount of money. One tries to explain the technicalities, as I shall shortly attempt to do. However, the fact is that the man in the street, the ordinary Australian who is paying inflated prices for his fuel, primary producers and small businesses which also must pay high interest rates and which are facing disaster, are unable to understand why large multinational corporations are to receive what is, to all intents and purposes, a windfall.

The Government had no choice because of the rigid structure under which it operates. The purpose of this legislation is to compensate oil refiners for stock losses suffered during February 1986 as a result of the dramatic drop in crude oil prices passed on in the 1 March import parity pricing adjustment. The reason for this is that government regulation which, on the one hand, requires refiners to take stocks of crude oil and, on the other hand, limits their ability to recoup any cost penalty through wholesale price controls administered by the Prices Surveillance Authority.

The import parity pricing set on 1 January 1986 was $43.71 per barrel. Refiners were required to take supplies of domestic crude oil at this price during January and February despite the rapid plunge in comparable world crude oil prices. The Government lowered the price of domestic crude oil supplies to be allocated to refiners on 1 March 1986 to $27.09 per barrel which is a fall of $16.62 per barrel. Prices were again adjusted downward by a further $6.10 per barrel on 1 April 1986. Under normal market conditions companies would have been able to limit stock losses by delaying stock purchases and price reductions on sales. However, the allocation system and wholesale price controls prevent this normal commercial transaction. So the Government had no choice. It was caught between the devil and the deep blue sea. But why should we be forced to compensate oil refiners for losses suffered because of this Government's stupidity in refusing to recognise the realities of the world oil market and, further, turning its back on the obvious advantages to Australian producers, to our export industries, to small businesses and to ordinary consumers of lower fuel prices?

This Government depends heavily, if not totally, on the revenue raised from not only oil producers but also fuel excises applied at petrol stations. When Labor came to office in March 1983, Mr Deputy Speaker, you will be interested and no doubt shocked to know, Commonwealth excise on petrol and diesel fuel was a little over 6c a litre. As of now Commonwealth excise is over 18c a litre.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 19.2c.

— It is closer to 19c a litre, as my friend from Maranoa reminds me. My calculations were done to 26 March of this year. This represents a massive 200 per cent increase and that is not taking into account the punitive taxes applied by Labor State Governments which have increased by a similar measure. Those figures cannot be disputed by the Government. They cannot be argued away. They cannot be blamed on any previous administration. Labor has also tied fuel excises to the consumer price index as from the 23 August 1983 Federal Budget. That means that fuel excises automatically increase every six months according to the CPI. For the average motorist, therefore, fuel prices will rise in the future according to movements in the CPI. We now have an inflation rate of some 9.2 per cent. For that reason there is little relief in sight for the motorist, the primary producer or small businesses-almost every Australian who depends on fuel so greatly.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party of Australia, together with our coalition partners, the Liberal Party of Australia, believe that the Government should pass on to Australian consumers the full benefit of world oil price cuts. The loss of government revenue from a full cut should be made up by cutting the wasteful Labor programs. Medicare, which costs somewhere between $2 billion and $3 billion a year, is the starting point. There are so many other areas of government administration we should at least be examining but which we at least have firm ideas on, such as the unemployed being required to do some work for receiving unemployment benefits. Scandalous wastage and fraud occurs in a whole range of social security benefits, particularly the supporting parent's pension. The Labor Party should not underestimate the depth of feeling in the community regarding wastage, duplication and dishonesty in out social security services.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m. the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101a. The honourable member will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 12.45 p.m. to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did the the Minister Sport, Recreation and Tourism first become aware that Mr Groux, during the time he was employed on his personal staff, was doing work for Mr Justice Murphy concerning the criminal charges that the judge was facing?

—I am in no position to say exactly when that was because I did not diarise it. As I answered in this House yesterday, it was of little importance to me when Mr Groux suggested to me, in a very brief conversation, that he wanted to do some work for Mr Justice Murphy. I said: `What you do in your own time is your business'. I did not diarise it and I do not know exactly when it was.

—Has the attention of the Acting Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs been drawn to the well documented Australian Broadcasting Corporation program entitled Background Briefing of 13, 20 and 27 April as well as the Four Corners program of 21 April in which a number of former nazi war criminals now living in Australia were named? Has the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs checked its files to explain how it was possible for types such as Srecko Rover and Lyenko Urbanchich to migrate to Australia without disclosing their nazi past and their involvement in war crimes in Yugoslavia during the Second World War? Is the Minister aware that the nazis named are continuing their nazi Ustasha activities in Australia? Will the Minister undertake that the Department will conduct an inquiry into these matters?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware of the allegations that have been made recently on an ABC program and that have been been summarised by the honourable gentleman. Both myself and the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, before he went overseas, have asked the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to conduct a review of the relevant files to see what the basis was for testing immigrants at that time. The honourable member will appreciate that this involves an examination which goes back many years. The investigation that is being conducted is directed to the question of process; it is not dealing with the rights of any particular individuals. As soon as I have that information I will make it available to the honourable gentleman and to the House.

—My question is to the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. While employed with the Minister, on how many occasions did Mr Groux speak to him about the work he was doing for Mr Justice Murphy? What was the nature of that work?

—As I said in the House yesterday, Mr Groux mentioned to me on one occasion that he was interested in doing some work for Mr Justice Murphy. I said: `That is not part of your charter with me; that is not part of your job. Whatever you do for Mr Justice Murphy or whatever else you do in your own time is your business'.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: TECHNICAL JARGON

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware that many pensioners are unsure of their correct entitlements and find it difficult to understand technical jargon in correspondence; If so, what steps has he taken to overcome this problem and when can these be expected to take effect?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I think it is a matter of considerable concern amongst many of Australia's pensioners that the form of communication used by the Department of Social Security is often incomprehensible and often full of jargon with the result that often people are unclear about their rights. On occasions there have been overpayments. The Government has developed a new plain English form of letter to be sent to people on social security.
—Are you going to give a copy to the Prime Minister?

—The Leader of the Opposition probably wishes that there was not effective communication between him and many of Australia's pensioners because he is so often putting them down. The first of these letters will be delivered this week to coincide with Thursday's pension increase. Each letter is personalised to the individual recipient and sets out very clearly how his or her entitlement has been calculated and the domestic and financial information that the Department has used in its calculation. The letters ask people on social security to inform the Department if any of the details shown in the letter are wrong. It also points out that it is not necessary to contact the Department if the details are right or if the recipient's income has changed but is still below the limit shown on the letter.

ANSWER.PARA: The letters are an important part of the Government's strategy to improve communications and to combat social security overpayments. Making it easier for people to ensure that the Department is using correct and up to date information in its calculations of entitlement will help to reduce overpayments resulting from oversight or accidental misinformation. More specifically, the letters will keep people informed of the basic details of their entitlement, advise people of their obligations to notify the Department of a change in their circumstances and enable the Department to maintain addresses and generally improve communication.

One of the great problems with social security is the scale of the operations. We are dealing with millions of Australian households. Almost every family in Australia, one way or another, receives payments from the Department of Social Security. A massive task is involved in communicating with people in such a way that they have a clear understanding of their rights. I believe that these improved advices and letters from the Department, which will be extended on an annual basis beyond age pensioners to unemployment beneficiaries and all people who receive family allowances, will be of considerable benefit to pensioners and beneficiaries in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Did Mr Groux, while a member of his staff, spend the latter part of August and part of September 1985 working almost exclusively in investigating material for Mr Justice Murphy and reporting to him regularly in both Canberra and Sydney, as reported in the Canberra Times this morning?

—If Mr Groux did as the Leader of the National Party of Australia suggested, that is news to me. If he did it, he certainly was doing it in direct conflict with the duties to which I had assigned him.

—Is the Minister for Health aware of the criticism from Opposition members that the Government's anti-drug campaign is a $100m flop and the claim of the Leader of the Opposition that the campaign is designed for self-promotion? Are these criticisms correct and have the Premiers of Tasmania and Queensland expressed similar views?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the extraordinary document which has been circulated under the name of the honourable member for Gilmore in which he describes himself as the chairman of the coalition drugs task force. That is a body from which we have had not one positive comment about drugs since whenever it was inaugurated. All it seems to be able to do is devote itself to quite negative criticism. I can imagine nothing more negative, more destructive or indeed more foolish than this present effort from the so-called coalition drugs task force. It has surveyed some 500 people and has drawn conclusions about the success of the drug offensive campaign. Let me say first of all that I do not know where this task force got the 500. I presume they were Liberal Party branch members, though I am surprised that there are so many left in a party which is so negative, derelict and destructive.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look at the facts we have to date on the drug offensive. Less than 200 complaints have come into the organisation about the distribution of the booklet and they have been followed up in each case by the Salmat direct marketing organisation. There has been a carry-through by the supervisors of that organisation and they have reported that in a survey of $20,000 households, taken immediately after distribution, the booklet had been received by between 98 and 99 per cent. Additionally the booklet is also available through the information hot line number and already we have received some 7,000 requests for extra copies of the booklet, in many cases from parents impressed by it, by schools and by other government authorities. Moreover, the hot line, which has been advertised in that booklet, has already had 13,500 calls, showing the kind of interest that has been aroused.

On Saturday night some four million Australian viewers saw Dire Straits, one of the most famous rock bands internationally, use throughout its program the drug offensive logos to get at the very people in the community who both the band and the Government want to approach. I was accompanied on that occasion by the Leader of the Opposition and preceding that broadcast there was a drug advertisement by the leader of that band, who has actively supported the Drug Offensive campaign. This kind of foolish, destructive, negative and nit-picking criticism directed by this peculiar organisation, the coalition drugs task force, does no service to this Government or to any government in this country which has supported the drug offensive campaign. So the criticisms are directed not just at us but at the governments of Queensland, Tasmania and the Northern Territory as well as the Labor governments in this country. If this is an example of the destructive, negative approach of the Opposition, I am not surprised that it is so hard to find Liberal governments around this country.

Let me say finally that it is easy to make nit-picking arguments about a campaign of this nature but if Opposition members really want to make a partisan campaign of this issue, so be it. We will be proud of our record compared with their do nothing record on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism: How was it possible, in view of his previous answer, for a person employed as a consultant on his staff, answerable to him as Minister, to spend almost an entire month working on an allegedly extra-curricular activity without the Minister being aware of it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate what I said a minute ago: If Mr Groux--
—You must know. Come on!
—Do you want the question answered or not?
—Yes.
—Then if you shut your silly mouth I will answer it.
—The Leader of the Opposition has been asked on numerous occasions by the Chair to have regard for the authority of the Chair. I now ask him to cease interjecting across the table.

—If Mr Groux was doing the work attributed to him by the two previous Opposition questioners, he was doing it without my knowledge. My statement is this: This series of questions and an article in the Canberra Times this morning are predicated apparently on an affidavit supplied to the honourable member for O'Connor and to the Canberra Times by Mr Groux. I suggest, with deep respect to the Opposition and without any intended disrespect to Mr Groux-who I think is more to be pitied than abused-that the Opposition's information is based on statements from a man who lives in a fantasy world.
—Is this a character assassination?
—Order! The House will come to order. The House might take note of the fact that the Chair is on its feet.

—I think I heard some interjections about my being a character assassin. I am not about to assassinate anybody's character. I am suggesting to the honourable member for O'Connor and the Leader of the Opposition that they ought to be very careful about checking their facts before they make these charges because their informant does not have a long record of veracity.
—How come you gave him a job?

—I have been challenged about how I employed him. I am quite happy to go through the process. Mr Groux is the man who blew the whistle on some cheats in the meat scandal-a scandal which of course operated under the amazing stewardship of the present Leader of the National Party of Australia. His lack of capacity in his own department allowed the meat scandal to take place. Anyhow, as it turns out, Mr Groux became a very credible witness, having turned Crown witness and having been charged with an offence relating to that meat scandal. He blew the whistle on a lot of cheats. As somebody who had been active in the meat industry for a long time I admired what he did because he helped to clean the cheats out of the meat industry. Because of his honesty, because of his courage in that case, he was unable to obtain a job in the meat industry. He came to Canberra and was recommended to me by the honourable member for Diamond Valley, Mr Peter Staples--

—I hope honourable members opposite find that amusing. Mr Justice Woodward recommended him as a witness of great honesty who showed great courage in coming forward. As far as I was concerned his credentials were impeccable. I gave him a job with the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Service here. He did a very good job for me over there, once again uncovering a few cheats. In the meantime my stewardship in that area was terminated and it became part of the portfolio of the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services.

—I am glad honourable members opposite find it so highly amusing. So Mr Groux was again out of work. Because of the work he had done for me, which was of good order, I employed him as a consultant to do a specific task for me. I am afraid that there can be a parallel drawn between Mr Groux and the honourable member for O'Connor-a good parallel. Mr Groux suddenly found himself-in his own mind, I am sure this is the case-in all innocence, in all honesty, in the vanguard of the fight against crime. He suddenly undertook to himself to be the arbiter of all decency in the community.

ANSWER.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor, having had one alleged victory in his mind-having produced some rather scurrilous information against the Treasurer which, according to the media, he used to great effect but with which, in the view of all of us on the Government benches, he merely sullied himself-is now prepared to accept anything from anybody if he thinks it will denigrate somebody on this side of the House. Let me tell honourable members something about the witness he has got. I will just give one instance. I have a letter, which I will not quote but which I will table, from a highly respected man who works for the Lend Lease Sports Foundation-a man called Lee Donnelly. He is highly respected man in this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know about it.
—Oh, you know about it, do you?
—I warn the honourable member for O'Connor that if he continues to interject I will name him.

—The man Groux descended into flights of fantasy. He undertook to himself all sorts of positions and all sorts of accolades. He informed Mr Donnelly that he could arrange for him to become a member of the board of the Australian Institute of Sport in Canberra and went further. At a public meeting, in front of about 100 people, he announced: `Today, I have arranged for Mr Donnelly to become a member of the Board of the Institute of Sport'. Mr Donnelly was delighted. He then contacted his boss at Lend Lease in Sydney and asked for his permission to take the job on the board. The news, of course, travelled the network of the Lend Lease Sports Foundation throughout Australia. Mr Donnelly was inundated with letters and telegrams of commendation, bottles of champagne, flowers and all the paraphernalia associated with his great success. Mr Groux also announced that the appointment was for six years. I think Mr Groux also went on to say that he had been appointed Chairman of the Institute that day, having defeated the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Lionel Bowen, in a ballot. This is the measure of the imagination of a man who is now giving affidavits that the Opposition is using as holy writ to try to persecute me, the Prime Minister and anyone else. Mr Donnelly in due course contacted me and said: `I have not heard anything about my appointment to the board yet'.
—When was that?

—About three weeks after this announcement. He was waiting for his letter of approval. Eventually I had to write to Mr Donnelly and apologise most profusely and poor old Mr Donnelly had to write a letter to all his friends as follows;

ANSWER.PARA: It is with deep humiliation and personal embarrassment that I inform you that the announcement made by a ministerial adviser on Monday, 23 September 1985 concerning my appointment to the board of directors of the Australian Institute of Sport was in fact without any foundation. I had not at any time been considered for such a position.

That is one of probably 100 instances that I can give honourable members of the flights of fantasy with which this man associated himself. Yet the Canberra Times had the hide to publish on its front page an affidavit of this very doubtful witness condemning people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got the date of that?

—I will table it. It is dated 30 September 1985, just after I had arranged for Mr Groux to give me a resignation and terminate his position on my staff. If honourable members opposite want to use Mr Groux as their credible witness to pour scorn on anyone on the Government benches or to suggest that I in any way approved of Mr Groux doing what honourable members opposite allege, namely, work for Mr Justice Murphy-and I have no evidence that he did work for Mr Justice Murphy-then that is their business.
—Order! Did the Minister wish to table only one paper?

—In fairness, I also table a letter to me from Mr Donnelly outlining his complaint; a letter from John Cheffers, the Director of the Australian Institute of Sport, reiterating the embarrassment the Institute suffered over that; my letter to Mr Donnelly, apologising; and a letter from Mr Donnelly to Mr Groux also asking him what was the truth.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence. Can the Minister inform the House of the progress this Government has made in investigating and improving the conditions of service personnel and their families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question. He, along with a number of other honourable members, has been most assiduous in his advocacy of the needs of his constituents who happen to be service personnel. I am pleased to be able to report that the person I appointed to do a review of the conditions of service families, Ms Sue Hamilton, has now reported to me. I would like to place on record my thanks to her for the work she has done. In the course of her review, she visited many defence bases, including those with which the honourable gentleman would be most familiar, and saw some 4,300 service personnel or their spouses.

ANSWER.PARA: In what has been a very impressive survey of their requirements, she has identified several problems. She believes them to be poor communications between the Services and service families, lack of extended family and other community support systems for those families, poor employment opportunities for them, low self-esteem among the spouses, family stress caused by disruption to children's education because of frequent postings, and dissatisfaction with the standard of service housing, housing maintenance and the removal of personal effects. The report not only identifies those problems but also has some very practical suggestions as to how we might deal with them.

I would commend Ms Hamilton for having been sensible in ensuring that some of the responses to the problems that have been confronted are going to be dealt with on what might be termed a self-help basis, making use of the very considerable resources that are to hand among the service spouses themselves at the various installations to improve both child care facilities and the dissemination of information on service conditions and rights, and also the possibilities for providing an employment service for service spouses.

She has been sensible and modest in what she has proposed in terms of expenditure and the large number of very helpful recommendations she makes comes to an amount of $6m. I will take the view, as we look at her report in detail in the Department of Defence, that it is a readily implementable report, that it ought to be implemented and that a high priority must now be given to the question of the morale of service spouses as an important feature of the situation in which service personnel find themselves in their willingness to continue in the service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you make a statement on it, Kim?

—I will not get a debate out of the right honourable member for New England, I know that. I have a very long list of steps taken by this Government over the last couple of years to address deficiencies that occurred in the administration of our opponents of the defence forces over the last 20 or 30 years. They include providing for service personnel the capacity to have their own independent tribunal and arbitration of their wage claims so they are no longer subject to the capricious actions of Ministers, of which the right honourable member for New England, who is heckling, is so aware when it comes to a consideration of their just requirements. It also, of course, complements what we are doing in the housing area in regard to improving the conditions of service personnel. It is a matter we take seriously and, therefore, we can look forward to the implementation of the recommendations made by Ms Hamilton, which I think will do a very great deal for service personnel in this community.

—I ask a further question of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. In the light of the Minister's obvious preparedness to table certain documents, I ask: Will the Minister give details of the actual duties and activities performed by Mr Groux when he was employed as a full-time consultant on the Minister's staff and in particular for the period August, September and October 1985. Will the Minister table all diary notes, worksheets, movement vouchers, travel warrants, details of Mr Groux's home base and any other records relating to visits to and work done by Mr Groux in Sydney in 1985?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, I will not table those things because some of them, in light of information that came to me after Mr Groux's resignation, are under investigation.
—Ah!
—Nothing to do with the allegation of the honourable member about Murphy by the way. The dates that the honourable member mentioned were August, September and October?
—Yes.
—Let me put the record straight.
—My records are always straight. That is one thing I can say that a lot of Opposition members cannot say-I tell the truth, and all the time.
—Particularly about the Parramatta Leagues Club.

—What about the Parramatta Leagues Club? If the Leader of the Opposition has something to say, he should say it louder. I am ashamed of him. I thought he was better. After two conversations with the Prime Minister on 22 and 26 August when he brought certain facts to my notice concerning Mr Groux's record of personal behaviour, he suggested to me that Mr Groux should be asked to resign. It would have been a fairly simple matter to have sacked Mr Groux I would have thought, but as those sitting opposite who were Ministers will know, and as we found out with the Australian Bicentennial Authority, to sack somebody on contract is a pretty tricky affair. I thought the better thing to do was to get Mr Groux to resign, which he did on 20 September in these terms:

ANSWER.PARA: My dear Minister, It is with deep regret that I hereby tender my resignation as your consultant, effective as from c.o.b., 1st November 1985. Yours in friendship, Rodney Gordon Groux.

I table that letter. With regard to Mr Groux's duties, they were described as such. I believe that the Opposition has a copy of the reference I provided Mr Groux-a very guarded reference. I am happy to read it because it happens to outline them and I can do it all at the one time. It states:
Thank you for your letter of 20 September 1985 in which you tendered your resignation, with the intention that it be effective from 1 November 1985.
I would like to place on record my sincere appreciation of your assistance since 6 May 1985 when you joined my staff as Consultant and were assigned the following tasks:

Assist and advise on a variety of takeover procedures and new entities to be set up such as the National Sports Centre and setting up the Sports Aid Foundation. Provide advice in the area of the Australian Government Publishing Service, Government Bookshops and EXPO. Such tasks as are from time to time specified by the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism. Such tasks as are from time to time specified by the Secretary, Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism with Ministerial consent.
You have demonstrated your willingness to protect the Government's interests, and consequently those of the taxpayer, on many occasions in the past--
this of course was dated September--

In 1984 during your period of employment as Trainee Manager with the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Services Ltd you drew attention to certain procedural and administrative deficiencies in the running of the Hostel where you were employed. These were taken up separately by the Commonwealth Audit Office and corrective action was instituted by the Company.

Your valuable assistance as a Crown Witness during investigations of the Australian meat industry by the Woodward Royal Commission in the period 1981-83 is well documented. It was reported that while it was found there was an attitude of reluctance in the meat industry to assist the Commission, you were a notable exception. In the Commission's report you were given due credit for your belief that the long-term interests of producers and of law-abiding processors in the industry would be better served by frank disclosure than by secrecy.
In accepting your resignation I would like to take this opportunity to thank you for your assistance during our association, and offer my best wishes for the future.

Subsequent to that reference-I read it because I know that the Opposition has a copy, and I might as well put it on the record-certain facets of Mr Groux's behaviour, for instance the incident with Mr Donnelly, came to my notice. A whole barrage of information came to my notice which confirmed my belief that my staff was better off without Mr Groux's services. If in that period Mr Groux was doing any work with Mr Justice Murphy, that is something of which I have no knowledge. I say that without any equivocation. If Mr Groux's affidavit states otherwise, well, it might well be that he did. It might well be that he did not either. Perhaps some reference to Mr Murphy or the Federal Police might establish what he did or did not do. So far as tabling the documents are concerned, I am not prepared to table them because some of Mr Groux's travel movements in that period are under investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why?
—Because they were undertaken without my approval.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the Speaker's Gallery today the Hon. Kevin Newman, former Minister and member of this House. On behalf of the House I bid him welcome.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable members-Hear, hear!
