TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Attorney-General been drawn to the concern expressed by the record and video industry over cassette piracy? Is the Minister aware that this theft is putting at risk the multimillion dollar recording industry in Australia? Is it a fact that ridiculously low penalties for breach of copyright do not discourage cassette piracy, and what action will the Minister take to protect the recording and video industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter has been of concern for some time because of the extensive piracy of what are called unauthorised commercial dealings in infringing copyright. The last time the penalties were brought in was in 1981 and it is appropriate that they would have been reviewed. Towards the end of last year I received advice as to the type of proposed new penalties that could be imposed. They would relate, for example, to first conviction on matters other than a film of $500 per article per person or $2,500 per article per corporation. Or first conviction for a film the proposals were for a person $1,500 per article and/or two years' imprisonment, and for a corporation $7,500 per article. There was also a proposal that on subsequent conviction for a film the penalty would increase per person to $1,500 an article and/or five years' imprisonment, and for a corporation $15,000 per article, with an overall limit of a fine per offence to be on the basis of, a person, $50,000 and, a corporation, $250,000.

ANSWER.PARA: At that time I also received representations from the Video Industry Distributors Association, the organisation representing those concerned. I gave the Association that sort of information about the proposals that were to be brought by way of legislation. I was surprised after that to have representations made by VIDA that it regarded the penalties as not being high enough. As I understand on advice from my Department, the proposed penalties would be the highest in the world, but I have asked that there be discussions between representatives of my Department and representatives of VIDA as to the position. I understand at this stage that the representatives of VIDA feel that the penalties ought to be increased even further. I emphasise the distinction between the proposed penalties and those that have applied since 1981.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they understand that it was per article?

—I do not think they do understand, and that might be one way of saying that penalties of $250,000 per offence and penalties of $15,000 per article are pretty substantial, and are a very substantial increase over 1981. I have now gone ahead and given instructions to have appropriate legislation prepared to encompass those penalties, and I hope that we can introduce that legislation during the course of this session.

—Can the Prime Minister inform the House when he first became aware that a consultant on the staff of the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism was involved in matters relating to the preparation of Mr Justice Murphy's defence? What was the substance of the matters raised by the Prime Minister in his discussion with the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism on, I think, 23 and 24 August, referred to by the Minister in his previous answer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I though that I was never going to be asked. I am indebted to the Leader of the Opposition. At the outset let me confess that I have something of an animus in this matter. I confess that at the outset because in the various realms of fantasy that have been inhabited by Mr Groux one really struck me badly; I did not like it. Mr Groux is reported to have said that he did law with Hawke, that he came first and Hawke came second. That is a remarkable achievement in any circumstance, but particularly remarkable when one remembers that this man is supposed to be 39 years of age. I commenced my law degree in 1947, so Mr Groux was outdoing me before the age of one year. Members will see that I have an animus in this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me come to the facts. It was brought to my attention in August that there were certain facets of the operation of Mr Groux that were disturbing. These concerned two things: Firstly, that it was said that he was occupying some of his time managing a meat store in Canberra and, secondly, that he was an undischarged bankrupt, a fact that he had not disclosed at the time of making his application for a job as consultant. When these matters were brought to my attention by a member of my staff, I was obviously concerned because the question of the propriety and the impeccability of the people who are working for this Government is, as is well known, a matter of concern for me. Immediately, therefore, I asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism to come to my office, which he did on Thursday 22 August. I then acquainted the Minister with the concerns that I had. Over the weekend a document was made available to me from the Attorney-General's Department, and let me say that in what I am going to refer to now I take no pleasure. The initiation of this has come from those who would seek to deal with people like this. They have put it on the table; we are not going to sit here and not respond to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You employed him.

—The Leader of the Opposition should not worry about the question of employment-the Minister has indicated the basis upon which that was done. In fact, the basis of the appointment was cleared by a statement of the Public Service Board and by the panel which considered this matter. Therefore, the appropriate processes were followed. Let us come to the basis upon which I acted in this matter. I have indicated what I did on 22 August in discussions with the Minister. Over the weekend I had brought to my attention a document from the Attorney-General's Department. This was a note to the Attorney-General from the Inspector-General in Bankruptcy, as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The purpose of this minute is to inform you of certain sensitive information about Mr Rodney Groux, ministerial consultant to the Minister which has come to my knowledge during my inquiries into representations Mr Groux made to the official receiver in Melbourne on behalf of Mr M. J. Rutherford, an undischarged bankrupt. In essence, the sense of the information is Mr Groux has been a debtor in three bankruptcy proceedings, one of which is still current.

Mr Groux, according to the official receiver, had some past business relationship, the precise nature of which is not yet clear, with the bankrupt Rutherford, on whose behalf he now makes representation, and both Mr Groux and Mr Rutherford were crown witnesses in the Victorian meat scandal inquiry. A copy of Mr Groux's letter to the official receiver is attached for your information. The substance of the letter is unimportant for the purposes of this minute and will be dealt with by me pursuant to the powers under section 12 of the Bankruptcy Act.

Background: During the course of my inquiries I have ascertained that Mr Groux is the same person as Rodney Gordon Groux who was made bankrupt in Queensland on 13 April 1970, discharged by operation of law on 14 April 1975 and who entered into a composition with creditors under part 10 of the Bankruptcy Act in Victoria on 18 August 1978 and into a deed of arrangement under part 10 also in Victoria on 6 March 1984. The deed of arrangement will, I understand, remain in operation until 6 March 1987 or thereabouts. I am informed by the official receiver in Melbourne that his investigations to date indicate that Mr Groux and the bankrupt Rutherford were business associates in Victoria and became involved in the Victorian export meat scandal which eventually led to criminal proceedings against a meat exporter named Hammond.

I understand that Mr Groux and Mr Rutherford were meat traders who sold donkey meat to Hammond, which was later processed and exported as mutton. The official receiver says that Mr Groux and Mr Rutherford were Crown witnesses at the Royal Commission into the matter. They were not charged with any offence because they were not directly connected with the fraud and they were co-operative witnesses. The official receiver is pursuing his inquiries into Mr Rutherford's bankruptcy and will be providing a further report to me in due course.

That was the information that came to me over the weekend. On the Monday I received further information from the office of the Attorney-General. I repeat: I regret that I have to go into this matter, but the miserable and increasingly despised Opposition members cannot talk about any economic issue in this country, cannot talk about any matter of moment. Their habitat is the gutter. Having chosen that habitat and having chosen their sources of information, let them live with the consequences. This is what I was informed of on the twenty-sixth:

Groux is a very active police informer and a con man with a long history. The police who have been handling him as an informer, both at the Victorian and Federal level, say that he is a thorough crook. He lives mainly by informing and would sell anything for money. He has no convictions, but in 1978 was charged with theft by deception. The charge was dismissed on the grounds that he intended to give the money back. He was charged with conspiracy over the meat scandal but was discharged. He is involved in several undischarged bankruptcies. There is an extreme amount of consternation that he could be in a Minister's office. There is no knowledge as to how Groux came to have connections in New South Wales. His parents came from Queensland and he was educated in Victoria. He has been employed as a meat worker, apprenticed as a master butcher, a meat inspector. He has been a weights and measures inspector and a car salesman . . . He has been in partnership with Rutherford.

I assume that there will be no wonder that, in the light of the information that I had in relation to Mr Groux, I told the Minister that it was my belief and indeed my instruction to him that Mr Groux's services should be dispensed with, and the Minister proceeded to do this. So that the full flavour of what the Minister has already given to the House can be properly savoured by all members, I will read the actual circumstances of the letter which has already been tabled about this gentleman. They are as follows:

It was the evening of 23 September at the annual general meeting of the Merchants Association of Woden Shopping Centre at which Mr Groux was present to receive a trophy for the store trading as Meat City.
I am reading from Mr Donnelly's letter to the Minister. The letter continues:

In his acceptance speech Mr Groux announced to the 97 guests and three staff of the Southern Cross Club that besides being a trader in the centre he was also a ministerial adviser. In that capacity he was happy to announce, `That as a reward for his hard work and devotion to junior sport Lee Donnelly was today appointed to the Board of Directors of the Australian Institute of Sport, and it is for a six year term, too'.
The silly fellows opposite should understand the sort of person they are dealing with. He is a man who is living in the area of fantasy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You employed him and you gave him a reference.

—And it was a very highly qualified reference, too. The Opposition seeks to rely on the allegations of this man. Let me say this: The affidavit that was given by this man went to the Director of Public Prosecutions. The Australian Federal Police are examining this matter. I spoke yesterday with the head of the Federal Police, Commissioner Grey. He has given me a preliminary report on investigations which have only recently commenced. He has told me that it is clear from those investigations to this point that there is no evidence to support allegations against any Minister of the Crown.

ANSWER.PARA: Let it be quite clear that this country is faced with the worst Opposition in its history. It is absolutely incapable. Have we had, yesterday or today, one question about the economy? Have we had one question about any matter which goes to the welfare of the people of Australia? Of course, we have not. Honourable members opposite, reduced by their own intrinsic incompetence, get into the gutter and grovel with people of this calibre. Is it any wonder that they are going down and down, as they will continue to do until such time as they obtain principles and a decent leader and concern themselves with the issues of this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I take a point of order. I ask the Prime Minister to table the document from which he quoted, a statement from the Commissioner of Police.
—I do not mind tabling it. I am more than happy to do so.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SINCLAIR
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the right honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—He may proceed.

—On 21 February this year the Australian Financial Review reported a testimony by the Chief Finance Executive of Aussat Pty Ltd, Mr Donald Cocks, in a defamation case against John Fairfax and Sons Ltd in the Supreme Court of New South Wales the previous day. Mr Cocks was quoted as saying that in May 1982, when I was Minister for Communications, I estimated at a Press conference that the all-up costs of an Aussat satellite system would be about $650m. He was further quoted as saying `He got it wrong' and as stating that he understood I had acquired the figure from a departmental briefing and had misunderstood or misinterpreted that figure.

SPEECH.PARA: In March this year I wrote to the Secretary to the Department of Communications and to the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, seeking access to the relevant briefing material provided to me before the Press conference to which Mr Cocks referred. That material has now been provided.

The transcript of the section of the Press conference to which Mr Cocks referred shows that I was asked about the contrast between my announcement that the initial cost of the satellites and their launch was $166m and estimates, attributed to the Finance Department and Treasury, that the all-up cost would be $650m. I said, and again I quote:

. . . it depends on what you are taking into account. The first project is the satellite system, and the two control manuals. You add to that the cost of the eight earth stations, then if you add to that the cost of all the installations from the Department of Transport and you add to it the eight capital city earth stations I have spoken about, plus the facilities for Telecom and plus those that will be required for other public sector users, predominantly the ABC, you come to an all-up cost at the moment of about $650 million . . . Obviously if you are going to apportion the cost around all the users (you) get a different value to that which relates specifically to the satellite itself.

Attachment F of my briefing notes from the Secretary to the Department of Communications, dated 23 April 1982, which has now been provided to me by the Secretary to the Department, concerned the reconciliation of estimates of project costs for Aussat.

That paper noted the Treasury-Finance estimates. It stated that they had been derived by adding Aussat's total funding needs to 1985-an estimated $435m-and adding satellite-related spending by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, the Department of Transport and Telecom Australia. `By this means', the paper stated, `a figure of the order of $650m can be obtained'. The briefing paper and associated material pointed out the fallacies inherent in that approach by Treasury and Finance.

It was in that context, and with that upper figure in mind from the departmental briefing paper, that I answered as I did at the Press conference referred to by Mr Cocks. I did not `get it wrong', nor did I misunderstand or misinterpret the figures supplied by my Department. My answer at the Press conference referred specifically to differing methods of arriving at the all-up costs of the Aussat project as of that time, and I stand by it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker, I seek leave to make a statement to the House concerning my recent overseas trip.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the House. Between 15 and 28 April I made official visits to Washington, London, Brussels, Rome and Athens. A principal purpose of these visits was to draw attention to the contemporary crisis in agricultural markets and to secure agreement on both short and long term measures needed to deal with that crisis. Immediately prior to my departure the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) tabled the Government's statement on economic and rural policy. This is the most comprehensive and important rural policy document ever tabled by an Australian government. Despite the politically inspired efforts by some to diminish its significance, that statement is destined to remain on centre stage as far as rural policy is concerned for a long time to come. The Government has clearly indicated that the farm problem must be addressed from both the income and the costs side. Both sides were addressed in detail in the statement. In reporting to the Parliament today my focus will be on the income side, particularly in relation to international markets.

SPEECH.PARA: The crisis in world agricultural trade has been brewing for a long time. The level of consumer transfers and subsidies to European farmers has been escalating for well over a decade. In many of the world's other major producing and consuming areas, protection of agricultural producers has similarly been unchecked by any semblance of order in the international trading system. Previous rounds of Multilateral Trade Negotiations have failed to address seriously the causes of our corrupted international agricultural trading system. Those causes lie fairly and squarely in the agricultural subsidy practices of the major consuming and producing countries.

The consequence for Australian agriculture has been a persistent, insidious erosion of our position as a major non-subsidising supplier of farm products. This has occurred despite the strong comparative advantage we have in agriculture-despite the fact that our farmers are among the most efficient in the world. European farm stocks were at very high levels even before the 1980s. During the 1980s the combination of European export subsidies and American farm policies resulted in a sharp downturn in the United States of America's share of world markets and the emergence of the United States as a stock holder of unprecedented proportions.

It was against that background that the United States enacted its 1985 Farm Act. That Act is unambiguously aimed at disposing of surplus stocks on the world market at low prices and with the aid of export subsidies. Its enactment has escalated what can only be termed as a trade war between the United States and Europe. Australian farmers are caught in the crossfire of subsidy and countersubsidy as the treasuries of the United States and Europe wage an irrational battle with each other, using their own taxpayers' and consumers' money. It was because of the seriousness of this situation-for the nation as a whole as well as for the rural community-that I embarked on my trip to the United States and Europe.

My overseas visit has been aimed at two specific objectives. First, I have been drawing the attention of world leaders to the fact that the world agricultural trade war is dangerous and that it is in nobody's best interests. Second, I have been trying to win sensitivity for Australia's position as a non-subsidising supplier, to minimise the damage being wreaked upon us while the trade war continues. In the United States I met with President Reagan, Secretary of State Shultz, Agriculture Secretary Richard Lyng, and congressional leaders in both the Senate and the House of Representatives. In Britain I met with Margaret Thatcher, Agriculture Minister Jopling and Secretary for Trade Channon, along with other Ministers and senior officials. In Brussels, meetings were held with European Community President Delors, Commissioner de Clercq and Commission officials. I continued my discussions with the Prime Ministers of Italy and Greece, along with senior Ministers and public servants in those countries.

Key points that I made to all of these world leaders were as follows: First, the crisis in world agricultural trade is so serious as to warrant immediate world attention. This must be a major issue for the leaders meeting shortly at the Tokyo Summit. Second, agriculture must be accorded high priority in the forthcoming round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations, under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. There is a need for fundamental reform of the rules governing world production and trade for farm commodities. Third, there is a need for reform of the agricultural support and subsidy policies in many countries. In the EC 60 per cent of the returns from agricultural production consists of subsidies paid by consumers and taxpayers. The cost is around $70 billion per annum. The common agricultural policy is costing Europe up to one million jobs through its effect on the European manufacturing sector. The economic costs of the United States farm program have not been fully documented, but they are extraordinarily high. In many other countries income and employment is much lower than it otherwise would be because of excessive agricultural protection.

Fourth, there is an immediate need for the exercise of strong restraint in agricultural production, price support and export subsidisation. We do not have time to wait for the MTN round before beginning to restore sanity in world agricultural trade. Fifth, Australian farmers are innocent victims, losing around $1 billion per annum in world market returns as a consequence of the CAP alone, let alone the impact of the agricultural policies in other countries. Our farmers' incomes are in real terms at the second lowest level recorded, and look set to fall another 20 per cent in 1986-87. Sixth, the Australian economy as a whole is suffering from the atrocities being inflicted upon our rural community. We rely on the rural sector for almost 40 per cent of our export earnings. In contrast to Europe and the United States, we export around 80 per cent of production of our four major agricultural export commodities, that is wheat, wool, beef and sugar. We clearly cannot afford to join the irrational world agricultural trade war. Seventh, in all the circumstances there is a demonstrable need for the exercise of sensitivity in relation to Australia's position. This applies both in the administration of the United States Farm Act and in the conduct of the common agricultural policy.

I am pleased to be able to report that the broad thrust of our case has been accepted in both North America and Europe. President Reagan and President Delors, along with the leaders of Great Britain, Italy and Greece, agree that the current world agricultural regime is intolerable. In both the United States and Europe I have received support for the view that agriculture must be given a prominent position in the forthcoming Multilateral Trade Negotiations. There is also strong agreement on the need for the immediate exercise of restraint on agricultural subsidies and disposal of surplus stocks pending the outcome of the new round.

I believe that there is also a good measure of understanding of Australia's particular circumstances and of the effect that the corruption of international markets is having on our rural community and on our economy as a whole. In relation to the United States Farm Bill, I have been able to build further on the assurances given to the Minister for Trade, Mr Dawkins, during his visit in February. In particular the United States administration has assured me that:

the export enhancement program will be administered on a targeted basis, aimed essentially at markets of subsidising exporters. Recipients under the EEP will be encouraged to maintain their normal level of imports from traditional non-subsidising suppliers such as Australia;
sale of beef in association with the whole herd buyout scheme will be handled in a way which seeks to minimise disruption in Australia's export markets;
we should continue to receive access to the United States beef market at least at the levels consistent with the operation of the existing meat import law;
Australia's traditional share of the United States sugar market is being protected and our concerns in relation to the cotton and rice programs have been noted;

the consultative process covering bilateral agricultural matters will be extended to include Australia's concerns in the implementation of United States export subsidy and surplus stock disposal programs. Periodic meetings between our respective trade and primary industry Ministers will be central to that continuing process.

In Brussels I was also given some specific assurances in relation to the management of the common agricultural policy. Most importantly, however, I have been able to restore, and significantly extend, the consultative arrangements between Australia and the Community, within which these issues can be further addressed in the future. Key outcomes of my discussions with the Community were:

the Andriessen agreement, under which the Community has agreed not to subsidise sales of beef into our six major Asian-Pacific markets, that is, Japan, Korea, Taiwan, Malaysia, Singapore and Papua New Guinea, has been reaffirmed. This was most important given the request of the United States Administration under the Farm Act to dispose of 200 million pounds of beef outside the United States market.
the EC is committed to continuing to respect the minimum price provisions of the International Dairy Agreement;

there will be discussions later this year to try to find an alternative basis for dealing with the arrangement between Australia and the EC on so-called `balance sheet' beef. Certification procedures under the proposed veterinary directive relating to growth promotants will be the subject of consultation with Australia at an early date;
a new consultative framework, consisting of four components, has been agreed for future conduct of Australia-EC relations. These elements are:
high level ministerial talks covering the full range of agricultural commodity and trade issues are to be resumed at an early date;
a basis is to be established for formal liaison on respective approaches to the new MTN round during the lead-up to the new round and for its duration;
a basis is to be established for formal liaison on respective approaches to the new MTN around during the lead-up to the new round and for its duration;
an EC mission in the field of technological research and development, including agriculture, will visit Australia in May or June; and
continuing discussions will be held at an official level between our delegations in Europe and in Canberra on all trade issues between the EC and Australia.

I will not attempt to delude Australia's rural community by pretending that I have resolved the world agricultural trade crisis. It would be quite ridiculous to make any such attempt. I have not been able to change fundamentally the policies of the United States of America or the EC. Those policies will continue to corrupt markets and to depress prices for a considerable time to come. I do believe, however, that I have been able to add some impetus to the urgency with which these problems might be addressed by world leaders. I have highlighted the burgeoning costs of allowing the present absurd situation to continue.

Only time will tell whether the problems of agricultural trade are given the high profile that they deserve in Tokyo, and in the MTN round. Only time will tell whether the world's leaders, and the political processes in major producing and consuming countries, will resolutely face the intractable farm trade problem. But, whatever time reveals, there is one thing that it will show. This is that no Australian government has worked more determinedly, more comprehensively or more effectively in its efforts to have these matters properly addressed. In the meantime, I have been able to win some sensitivity to Australia's position as a non-subsidising nation. A proper reading of history will show that this mission has brought Australian farmers some respite.

We have been able to establish some guidelines within which existing policies in the United States and Europe will be administered. These guidelines provide a framework for ongoing dialogue. We have a set of benchmarks against which we can seek redress, in the inevitable circumstances where the specific actions of others interact with the cold hard commercial world to damage our interests. The recently announced subsidised wheat sale to the Yemen Arab Republic would be a case in point. While Australia can expect to maintain its 400,000 tonnes contracted sales to that market, the avenues for dialogue established during my visit to Washington will be utilised with a view to minimising further subsidised competition from the United States in the additional market that has opened up as a result of the Yemen decision to open a new flour mill.

The structure of personal relationships and the consultative mechanisms that have been established through my visits are of enduring significance. These relationships and mechanisms provide a sound foundation for further determined efforts to bring about change in the world agricultural trading system, and to restore the fortunes of our rural community. Let me make this pledge to rural Australia: The Government will do all that is humanly possible to carry on the fight for a fair go for Australian farmers in the world economy.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has had these matters uppermost in his mind during recent meetings of the International Monetary Fund and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. He has sought a firmer foundation for more widespread and stronger growth in the world economy. He has sought a proper place for agriculture on the MTN agenda. The Ministers for Trade and Primary Industry have already made frequent representations overseas on behalf of rural Australia. We are already trying to build a coalition of likeminded countries, at both a bilateral and regional level, to pursue agricultural trade reform.

Official discussions are proceeding in many countries at our initiative. This week we are participating in high level meetings with significant agricultural exporting countries in Uruguay. The Minister for Trade will be attending a meeting of Trade Ministers in Seoul in June and will go on to Canada for a meeting of wheat exporting countries. He will inaugurate a new, formalised dialogue with United States Trade Representative Yeutter soon after. The Minister for Primary Industry will visit the United States, Europe and other countries in June. The Government's approach to international agricultural trade and diplomacy has been clearly set out in the statement on economic and rural policy. As indicated in that document, we will shortly be convening a high level official group to map out a more comprehensive bilateral agricultural trade strategy.

Finally, let me say that Australian farmers continue to face serious problems. We have addressed them comprehensively in our statement. We will act upon them comprehensively in the months ahead. It is our sincere hope that the rural community as a whole, and the leaders of farm organisations in particular, will join with the Government in working constructively to seek and implement practical solutions to the problems we face. Australia's rural problems are problems shared by the nation as a whole. While the major purpose of my visit to Washington, London and other capitals, was to discuss the problems confronting Australia's trade in agricultural products, I took the opportunity, of course, to review a wide range of other matters. Let me go to those matters.
ANZUS

President Reagan and I reaffirmed the importance of the ANZUS ties between us which are fundamental to Australia's foreign and defence policies. They also have important implications for the security and stability of our region. In reaffirming the importance of our security arrangements under ANZUS, I also made clear to the United States that, notwithstanding the current difficulties between New Zealand and the United States over ANZUS, Australia intended maintaining its bilateral defence co-operation with New Zealand. The United States has already indicated that, if New Zealand proceeds to enact its proposed anti-nuclear legislation, the United States will review its security commitments to New Zealand. In my discussions with President Reagan, I reiterated Australia's firm view that, whatever may occur in the security relationship between the United States and New Zealand, the legal framework of the ANZUS Treaty should be left intact, and the security relationship between Australia and the United States reaffirmed. In the President's words: `Australia is a responsible ANZUS ally, an important trading partner and a trusted friend'.

In his departure statement at the White House on 17 April, President Reagan confirmed to me that, whatever New Zealand's decision, the United States commitment to Australia under ANZUS is firm. Further discussions on matters related to ANZUS will take place at the Australia-United States ministerial talks which are scheduled to be held in San Francisco in August.
Terrorism

In the light of recent instances of terrorism and the United States military action against Libya, it was inevitable and appropriate that I should discuss these issues with political leaders in Washington, London, Rome and Athens. I made it clear that the Australian Government unequivocally condemns terrorism. We deplore the loss of innocent lives and the poisoning of relations among States which result from terrorist outrages.

In my statement to Parliament before I left Australia, I said that the Government counselled restraint by both Libya and the United States. The Government does not accept that violence, in particular terrorism, is a solution to the complex problems of the world. Members of the House will be aware that Australia drew the attention of the United Nations Security Council to a number of possible measures open to the international community to further the possibility of a peaceful solution. To those who have criticised such action as unrealistic, I would respond that the Government takes pride in the fact that Australia sought to play a responsible and constructive role in the Security Council in the face of the prospect of an intensifying cycle of violence.

Regrettably the Security Council has so far been unable to take any positive initiative. An essential condition for progress is a genuine and binding pledge by Libya to terminate its Government's direction and export of, and support for, terrorist activity against civilians and civilian targets. Such a pledge should make possible a reciprocal commitment from the United States to refrain from recourse to armed force. The Australian Government accepts that there is a substantial body of evidence of Libyan direction of and involvement in international terrorism. While in the United States, I put it to the President and others that it would be in the best interests of all that that evidence should be made publicly available.
East-West Relations and Arms Control

My discussions in Washington also covered the prospects for progress towards effective arms control and disarmament. I confirmed Australia's support for the United States-Soviet summit process and the deep concern of the Australian Government and people that the Geneva arms control negotiations have still not achieved any significant progress towards the conclusion of agreements to reduce nuclear armaments. The United States side reassured me of their commitment to continue negotiating seriously and in good faith. At the request of President Reagan, Ambassador Paul Nitze, Special Adviser to the President on Arms Control, briefed me in Rome on the President's provisional thinking, before taking a final decision, on continued United States adherence to the SALT II agreement. Ambassador Nitze was in Rome as part of his assignment to brief the Heads of Government of European allies of the United States on President Reagan's views on these issues. My discussion with Ambassador Nitze was part of the continuing process of consultation between Australia and the United States on major arms control and disarmament questions.

Although SALT II has not been ratified, both sides have publicly undertaken to adhere to its provisions. The United States has previously made clear its concern about Soviet compliance with the SALT agreements. I advised Ambassador Nitze that the Australian Government appreciates United States concerns about Soviet compliance with aspects of the SALT II Treaty and the Anti-Ballistic Missiles Treaty and believes that the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has a case to answer. We remain of the view, however, that continued United States compliance with the SALT agreements is of great importance, especially as the United States seeks to ascertain Soviet intentions during the Summit process in the year ahead. I have since written to President Reagan in these terms.
South Pacific

In my discussions in Washington, both with the Administration and with Congress, and also in London, I outlined the objectives of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty. I explained that this Treaty represents the strongly held aspirations of the countries of the South Pacific, including Australia, to prevent the manufacture, acquisition, possession, testing and stationing of nuclear weapons in our region. I made it clear that the Government regards it as a responsible arms control measure which enhances regional security and marks a positive step forward in the international search for peace and disarmament. I also emphasised to the United States and United Kingdom governments that the Treaty fully respects rights guaranteed under international law, specifically recognises the sovereign right of parties to determine access to their ports and airfields, and is completely consistent with Australia's responsibility under ANZUS. Indeed we would not have entered into the Treaty unless this were so. I urged both governments to sign the Protocols of the Treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was their response?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, my friend opposite--
—Increasingly popular.
—He is increasingly popular.
—Looking better every day.

—My looking better every day friend. He is now blushing. Stop it, Andrew! He just interjected gently, sotto voce, in a very friendly way `and what was their response' when I urged both governments to sign the protocols. I am pleased to say to him-how do I describe him, perhaps as the shadow Foreign Minister, that is neutral-that my submissions, exposition, explanations and very logical setting out of the consideration were listened to with great attention in Washington and in London. Both governments have promised to give thoroughgoing consideration to them. I am hopeful that the brilliance and clarity of the exposition will bear fruit.
—Do you want a wager?

—I will not respond to that interjection. In addition, while in Washington, I took the opportunity to welcome the increased attention now being given by the United States Administration to the fisheries concerns of South Pacific countries.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that here comes the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard). Word does not take long to travel, does it? He came as soon as he heard on the microphone what had been said. Would he like to have a ballot? I see that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Hodgman) is now in the Leader of the Opposition's seat-old Potty, the perpetual optimist from Tasmania.
South Africa

In both Washington and London, my discussions covered the tragic situation-I hope we all agree-in South Africa where there is-I hope we all agree-an urgent need to find a peaceful means of abolishing the abhorrent apartheid system. I reiterated the Australian Government's concern that time is running out for a negotiated settlement with moderate black leaders. It was significant, I think, that the urgency of the situation was readily acknowledged by the United States Administration. I also discussed in both capitals the work of the Commonwealth Eminent Persons Group, which is seeking to encourage dialogue between the South African Government and the various racial groups with a view to the peaceful establishment of a non-racial, democratic and representative government in South Africa. In accordance with the communique issued after the last Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting in Nassau in October 1985, heads of seven Commonwealth governments, including Australia, will meet later this year to consider the report of the Eminent Persons Group. The report is due by 30 June and the Australian Government believes it is very important that the meeting take place as soon thereafter as possible.
Italy

This was my first official visit to Italy. I was delighted to confirm the strong ties of friendship between our two countries and to pay a special tribute to the contribution which the Italian community has made to Australia. I had valuable talks with Prime Minister Craxi on a range of international issues of importance to us. A very important part of my meeting with him was for us both to sign the Australia-Italy Social Security Agreement which provides comprehensive social security coverage for people moving between the two countries. People in Australia and Italy who will benefit from the agreement include those who have lost pension rights by ceasing to be Italian citizens or by leaving Australia before being granted pensions and those who have not spent sufficient time in Australia or paid sufficient contributions to the Italian scheme to qualify for payments.

In addition to our discussions about the Common Agricultural Policy of the EC, the place of agriculture in the forthcoming MTN round and our bilateral trade relations, I also took the opportunity to discuss with Mr Craxi Australia's Bicentenary celebrations. I emphasised how much we looked forward to a major involvement by Italy, pointing out that ten countries have established national bicentennial committees. I am pleased that Mr Craxi said that such a committee would be established in Italy, combining the government and private sector, to try to maximise the degree of Italian involvement in the Bicentennial celebrations. I am now hopeful that as part of Italy's participation the Amerigo Vespucci, one of the world's finest sail training ships, will be able to come to Australia in 1988.
In the course of my visit I extended an official invitation to Mr Craxi to visit Australia. I am delighted that he accepted and I hope it will not be long before the visit takes place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is he coming to Stirling?

—Yes, let him go to Stirling. There are many good Italians there. He might just visit Wills, too. I also mentioned to Mr Craxi that we would be very pleased if an Italian Minister were able to visit Australia when Italy is participating in the America's Cup, at which time we look forward to welcoming many Italian visitors to Perth. At the same time our joint working group on trade will meet for its third meeting in Perth. This will follow the second meeting due to be held in Rome next month.

SPEECH.PARA: My visit also provided the opportunity to acknowledge the splendid work undertaken by Australian Italians through the Southern Italian Earthquake Committee in rendering assistance to the areas ravaged by the Italian earthquake of 1980. Hazel had the pleasure of opening the Child Development Centre at Avellino. The construction of this Centre was funded through Australian contributions.
Call on the Pope

In Rome, I had an audience with His Holiness, Pope John Paul II. Pope John Paul indicated to me the affection he holds for Australia and the enthusiasm with which he looks forward to visiting us later this year. This was no formal indication on his part; it was very clear that His Holiness was looking forward with great eagerness and anticipation to his visit to our country. I informed him of the intense preparations being made for his visit and of the very warm welcome he will receive from the Australian Government and the Australian people.
Greece
I had the great pleasure of making my first official visit to Greece, a country whose people have also made a most important contribution to Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Andrew?

—I was looking for him. In Athens, I had the benefit of interesting and fruitful discussions with Prime Minister Papandreou and also made a courtesy call on President Sartzetakis. My visit coincided with ANZAC Day and served to remind us of the strong friendship between our countries forged in two World Wars, when Australians and Greeks fought side by side in defence of liberty and democracy.

SPEECH.PARA: Again a major focus of my discussions was the common agricultural policy of the European Communities, the need for trade in agriculture to receive a prominent place in the forthcoming multilateral Trade Negotiations and the opportunities for increased bilateral trade with Greece. In respect of bilateral trade, Mr Papandreou suggested that we examine the scope for an economic and technical co-operation agreement between our two countries, to which I responded positively and this matter will now be examined in more detail at an official level.

In addition, I mentioned the Social Security Agreement which I had just signed with Mr Craxi and indicated that I was happy to see continuing consultations with the Greek community in Australia and subsequently the initiation of work aimed at concluding a similar agreement with Greece.

I also sought the co-operation of the Greek Government in establishing a national committee linking government and private sectors to promote and plan the participation by Greece in our Bicentenary. Mr Papandreou, as had Mr Craxi, responded positively and such a committee will be established. This will be an especially welcome reflection of the very valuable role played in our development by the Greek community in Australia.

Mr Papandreou accepted my invitation to visit Australia, having previously visited us as an exile during the role of the junta. The timing of his visit, to which Australia will be looking forward enthusiastically, is now a matter of discussion between us.

My visit to both the United States and Europe has, I believe, firmly established in the minds of both the American and European political leadership the seriousness of the contemporary agricultural trading crisis and the need for effective action to deal with it. No instant remedies are available, but comprehensive longer term approaches and medium term responses have been identified. I am satisfied that I have also raised within the countries visited sensitivity to Australian interests. This heightened sensitivity should inform the administrative decisions of the major trading nations.

At the same time, I am confident that my visit has served to strengthen the friendly relations that Australia enjoys with the United States, Britain, Italy and Greece. These relations in their different ways are very important to Australia and will continue to be developed and consolidated by this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Opposition welcomes the report of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Parliament on the outcome of his visit to Washington, London and other world capitals. As the Prime Minister indicated in his address, the main purpose of his visit was to put to the United States Administration and to the European Economic Community the concerns of Australian primary producers about the impact of the trading policies of the United States and of the European Community on the welfare and interests of Australian farmers. Of course, the Prime Minister is correct to observe that the task of winding back the levels of protection and the levels of subsidisation of inefficient rural production does to Australia's rural export industries, is not an easy one. Nobody on this side of the House would pretend for a moment that with the wave of a wand or the snap of fingers it is possible for any Australian government to make serious and lasting inroads into the common agricultural policy or to bring about a significant change in the attitude of the United States Administration towards the protection of its farming community. One can only assume that fairly modest returns will result from any prime ministerial or ministerial mission overseas on matters relating to agricultural protection.

SPEECH.PARA: However, that having been said and freely acknowledged by the Opposition, it ought to be recorded that in relative terms this has not been a successful mission by the Prime Minister. The claims made by the Prime Minister, particularly in relation to the gains made on the agricultural front, simply do not stand up to serious analysis. If the trip was so important and if the impact of the United States 1985 Farm Act required action at the highest government level by the Australian Prime Minister, the reality is that the Prime Minister should have gone there six months ago to talk with members of Congress before the Farm Bill was ratified and implemented by the President. Indeed, one of the responses made by the President and the American Administration to the representations of the Prime Minister was that the final decision in these matters rested with the congressional leaders on Capitol Hill. Our complaint is that if this mission was necessary and if representation from the Prime Minister at the highest level of government was required, that representation and that action should have been taken some six months ago, before the Farm Act was passed into law.

However, the Opposition has one even more significant criticism to make of the Prime Minister's handling of the whole farm issue and the whole credibility of the Prime Minister's visit overseas. That is simply this. The Prime Minister would have gone to Washington, Europe and overseas as a representative of Australia's rural community carrying far greater weight and far greater clout if, before he had gone overseas, he had removed from the shoulders of Australian farmers the burdens of the anti-rural bias of the policies that his Party is now following.

It passes very strange for a Prime Minister of Australia to go to Washington, Brussels and other world capitals and say to the leaders of other countries: `We would like you to do for our farmers something that we, because of our policies, are unwilling to do for those same farmers'. If the rural package of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) had met the needs of Australian farmers and if, before the Prime Minister had gone overseas, he had announced the lifting of the anti-rural elements of the Keating tax package and had responded to even half of the representations of the farming community of Australia, he would have gone to Washington carrying a lot more clout and a lot more conviction and he would have been treated a lot more seriously. Let us face it, with all the verbiage, all the courtesies and all the niceties of international diplomatic exchange-even between old friends such as Australia and the United States stripped away, we have the simple proposition that really the Prime Minister's agricultural mission was not worth a row of beans. To be perfectly honest, the best demonstration of that is that virtually the day the Prime Minister arrived in the United States, the United States in effect decided to subsidise its own entry into the North Yemen wheat market. That deal has done more to undermine the credibility of what the Prime Minister has just said in this House than anything else.

TALK.START.PARA: —It made a monkey of him.

—Indeed, as my colleague the honourable member for Gwydir, the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia so rightly says, the North Yemen wheat deal has made a monkey of everything that the Prime Minister has said about his visit to Washington on the question of agriculture. So not only did the Prime Minister fail before he went to abandon the anti-rural elements of the tax package, such as the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax, but also he failed to announce a proper response by his Government to the worsening inflation situation that this country faces. While he was away his Government chalked up one more unenviable record; that is, we now have a level of inflation, expressed as a ratio of our rate of inflation compared with the average rate of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, that is the worst it has been since 1961. In other words, all of the countries the Prime Minister visited-the United States, West Germany, Japan, the United Kingdom and even Italy-are chalking up inflation rates way below what we have here in Australia. Australia is going back to a situation in which its inflation rate is more than double-indeed, it is treble-the average of many of our major trading partners. There is not a word in his speech about that. He did not get any advice from the American Administration about how to bring our inflation rate back. He did not raise that, and he did not raise it in the United Kingdom with a government whose policies he chooses to deride. He did not raise there any concern about our comparative inflation rate. So the Prime Minister, while he was away, saw a very significant additional record chalked up against his Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister quite rightly says that many atrocities are practised on Australian farmers as a result of the international trading practices of the European Economic Community and the United States. Of course atrocities are practised. Let me say to the Prime Minister that a great many atrocities are practised on Australian farmers as a result of his own policies. If the anti-rural bias of his policies were not so atrocious, some of the difficulties our farmers now face would not be so great. For example, we still do not know whether or not farm losses are subject to the Keating announcement of quarantining. We still do not know whether we are to follow the Kerin version, which says quarantining is off, or the Walsh version that says quarantining is still on, that there has been no reversal. Two weeks have now gone by and we are still completely in the dark. Nothing has been done to resolve the conflict between those two Ministers. Nothing has been done to resolve the doubt that has been cast in the minds of so many Australian farmers.

Frankly, we say again to the Government that the Prime Minister would have gone overseas with a great deal more credibility and clout if before he went he had done something to change the policies of his own Government which are doing such damage to Australian farmers. He would have been taken more seriously in Washington, in Brussels and all around the world if he had done something about those policies. To that extent it is therefore not surprising that the North Yemen wheat deal should have revealed the relative failure of the Prime Minister's mission. The failure of that trip is graphically demonstrated by the United States wheat sale to North Yemen, which was announced virtually on the day he returned from that overseas trip.

Let us examine what happened. Hard on the heels of the Prime Minister receiving assurances from President Reagan that the United States would `be as responsive to the extent we can to Australian interests' with regard to the implementation of its export enhancement program, the United States undercut an Australian tender to supply 50,000 tonnes of wheat to North Yemen-a market which, as my colleague from Gwydir will testify, traditionally takes 100 per cent of its wheat imports from Australia. The interesting point about this deal is the clear conflict of interpretation between the Minister for Primary Industry and the Australian Wheat Board. The Minister for Primary Industry has argued:
The United States subsidised wheat sale just announced will be replacing European Community flour. Australia will still be able to make its normal wheat sales in the market.

That is a quote from the Minister for Primary Industry in the Australian Financial Review of 30 April-today. Clearly the Minister for Primary Industry was trying to make excuses for the United States action in an effort to keep alive the assurances given to him by President Reagan in Washington on 18 April. The Prime Minister's office is trying to do likewise. I quote from today's Melbourne Age:
In Canberra yesterday a spokesman for Mr Hawke said the US assurances on wheat sales given to the Prime Minister during his visit to the US only included sales to existing US markets.
This meant that the US sale was not in breach of the assurances given to Mr Hawke, because North Yemen was not an existing market, but a new one, the spokesman said.

Let us have a look at the remarks made immediately after the meeting between the President and the Prime Minister, because there was certainly no such qualification contained in the formal words used by President Reagan on this issue after his meeting with the Prime Minister. The President had this to say about the trade issue in his farewell speech on 19 April 1986:

Necessary interim measures to counter unfair subsidisation, like our own export enhancement program, should take account of the interest of friends like Australia. Prime Minister Hawke has been assured of this and we will of course continue our dialogue on this important subject.

There is a stark conflict between, on the one hand, that comment and what the Wheat Board has said and, on the other hand, what the Prime Minister's spokesman and the Minister for Primary Industry are now saying. They have dragged up this business about it only applying to new markets after the event because they are totally embarrassed by the North Yemen wheat sale as it completely undercuts any claim by the Prime Minister that anything at all was derived from his discussion with the President in Washington on this whole subsidisation issue. To use the apt and pithy words of my colleague the Deputy Leader of the National Party, it really does make a complete monkey out of everything the Prime Minister has said on this issue.

To conclude my remarks on the agricultural side of the Prime Minister's mission, I have to say that in relative terms it has been, to say the least, a very undistinguished mission. It started off on the wrong foot because it was commenced with a statement on primary industry by the Minister for Primary Industry that fell far short of the expectations he had generated amongst Australian farmers. It failed to address the major needs and claims of Australian farmers, it left important issues such as the quarantining of farm losses completely clouded in doubt and mystery and it generally sounded the entirely wrong note on the departure of the Prime Minister.

I would like to allude to a number of foreign policy matters covered in the Prime Minister's speech. The Prime Minister in his discussions with President Reagan covered the ANZUS relationship. He also covered matters relating to international terrorism and in particular the recent United States response to an incessant campaign of international terrorism by the Libyan Government. It has to be said that our Prime Minister has one foreign policy when he is in this country and another when he is elsewhere. We all remember on the day of the United States military action against Libya the Prime Minister getting up in this House, with the left wing of his Party breathing down his neck-

TALK.START.PARA: —As always.

—As always on foreign policy issues. The Prime Minister is ever conscious that he can always throw the left wing of the Australian Labor Party a bone when it comes to foreign policy, because in his eyes it probably does not really matter. What did he say on that occasion? In effect, he said to the United States and Libya: `A plague on both your houses'. There was no suggestion that he agreed with the United States action. The Opposition said then, has said since and will continue to say that, regrettable though military action always is, in all of the circumstances the action taken by the United States was justified and should have received the support of the Australian Government, and it should have received the support of the Australian Government in this Parliament before the Prime Minister went overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, in the eyes of many Australians, something cowardly and unbecoming about a Prime Minister who will say overseas to suit his audience things that he does not have the courage to say in Australia because of internal political difficulties. That is the criticism that we have of the Prime Minister on this issue-that he would say one thing here and would say another thing in the United States. No doubt, now that he is back here he will go to Labor Party gatherings and say again what he said in this Parliament the day the military action took place. So we on this side of the House condemn the Prime Minister's two-faced approach to this very important foreign policy issue. It does him no credit. It does Australia's international standing no credit to have a Prime Minister who will not adopt a consistent line, who does not have the courage to face his Australian electorate with the same remarks and the same assurance as he is willing to give international audiences.

I can only say again that it is a great pity that there was a failure by many countries to respond at the beginning of this year to the initiative put forward by the United States to respond to Libyan terrorism by non-violent means, the initiative involving diplomatic and economic action, the initiative that may have rendered the events of almost a month ago unnecessary. It is a great pity that many of those countries, including many European countries, which now moralise and lecture the United States about her action against Libya and are so ready to call for sanctions and so on did not respond to the United States action in January of this year. It is a great pity that the Australian Government had not been willing in January of this year to be more responsive to the initiative put forward by the United States at that time.

In his speech the Prime Minister also touched very briefly on East-West relations and arms control issues. Whilst the Opposition has no quarrel at all with-indeed, fully endorses-any aspirations of the Prime Minister and the present Australian Government towards the achieving of an effective, verifiable arms control agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union that will lead to the dismantling of existing stockpiles of nuclear weapons and prevent the use of nuclear weapons into the future, the Opposition regrets and continues to regret the approach taken by the Australian Government towards President Reagan's strategic defence initiative. In his comments today the Prime Minister totally ignored the question of the strategic defence initiative, which is one of the most important issues involved in the whole nuclear arms debate. Once again, it is a cop-out to the left wing of his own party.

The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), who is sitting in the House at the moment, himself was to say two years ago that the motives behind the strategic defence initiative were highly moral. That was at a time when the goal of the strategic defence initiative, which is designed to give to the world a non-nuclear defensive capability against nuclear attack, was something that was seen in a more objective light. Even the Minister for Foreign Affairs was prepared to say then that the aim of the strategic defence initiative was an extremely moral purpose.

It is a great pity that the Australian Government has taken such a negative attitude to the President's strategic defence initiative. It is, after all, at the moment only a research program. Not only are we locking ourselves out of support for that program but, by the attitude we are now taking, we are denying Australian scientists the opportunity of co-operating in SDI research, and in the long run that will deny Australian industry access to the most developed technological research undertaken in the world.

The Opposition again states that it is its very firm view that the research initiative-the SDI-should be supported by the Australian Government. It has the goal of providing a non-nuclear defence capability against nuclear attacks. In those circumstances, if fully developed, it may in fact offer the only long term alternative to a maintenance of the balance of terror which has kept the world at peace for the last 40 years. It is beyond our belief and comprehension how a party which claims to be so dedicated to the idea of lasting world peace can stick its head in the sand and adopt the attitude that it does in relation to the American activity on the SDI, particularly against the background that the Soviet Union has been undertaking SDI research for a period of up to 17 years. In the discussions which the shadow Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Sinclair) and I had with the Secretary of Defence, Caspar Weinberger, several weeks ago, he spent some time explaining to us the vast superiority in strategic defence research that the Soviet Union would achieve if the entreaties of those who oppose President Reagan's initiative in this area were to be successful. So it is a disappointment. It is a wrong-headed attitude by the Government and we continue to believe that it should give an expression of support to that particular initiative.

Finally, the Prime Minister made some remarks about the South Pacific and about South Africa. As far as the South Pacific is concerned, let me say for the Opposition that the Prime Minister's comments concerning the South Pacific nuclear free zone treaty totally neglect the very central fact that the treaty does nothing now nor indeed into the future to prevent the Soviet Union locating missiles at or about the perimeter of the nuclear free area. Those who argue that in some way having a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific is going to insulate that area from any kind of nuclear incursion simply live in some kind of fantasyland or dreamworld. Of course the Opposition condemns French nuclear tests in the South Pacific. That was the policy of the Fraser Government; it was the policy of the Whitlam Government; it is the policy of the Hawke Government; and it remains the policy of the Opposition. We have no argument with the opposition expressed by the Government to French nuclear tests, but we have all the argument in the world with the naivety of a government that pretends that, if we put a circle around part of the world and we declare that as a nuclear-free zone, in some way we abolish the capacity of any country to intrude nuclear weapons or nuclear activity into that area. It is a complete fantasy concept and in those terms we are not attracted to it.

Finally, the Prime Minister made some remarks about South Africa. I say for the Opposition that we too look for the day when there will be a multi racial government in South Africa, where the denial by the white minority in South Africa of the legitimate political and social aspirations of the black majority will give way to a more liberal, a more sensitive and a more understanding regime. To that extent I can express agreement with the comments that have been made by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs about South Africa. It is well known, of course, that the Opposition does not share the views of the Government regarding the imposition of economic sanctions on South Africa. We remain of the view that to impose economic sanctions on South Africa would damage the black community in that country more than anyone else. We remain of the view that it would be a shortsighted, negative policy to impose economic sanctions.

I have to say for the Opposition that, much and all as I can understand the interest in South Africa of the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Prime Minister, if only over the last three years the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs had devoted as much time, as much energy and as much intellectual commitment to building up Australia's relations with Indonesia as they have to moralising and hectoring about the situation is southern Africa, the foreign policy goals of this country would have been more greatly served, because there is no country with which relations between it and Australia are more important than Indonesia. Our relations with Indonesia have fallen very much into disrepair under this present Government. I do not agree with the action taken by the Indonesian Government in denying entry to Bali of two Australian journalists, and I share the Prime Minister's view that it is the tradition of this country to have a free Press. It is important that the leaders of Indonesia, and indeed the leaders of many other countries, understand that we are a democracy that reveres the tradition and the principle of a free Press and that countries that wish to have a proper relationship with Australia must understand that.

I have to say in that same context that if the relationship between Australia and Indonesia had been better, if there had been more fat on the bones of that relationship, if it had not been neglected so badly as it has over the last three years by both the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister, if the Foreign Minister had not gratuitously blundered into an anti-Association of South East Asian Nations position over the Vietnamese occupation of Kampuchea, if the Foreign Minister had not gratuitously ignored the sensitivities of many of our ASEAN neighbours on those sorts of issues, then it would have been a better relationship. It would have been a deeper relationship and one that could have survived the inevitable tension created by the publication of the Jenkins article in the Sydney Morning Herald. I do not for a moment contest the right of any newspaperman to print in this country a story that he believes to be true. It will always be a cardinal principle of this Opposition that freedom of the Press is an absolute in terms of our political verities. But what has to be said and what the Government has to answer is its total failure to give an adequate priority to Australia's relationship with Indonesia over the last three years.

The Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister have been long in their lectures and sermons about what should happen in southern Africa, Kampuchea and Nicaragua, but have been strangely silent on building up our relationship with Indonesia. They have allowed the impression to be created in Indonesia that the real authoritative voice of the Australian Labor Party on our relations with Indonesia is the left wing of the Labor Party with its preoccupation about the events that occurred in East Timor almost 11 years ago. Whilst I do not for a moment condone what occurred in East Timor 11 years ago, the reality is that our relationship with Indonesia goes far beyond that. It should have been put in better repair three years ago. The Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister should have given it greater priority. They carry a lot of the blame for the present tension that now exists. It is about time they stopped expending so much energy moralising and lecturing about events in southern Africa and spent a lot more of their time and intellectual effort and energy in tending to our relationship with our nearest and most important Pacific neighbour.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the failure of the government to honour its election promises to pensioners.
In particular those promises relate to the following commitments:
1. That within three years of its election to office, a Hawke Labor Government would raise the level of the standard pension to 25% of Average Weekly Earnings;
2. That the lag time between the announcement of the Consumer Price Index figures and the subsequent adjustment of pensions would be reduced to one month, and
3. That the disproportionate tax burden borne by low income earners would be lifted.
None of these promises has been honoured to date.

Your petitioners are extremely angry at the failure of the Government to live up to its commitments and as in duty bound will ever pray that these serious omissions will be given the attention they deserve.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Brumby,Mr Lee and Mr Sharp.

PETITION.TITLE: Changes to Veterans' Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that persistent rumours suggest that the Hawke Government intends to reduce Government expenditure by contracting or eliminating programs for war veterans and war widows.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment and that of previous Governments to ex-servicemen and women by:
Ensure no additional cut-backs will be made to the portfolio of Veterans' Affairs.
Review the previous cut-backs in such areas as the travel allowances, dental scheme and repatriation pharmaceutical benefits scheme.
Proceed with abolishing more stringent conditions applying to the granting of the TPI pension.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Mr Halverson,Mr Hunt and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will:
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale,Dr Harry Edwards,Mr McArthur and Mr Shack.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Tests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; and to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that a comprehensive ban on all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time would be a vital first step towards:
inhibiting the addition of more and more sophisticated and destabilising nuclear weapons to the world's arsenals;
arresting the extension of the arms race to outer space;
upholding the provisions of existing treaties and agreements.
Your petitioners humbly pray that:

1. The Australian Government-(a) take new initiatives to encourage all member states of the United Nations-especially the governments of nuclear weapon states-to conclude at an early stage a treaty banning all nuclear weapon tests in all environments for all time; (b) call on all nuclear weapon states to declare an immediate moratorium on all nuclear weapons tests pending conclusion of a CTB.
2. All Federal members of parliament and senators make strong representations to the Australian Government to act towards these goals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Ms Jakobsen and Mr Tickner.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth that:
We are opposed to the imposition of a Capital Gains Tax.
Your petitioners humbly pray: That the Honourable House repeal any Act and reject any Bill which imposes this disincentive to economic growth.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Prescription Drugs for Pensioners
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth:
(1) That we the undersigned are totally opposed to the introduction of a $2.00 fee on prescription drugs for pensioners;
(2) That the impact of such a fee will be particularly felt by the chronically ill elderly who will be faced with a $2.00 burden with the purchase of each Pharmaceutical Benefit Scheme drug.

Your petitioners therefore urge the House of Representatives and the Government of the Commonwealth to ensure that prescription drugs continue to be provided to the pensioner population without the $2.00 fee on each prescription. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Fuel Prices
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that the Hawke Government should:
Pass on the full benefit of lower international oil prices on 1 March 1986;
not increase or extend fuel taxes; and
maintain its tax cut commitments.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Hawke Government honour its commitment to the Import Parity Pricing policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights and Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission Bills
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned showeth that there is widespread public concern about the provisions of the Bill of Rights and especially the dangerous powers to be vested in the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission, and the failure to protect vital rights such as the right to own private property.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
