(i) that the Hawke Labor Government not proceed with the Bills enacting the Bill of Rights and the Human Rights and Equal Opportunities Commission; and
(ii) that we the people be given the opportunity to express our opinion on the Bill of Rights in a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tamils in Sri Lanka
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

We the undersigned are deeply concerned that under the guise of ceasefire the Government of Sri Lanka has largely militarised Tamil regions and has now resorted to air ship attacks in highly populated areas and indiscriminate killings of civilians which is seen even by the Indian Foreign Minister as having genocidal tendencies.
Your petitioners humbly pray the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call upon the Government of Australia to intercede with the Government of Sri Lanka:
To desist from airship attacks and seeking a military solution;
to offer refuge under humanitarian and compassionate programs, to Tamils who are fleeing from the violence;
abandon all direct and indirect forms of repatriation to any Tamil who has sought refuge in Australia and grant them meaningful assistance to resettle;
as a member of the Commonwealth, persuade the Government of Sri Lanka to pursue a political solution which will allow the Tamils to live in peace and dignity.
Your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned are deeply concerned that any proposal by the Government to adopt a flat rate family allowance scheme would cause considerable hardship to low income families.

Your petitioners therefore humbly request that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to give due consideration to the effects of such a proposal on Australian families.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Warships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Parliament and to the Australian Government.
This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
Foreign warships visiting Australian ports give acceptability to the increasing militarization of the Indian and Pacific Oceans;
W.A. endures a visit of a foreign warship on average every 1.5 weeks;
a situation of de facto `home-porting' facilities exists in W.A.;
there is increasing citizen concern that nuclear armed/nuclear powered warships put Australian ports and people at risk in many ways.
Your petitioners humbly pray that: The Australian Government refuse entry to Australian ports to all foreign warships.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Medicare Office, Wyong, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws the attention of the House to the fact that the lack of a Medicare Office in Wyong is seriously inconveniencing the residents of Wyong Shire.
Your petitioners therefore request that a Medicare Office is established in Wyong as soon as possible.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully shows:

That the recent failure of the Federal Parliament to disallow the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Publications Ordinance will contribute further to the erosion of moral standards in Australia. In particular, the legislation increases the danger of the moral well-being of our children, by removing controls, at the point of production and importation of pornographic material.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Capital Territory Classification of Public Ordinance of 1983 be repealed.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Honourable Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia sheweth whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.

Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Give a speedy passage to the Flags Act Amendment Bill which provides that the Australian National Flag can only be changed by a referendum.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Horticultural Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned, are deeply concerned that Australia's important horticultural industry is being severely disadvantaged by unnecessarily rising production costs.

Many Federal and State Government regulations, excessive taxes and charges are damaging the ability of horticultural growers to maintain supplies of food and plant products to Australian families at a realistic cost. Widespread unemployment will result if horticultural producers are further depressed.

The undersigned humbly petition the Parliaments of Australia, its States and Territories, to take all measures within their powers to reduce the burden of imposed costs and regulation, allowing Australian horticultural growers to develop production potential so the nation, as a whole, can share the benefits of the resulting growth and prosperity.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:

That in the light of the Labor Government's proposal to bring about a reduction in the amount payable under the present Family Allowance Scheme, that the House of Representatives assembled oppose such a move, on the evidence of its impact upon the family unit.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should immediately seek to restore payments to the former level.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Price Control
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and member of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth.

Our alarm with the continued spiralling cost of commodities. Brought about we believe, by the monopolisation of retail outlets by multi and transnational consortiums. We would ask the Government to legislate for, effective price control and anti monopoly measures to prevent erosion of the living standards of the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, seek your most urgent action to rectify this deep concern to the community.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain residents of the State of New South Wales draws to the attention of the House the Report of the Ministerial Committee to Review the Structure of Higher Education in Western Sydney which recommends the establishment in 1987 of a Western Sydney State University along lines detailed in that report.

Your petitioners therefore request that the Commonwealth Government acts promptly to rectify the serious deficiencies in Higher Education in the Western Sydney Region by taking all actions necessary to enable the New South Wales Government to establish the University.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Western Sydney State University
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:

That they strongly support the establishment of the western Sydney State University as recommended in the parry report and call upon the House to establish the Western Sydney State University in conjunction with the New South Wales Government.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of New South Wales respectfully showeth:
That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Establishment at Lucas Heights in New South Wales.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional reactor at Lucas Heights or within Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Sutherland Shire and New South Wales respectfully showeth: That they oppose the construction of any additional nuclear reactor at the Australian Atomic Energy Establishment at Lucas Heights in N.S.W.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government of Australia will not construct an additional Nuclear Reactor at Lucas Heights.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The petition of certain electors of Dawson shows that the proposed Bill of Rights
overlooks basic rights concerning union membership, education, and private property,
is a basis for massive intrusion into State responsibilities,
establishes a Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission with powers similar to a Court but without accepted legal procedures and protections for the accused, and
provides no avenue of appeal against decisions of the HR&EOC.

The petition further shows that fundamental protection of human rights is already to be found in the Courts, in tolerance, in fair play, belief in democratic institutions, and in support for rule of law.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Parliament will not allow the Australian Bill of Rights Bill to pass into law.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Capital Gains
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Mallee electorate respectfully showeth:
That all legitimate business expenses incurred in earning or producing assessable income should be allowable deductions.
That the proposed Capital Gains Tax is an unwarranted burden on the rural sector, which will severely affect its long term viability.
That the delay by the Government in introducing the legislation into Parliament is causing confusion and hindering farmers in the organisation of their affairs.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government introduces the Capital Gains Tax legislation without delay and that the Australian Democrats join with the Opposition to defeat the proposed legislation.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Page electorate respectfully showeth that:

The Hawke Labor government's productivity- superannuation accord with the ACTU and its support of the superannuation claims of the trade union movement will create an imbalance in industrial power and distort the future development of the Australian economy.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Reject the superannuation claim of the trade union movement, and allow superannuation to develop without trade union domination.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Home Loan Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the current policy pursued by the Hawke Government is causing an intolerable increase in home loan interest rates beyond the capacity of families to pay.
that consequently this policy is causing grave hardship throughout Australia and is contributing to social problems and the breakup of the family unit.
that unless the Government act urgently the Australian dream of home ownership is fast becoming shattered for many of our citizens.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray: That the Government make home loan interest rates tax deductible therefore alleviating the present crippling burden of current high interest rates on home owners and home buyers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions: Assets Test
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the Hawke Socialist Government be called upon to remove the unjust and cruel Assets Test;
That the Assets Test discriminates grossly against those people living on acreage blocks or in rural areas;
That the introduction of the Government's grab for the assets of senior citizens is condemned as un-Australian;
That the Government is requested to reconsider the Assets Test.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens of the Federal Division of Fisher in Queensland respectfully showeth:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. They are certain that any change to the Flag will produce divisions in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will: Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag remains sacrosanct from change''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Ayers Rock
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Queensland respectfully showeth:

Whereas the present Government of the Commonwealth of Australia has purported to present the Title Deeds to Ayers Rock in Central Australia, in reality the joint property of the people of the Commonwealth to an Aboriginal Land Council on 26 October 1985,

Whereas opinion polls and statements of representative groups, Members of Parliament and respected individuals show clearly that the Commonwealth Government had no mandate from the citizens of the Commonwealth to act in such a disgraceful manner,

Whereas the present Government claims to be totally opposed to apartheid (separate development) in South Africa but purported to hand over Ayers Rock to an Aboriginal Council in support of a policy of apartheid (separate development) which has been shown to be detrimental to the Aboriginal people of Australia,

Whereas it is pursuing this policy making it a crime for most whites and many Aboriginals to enter, without permit, large areas of the Commonwealth designated apartheid (i.e., set aside for separate development), contrary to our democratic traditions and experience of freedom of movement for citizens of all racial origins within Australia,
Whereas Australian citizens have no present means available to them to prevent this violation of their natural rights to unfettered common ownership of, and access to, a treasured natural asset.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Seek means available for the protection of the people's interests to reverse this outrage and preserve the democratic traditions of Australia,
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Bill of Rights Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth that:
The Hawke Labor Government's Bill of Rights seeks to make changes in the constitutional balance in Australia by intruding into the affairs of individuals and of State and Local Governments.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to: Repeal the Bill of Rights legislation and not restrict the individual freedoms of Australians and the present justice system in this country or in any underhand way centralise power in our three tier system of Government.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The continuing uncertainty over the Government's tax package, its damage to the whole Australian community and its failure to provide tax relief to low and middle income families.

Madam Speaker also received another letter. However, she has chosen the proposal put forward by the honourable member for Mackellar. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose the first question Opposition members will ask in beginning this matter of public importance is: Where is the Treasurer (Mr Keating)? Will the Treasurer be present to answer the case against the package, or does he intend to follow the practice he followed yesterday when the shadow Minister for finance and taxation, Senator Messner, went to the Treasurer's office and asked for a briefing from departmental officers on the proposals on negative gearing taxation and the Treasurer failed to agree to that briefing being given? The Treasurer has now walked into the House, but since Senator Messner wrote to the Treasurer expressing his concern about the Treasurer's decision not to give him a briefing on negative gearing, I hope that in the meantime he will have altered his decision.
—I haven't, no.
—The Treasurer says that he has not altered his decision.
—You will get a briefing when you get to government next.

—The Treasurer has just said that we will not get a briefing on the legislation that is coming before the House from the Department until we get into government. The Treasurer cannot get away with this sort of arrogance. If the Opposition spokesman on a particular matter asks for a departmental briefing on a Bill, the Minister is obliged to arrange for it as an elementary matter of courtesy. He can instruct the Department as to the limits of that briefing. But for him to come into the House and say that he will not arrange for departmental officers to be available for a briefing on negative gearing on essential tax matters is outrageous. He will not be allowed to get away with it. We will ask for a briefing on all these matters, we will expect it, and will keep taking it up until we get it.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason we are raising this matter this afternoon is that the tax package introduced by the Treasurer on 19 September last year is a total shambles. Not only has it not been introduced, as to most of it, in the form of legislation but a great deal of it has been changed, a great deal is subject to questioning, and a great deal is totally uncertain. Taxpayers throughout Australia do not know what their tax liabilities are. Not only that, but at the very heart of the proposals there is a fraud on the ordinary low income and middle income earning Australians as to the tax benefits in that package. Of course, what happened in the history of this matter is that we had a taxation summit in July in this very chamber. We had discussions between a whole lot of industry and community representatives and the Government. Numerous submissions were put forward and indeed in his statement of 19 September the Treasurer made these rather grandiloquent remarks. I quote from the Treasurer's statement of 19 September 1985, as follows:

For the first time in Australia's recent history a government has been willing to place tax reform on the political agenda. But much more than that, for the first time a government has been willing to act. We have invited debate, we have asked the people of Australia to express their views, and we have listened carefully to what they have said. The tax reform measures I am announcing today are the outcome of that unprecedented process of consultation.

In fact, they were really the illegitimate offspring of a meeting between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the ACTU in a motel in Canberra. After all the discussions had been held, after all the payments had been put forward and after the Treasurer and the Prime Minister had stamped the whole country trying to sell what they thought was a reasonable package-much of which was supported by the Opposition-they came in here and conducted a sham of a tax summit. The Prime Minister went off to a motel room and the ACTU told him what he could do. The Prime Minister then came back and told the Treasurer what the Treasurer could do. The Prime Minister cut the ground totally from the promises the Treasurer had made to reduce marginal rates of taxation substantially for low and middle income earning Australians.

This afternoon I will be dealing with the effect of this tax package as it now stands on ordinary taxpayers-not farmers and not small businesses. My colleague the honourable member for Forde (Dr Watson) will be telling us about the effect that it is having on business investment and the creation of jobs in Australia. He will be telling us about that. Firstly, let me look at the effect on families. What does the package mean for the ordinary Australian taxpayer and for Aust- ralian families? Having examined the figures in great detail-and we have now had plenty of time to look at them-we find that lower and middle income earners have been cheated by this package; they have been totally cheated. In his statement of 19 September last, the Treasurer said:

What I have announced today are far reaching, genuine and substantial tax reforms. They achieve the fundamental objectives we set ourselves at the outset of this ambitious endeavour, namely, to significantly reduce marginal tax rates.

That was the first objective that the Treasurer set himself, and it is the first objective that he claimed that he had achieved in his statement to the House. Let us look at the reality of that claim. Let us look at what has happened to lower and middle income earners. We conclude that after we allow for wages and inflation moving up over the period between the announcement of 19 September last and July 1987, when the package is fully implemented, all these taxpayers will be actually paying more tax. Let me quote some precise examples. A taxpayer on an income of $15,000 per annum, at the time the statement was made, that is, earning $290 a week, will, after the effects of inflation and wage increases-after the normal wage increases through the conciliation and arbitration system have been taken into account-be paying $10.06 more per week in taxation as a result of these measures. A taxpayer on $20,000 a year, that is, $385 a week, will be paying $20.29 a week more in tax as a result of this so called tax reform.

If we take a person at average weekly earnings of $404.50 as at the time of the statement last September, he will be paying under the current rates a top marginal rate of tax of 46 per cent, and I exclude the extra one per cent Medicare tax. Let us take the 46 per cent basic rate which is the top rate being currently paid. An average tax rate over the whole income is 22.73 per cent. The Treasurer tells these taxpayers that their top marginal rate will come down from 46c in the dollar to 40c in the dollar. That is what they were told on the night of the statement, and that is what they believed, and they thought they were doing well. When one looks behind that piece of flummery, one finds that their average tax rate will in fact go up from 22.73 per cent of their income to 24.49 per cent of their income. That is taking into account the effect of inflation on the taxation scales. Those people have been duped. The Treasurer came in and said: `We are dropping your marginal tax rate from 46c to 40c'. What the Treasurer did not say to them is: `We are putting up your average rate of tax from 22.73 per cent to 24.48 per cent'. There has been in this tax package a major marginal rate fiddle.

Over the two years between the time the package was introduced and the time it is actually implemented he tells us that the marginal rates will come down from 25c to 24c in the dollar, from 30c to 29c in the dollar and from 46c to 40c in the dollar. Everyone listening to the statement would have believed that that would have been helpful for them. However, the catch of course is that over that two-year period and by 1988 the effects of inflation, of rising prices and wages going up and no particular gain in real terms to wage earners-that is assuming they do not get any increases over and above the ordinary inflation and indexing-about two million taxpayers will have moved from a 29 per cent top rate to a 40 per cent top rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many?

—I said `two million taxpayers'. Of course, it looks good if one says that the top marginal rate is reduced from 46c to 40c and that the 30c rate is reduced to 29c. It sounds good, but when one realises that over the course of the two years, because of inflation, two million taxpayers will move from a 29 per cent top rate to a 40 per cent top rate, one realises that the whole thing is a massive swindle. Indeed, by the date of full introduction, in 1987, 50 per cent of all taxpayers will have moved into the 40c in the dollar top bracket; 50 per cent will be at the 40c in the dollar tax bracket, and a further 4 per cent each year will move into the 40c in the dollar rate purely because of the effects of inflation.
—What inflation rate?

—I might say, and certainly the honourable member for Deakin reminds me of this, that all these figures are based on earlier inflation estimates. We found last week that inflation in Australia had gone up to over 9 per cent: It is now 9.2 per cent. It is about two and a half times that of the average for our trading partners. We do not know what will happen to our inflation rate over the rest of the year. If we keep going at a rate two and a half or three times the rate of our trading partners, these figures will look worse by the time the tax package is introduced. This has been a massive confidence trick. It has been an illusion. It disguises the defeat of the Government at the hands of the ACTU, but it is wholly typical of the presentation of this Government. It is all surface. It is like the Priority One scheme: It is all advertising, it is spending up big, spending on advertising, and spending on the Prime Minister in front of a television camera; but it is actually heating the ordinary low income and middle income earners of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I can add to that, by taking the effect of petrol prices. The rest of the world has had the benefit of a fall in world oil prices passed on to them. A motorist in the United States or Japan can be certain that the effects of the fall in world oil prices will flow on to him at the bowser. However, in Australia the Treasurer-the bowser bandit-has been pinching most of that drop in extra tax. A low income earner on, say, $310 per week and running a car who is promised a tax cut of $4.60 in the Treasurer's statement-and mind you that is a fraudulent promise because it is $4.60 without taking inflation into account and in fact that person would lose about $12 a week-if he uses 45 litres of petrol a week will be paying an extra $3.90 a week in tax. The Treasurer says people like that gain $4.60 whereas in reality they lose $12, and the Treasurer is ripping off them an extra $3.90 a week in additional petrol excise. Of course, that hits the lowest income earners in the community.

So much for income tax. On top of that, we have the fringe benefits tax which has already caused massive falls in sales of motor cars. On the best industry advice, 10,000 jobs will be lost in that industry alone because of the fringe benefits tax. In addition, whereas the Treasurer said in the statement on 19 September that religious, charitable and non-profit bodies would be excluded from paying this tax, he has failed to give any assurance subsequently to those people that they will be excluded. This means that charitable bodies which have to collect money for their services will have to pay the full fringe benefits tax, as far as we know-unless he makes another statement. Schools which have to provide accommodation for teachers will have to pay the tax. Charities which look after welfare cases and so need to have motor vehicles will have to pay the tax. This is absolutely ludicrous. We will move an amendment in the Senate to try to have that changed.

With regard to people in the bush and in the mining industry, it is absurd that this tax will impose an extra payroll tax, in effect, on farmers and miners-in the coal industry alone it will cost about $40m-for the provision of housing in remote areas, the use of farm vehicles and all of those sorts of things that are an inevitable part of running a mine or a farm. Given the parlous position of our mines and farms in the present trading environment, it is absurd to impose this additional virtual payroll tax on those employers. Yet that is what the Government intends to do. It will kick them where it hurts at a time when they can least take it.

Also, of course, there is the negative gearing on rental properties which is drying up the rental market. There is the quarantining of farm losses which has been reversed. But has it been reversed? The Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) says that it has not. The Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) says that it has. The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hurford), as Acting Treasurer, said that it had. Senator Walsh said that the numbers were wrong and that it had not been reversed. Wherever we look in this package-the honourable member for Forde will say more about this-there is confusion, uncertainty, disincentive and downright fraud in regard to ordinary taxpayers at the lower and middle income levels. The Treasurer has a lot of explaining to do and we will be very interested to see how he can explain it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) would not entrust the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) with taxation. He buried it in the Senate with Senator Messner. The fact is that I had to be bored stiff for a quarter of an hour by this pedestrian performance about uncertainty and damage. What uncertainty? We have had the longest tax debate in Australia's history. What is more, we have had a public debate, a government statement and most of the legislation already presented, yet the Opposition talks about uncertainty. If it expects to get any marks for credibility from me, it will get none. Honourable members opposite talk about damage. Do they actually talk about damage to the tax system after the national scandal, the rotten mess in taxation, with which they left this nation? There were five years of tax scandals. The previous Government not only did not reform the system but left it in stinking repair, with all the fraudulent paper evasion-not avoidance, but evasion-schemes left untouched before it was dragged screaming to the table in the House of Representatives by the Costigan and McCabe-Lafranchi reports. Yet the Opposition talks about damage. Does it expect me to say that I have explaining to do? Honourable members opposite must be cracking jokes.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, they ran the tax administration into the ground. They gave the Commissioner of Taxation no people with whom to work. We have implemented a massive recruitment program in the Australian Taxation Office to try to cope with the job of managing it because the previous Government supposedly put some ceiling on the Public Service. But the signal given to the Tax Commissioner was: `Lay off all the rants and rorts. Don't touch the paper schemes'. Do honourable members opposite remember Mr Commissioner O'Reilly's telephone book of letters to Mr Howard imploring him over about five years to do something about the rotten paper evasion schemes? Do honourable members opposite remember all of that? That occurred in 1982, for the benefit of those who were here then. This Government has put down the biggest reform package ever. Yet the Opposition talks about credibility, uncertainty and damage!

Does the Opposition remember its broken promise? Does it remember its promise in 1977 to index the tax scales? In 1977 Malcolm Fraser said that there would be full tax indexation. Do Opposition members remember the television advertisements which stated: `Ring up the Liberal Party headquarters and find out how much your tax cut is'? Do they remember those television advertisements? Do they remember when they took them away the following May, five months later? Do they remember that? The Liberal Party has a hide as thick as an elephant's. It will say and do anything. It says: `Don't look at what we did. Don't examine what we didn't do. Don't do as we did, just do as we say'. It not only did not reform the tax system but it did nothing about general running repairs, the kind of necessary repairs which need to be done all the time to close loopholes. That is what this Government has done in regard to superannuation lump sums, income splitting, abuse of unit trusts, leverage leasing, the prescribed payments system, sales tax avoidance schemes and all the others which, since 1983, total about $2 billion to $3 billion in terms of savings to the revenue in trying to make the system spin around. Those opposite did not do any of the running repairs as the need came about.

The Opposition sat and watched the tax system being ripped apart so that tax in this country was made optional. It left a high marginal tax over a narrow income range which encouraged everyone either to split their income or to avoid it. It then provided all of the mechanisms for everyone to slide down their tax obligations, except the poor person on a pay as you earn income who never had any of the options of getting out of paying tax, who never had any of the options of diminishing his tax. It left all the rorts in the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a pathetic performance.

—The honourable member can leave if he likes. He never liked the truth. The Opposition left all the rorts in the system. It thought that everyone would ignore the system forever. In the end the system broke down. This Government has had to deal with it as best it could. It has dealt with it by introducing, after a long debate, the most far-reaching and comprehensive reforms in the history of the system.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very interesting to hear the Opposition now whinging about the fringe benefits tax, the motor vehicles tax, negative gearing and remote area housing. I refer particularly to things such as negative gearing and motor cars. The Opposition operated by always leaving an out for the high income people who it thought supported it. It always left it in there. All the other mugs could pay their tax but the smarties-the mob it represents-could always sneak out under a bit of negative gearing, or they could have their Rolls-Royces, Jaguars, Mercedes Benzes, or Holden Commodores with all the options. They could write it all down-

TALK.START.PARA: —And Ferraris.

—And Ferraris, yes. They could write it all down. In terms of fringe benefits, the Opposition did not mind that the middle ranking executives had their children's education paid or that they walked around the tax system in some other way by claiming hostess allowances, or whatever it might be, because these allowances were all for the Opposition's people. It was only the ordinary poor fellow who had to pay his way. Of course, now we are knocking out the ingrained rorts-
—You would not be leasing a Ferrari, would you, Paul?
—Order! The honourable member will remain silent.
—The honourable member keeps yelling about Ferraris. Does he have a Ferrari?
—No, but you leased one.
—Like hell I did. I have never had one in my life.
—You are a ferret in a Ferrari.

—Let us not deal with this clown opposite. Let me make this point. All of these rutted-in things were things which politically could not be touched. The political thing was that the Opposition could knock off some paper scheme but it could not touch motor cars, negative gearing or all of the other rorts in the system because it said: `They are there for our people. They are on the side'. The fact is that we have done that, and honourable members opposite squeal like stuck pigs about it.

SPEECH.PARA: I walked in to the amazing situation of having the honourable member for Mackellar demanding of us that we provide tax officials to talk to him about negative gearing when he has said that he will oppose the measure. I am expected to drag somebody off the tax reform package to come over here to explain to his Party what the measure is about when his Party has said that it will oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you still have to provide a briefing.
—I do not have to provide the honourable member with anything. He will get what I give him, and that is that.
—You do not understand the parliamentary system. You are totally contemptuous of it.

—Oh, no! I have been here since 1969. Does the honourable member know how many briefings I got from his lot? I got none-N-O-N-E. The honourable member has received far more from me than I received from the previous Government. He has received them whenever he has asked for them reasonably to shed light on something. But if he thinks that he can tell us that he will oppose something and demand briefings of us which would require ripping people away from working on tax reform, he has to be joking.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition members should not talk to us about taxation; for God's sake, they can talk about any subject but taxation. On taxation they have the backside out of their pants. The Liberal Party was prepared to run the tax system into the ground. It was not prepared to fund the Australian Taxation Office and to staff it. It was not prepared to move against the blatant tax evasion schemes which had been operated by all the smart solicitors and accountants. It was not even prepared to do running repairs to the normal avoidance schemes and loopholes that appeared from time to time. Not only that; it was not prepared to look in any serious way at tax reform.

The honourable member for Mackellar talked about uncertainty and damage. Does he think there is any damage from a full imputation system for the business community in this country. This is the second country in the world after West Germany to provide full imputation for business; that is, no double taxation on dividends. The Germans provide for a corporate rate of 56 per cent. We provide for a corporate rate of 49 per cent. In other words, this is a world first. Does the honourable member for Mackellar think there is any damage in reducing the crazy marginal rates from the 60 per cent that his Government bequeathed us to 49 per cent, or from 46 per cent to 40 per cent, from 30 per cent to 29 per cent, or from 30 per cent to 25 per cent? Is that damage? Does the honourable member really expect to state such things and be listened to?

TALK.START.PARA: —The average rates are going up for low income earners.
—Listen, my friend, you have a long way to go if you think you can come into this House--
—Order! I remind the Treasurer that he should address the Chair and not address other persons in the second person.

—But he interjected, Mr Deputy Speaker. The fact is that the coalition has a long way to go when it comes in here trying to put over this sort of tripe. Most of the taxation Bills have been introduced; the balance will be introduced before this session is over. This is a massive and major tax reform exercise. The whole bureaucracy is flat out trying to cope with the enormity and complexity of the task. We will bring in as much legislation as possible as soon as possible. It is a revenue neutral operation and it will complete the tax reforms that will, of course, impact on marginal rates in September and on 1 July 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, interestingly, what we get in terms of credibility from the Liberal Party is that it says that it will not oppose the tax cuts but that it will oppose all of the measures to pay for those tax cuts. In other words, it will let the Budget bleed by about $1 billion by giving the tax cuts, but it will not support any of the measures to pay for the tax cuts. That has been said repeatedly.
There is not much more to be said about it than that. I have a meeting to go to and, frankly, that is more important than answering this tripe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Dr D.J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the statements by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), it is perhaps appropriate that I start off with an antique quotation. I think it was Dickens in A Tale of Two Cities who began his novel with the words:

SPEECH.PARA: It was the best of times; it was the worst of times.

Of course, he was talking about London and Paris at the time and was weaving a story about the lives of people, some with despair and some with hope. But perhaps today it is appropriate to reconsider those words: `It was the best of times; it was the worst of times'. When one compares Australia with the rest of the world, one can see the best of times in the rest of the world. Many countries are taking off today with high rates of growth, low inflation and a very secure future. One compares them with Australia and wonders whether we are getting the second half of those lines.

Recently I was reminded by a Japanese banker that, if one looks at the world economy in terms of a Boeing 747, one sees in the first class area countries such as the United States of America, Switzerland, West Germany and Japan. But where is Australia? Australia is back in economy class. It is no wonder that we are back there as this Treasurer has probably missed the plane altogether. Australia is back there when one considers items such as the dollar. Under this Government over the past 2 1/2 years we have seen the dollar fall not only against the United States dollar but against every other major currency in the world. We have the highest interest rates in the Western world, at least compared with those of our major competitors. We have the highest inflation rate in terms of consumer prices and probably even worse in terms of wholesale prices. That is reflected in the latest edition of the Economist, which shows that Australia has had a positive wholesale price index increase whereas many other countries, such as Japan, the United States and West Germany, have had negative price changes over the last 12 months in the wholesale index. This does not augur well for Australia's future.

At a time when Australia is facing these problems, we have a Government that cannot lead. We have a Government that cannot make decisions. We have a Treasurer who wants to run away rather than to face up to any questioning from the Opposition's shadow spokesman, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). It was well caught by Paul Kelly in his recent article in the Australian in which he indicated that one senior Minister had told him: `If it's an issue like what economic direction we should be taking, it is too hot for Cabinet to debate'. It is scarcely an exaggeration to say that the Hawke Cabinet is immobilised, watching its Treasurer's stunning juggling performance taking place at the edge of the economic precipice. Nowhere is this lack of leadership more obvious than in the taxation area.

At a time when the terms of trade are going against Australia, at a time when the balance of payments is going against Australia, at a time when the Treasurer is just hoping that that J curve will take off-he is almost sitting there imploring it to pull around-one would expect there to be a taxation policy in place which would encourage private investment in Australia. But, no, it is not in place. All that is being done is compounding the problem of private investment. Ever since this Government has been in place, private investment in Australia has been falling-from the highs of 12 and 13 per cent of a few years ago down to about 9 per cent of our gross domestic product today.

Investment is falling and it is no wonder. Investment is based upon expectations. An uncertain taxation system simply undermines those expectations. By looking at the legislative program that should be facing us, we can see why those expectations are being undermined. The changes affecting negative gearing were announced on 17 July 1985 to take effect from 18 July 1985; we still have not seen them. The measure relating to depreciation of residential buildings was also announced on 17 July, to take effect from 18 July 1985; but we still have not seen it. A capital gains tax was announced on 19 September 1985 to take effect on 20 September 1985; but we still have not seen it. Measures relating to non-cash fringe benefits were announced on 19 September 1985 to take effect from 1 July 1986; we still have not seen them. The same can be said of improved averaging provisions, quarterly provisional taxation, the foreign tax credit system and the imputation system for company tax. Then there is the quarantining of farm losses. What a great saga that has been. It was announced on 19 September 1985 to take effect on 1 July 1986. It was pulled out by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) on 15 April 1986 and reinstated the following day by the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh).

This Government tries to tax by proclamation, modified, of course, later by Press releases and statements from the Treasurer which unfortunately lack the finer detail required for taxation and investment planning. Business is being confused by the ad hoc manner in which reform is being undertaken. There exists, of course, already a high degree of uncertainty in Australian business, brought about by the economic policies which this Government has implemented. But taxation vagueness, which is the hallmark of this Treasurer-not taxation reform but taxation vagueness-is exacerbating the difficulty of making business decisions. We do not have to go very far to find them. For example, the real estate industry is reeling from negative gearing and capital gains taxation.

The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), as shadow Minister for housing, has repeatedly brought to the Government's attention the problem of falling loans in the savings bank and permanent building society area. Loans have fallen by between 33 per cent and 34 per cent this year. We have noticed that housing starts have fallen drastically this year. We know that rents are rising throughout Australia. In my area they have risen by something like 13 per cent in the last year. In Sydney and in other places they have risen by as much as 20 per cent. We have seen those rents rising, outstripping our already extremely high inflation rate. No wonder investor buyers are disappearing from the industry. No wonder owners are frightened to sell because of potential future capital gains on new investments. No wonder owners of negatively-geared property, which is clear of this tax, are frightened to re-finance their investments for fear of being caught in some potential, unknown refinements of the tax system which may or may not be disclosed in some future, unknown Press release.

It is absolutely impossible for business to enter into tax planning arrangements. We see even today in the Australian Financial Review and in other papers that the fringe benefits tax is blamed. It is certainly at fault in terms of current car registrations. Car registration is down by some 25 per cent to 33 per cent over a year ago. It is no wonder. I ask why is that? People do not know what the effect will be. No one has seen the legislation. If one introduces this kind of uncertainty into business decisions one will simply have investment fall off. I do not know whether these delays are deliberate. I do not know whether these delays simply reflect incompetence on the part of the Treasurer and this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely.
—I suspect that it does. After all, the Treasurer cannot even stay in the chamber and face any criticism.
—He has fled from the chamber.
—The Treasurer has fled from the chamber, as the honourable member for Fisher has said.
—He didn't finish speaking.

—He didn't finish speaking. He cannot answer anything. I think sometimes the government believes-the Treasurer spoke of this-that lawful business tax planning is tax avoidance. After all, this Treasurer has made an art form of confusing the population, of trying to suggest that legitimate tax planning is some kind of tax evasion. He did it when he was in Opposition and he has done it even more so since he has been the Treasurer. I suspect that he probably thinks that, if there is not any legislation, there cannot be any loopholes. I suspect that he really is quite incapable of understanding the full impact of any legislation that he brings into this House.

SPEECH.PARA: This Treasurer is actually maximising the uncertainty inherent in business and taxation planning. This Treasurer is actually destroying business confidence. This Treasurer, the Government, and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) are destroying the incentive and the initiative that should be existing in Australian business. This Treasurer is actually undermining and destroying future investment in Australia and, whether he likes it or not, his attitude, his policies and the uncertainty that he is introducing are simply undermining Australia's future. He ought to be in this chamber to answer that accusation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fatin Ms W.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from the Opposition a testament to the double standards it practised while it was in government and the hypocrisy it has brought to its whole period in opposition. The thing that appals me most of all is the low estimation that members opposite have of the intelligence of the Australian electorate. Hour after hour we have to sit in this chamber and listen while members of the Opposition repeat their half-baked ideas about issues that they really know nothing about. All the time we know, and the Australian people know, that the Opposition all but destroyed this country while it was in government. How dare honourable members opposite come into this chamber and talk about the Hawke Government creating uncertainty. How can they have the gall to talk about this Government damaging the community or failing to provide assistance for low and middle income families? All I can say is that, if the Opposition wants to talk about tax, we on this side of the House are very happy to do so. We will discuss tax any time of the day or night just as we will talk about jobs, industrial relations, or any other matters in which this Government has shown the Opposition how to implement successful policies. Because, of course, in all these areas, this Government has the runs on the board. This Government picked up the mess, the chaos left behind after Fraser and Howard had had their turn.
—Order! The honourable member for Brand will refer to honourable members by the electorate or the position they occupy.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is very tempting to go into some of the details of the frightful legacy bequeathed to us by Mr Howard and Mr Fraser. But the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton), has chosen tax as today's subject and I and my colleagues on this side of the House are more than pleased to concentrate on this aspect of our Government's policy. It is not really surprising that the Opposition never shows the same willingness to focus attention on its taxation policy. At the moment, of course, it is understandable that it is unwilling to have its taxation proposals subjected to any kind of scrutiny. There is a very good reason for this. It is simply, as we all know, that it does not have a policy on taxation. This in itself, of course, brings a certain consistency and uniformity to Opposition policy-making. Members of the Opposition do not actually have a policy on anything, although they are certainly quite well advanced in knowing how they will market a policy if one ever comes to hand.

SPEECH.PARA: What about the Opposition's record in the past? Are there clues to be gained from the way in which a Liberal-National Party government approached taxation? Certainly there are. The people of Australia read these clues. They watched the way in which Mr Fraser's failed Treasurer ducked and wove his way through the holes in the taxation system. They watched and they threw him out. (Quorum formed) The Opposition has accused the Government of creating uncertainty with its tax package. One thing can be said with certainty: There was never any uncertainty about the way the Liberal-National Party handled taxation matters.

During the late 1970s and early 1980s the integrity of the Australian taxation system was all but destroyed. It became a standard joke to talk about how little tax one was able to pay and how one could get away with it. Tax avoidance was elevated to the level of a national sport. Why reform the system when it was operating so nicely in favour of one's political colleagues and supporters? Why lower the very high marginal tax rates when so few actually paid tax at those rates, anyway? Why try to restore integrity to the system when to do so would cost votes and dollars-votes and dollars that were being accrued only because the system was breaking down under the pressure of the cheats. There was never any uncertainty about the Opposition's attitude to these cheats. Time after time Opposition members have come into the Parliament and refused point blank to vote in favour of legislation which would see the tax avoiders and evaders pay what they owe.

Let us ask ourselves who has ultimately suffered from the Opposition's refusal to take any firm stand on tax evaders. Who are the real victims of the Howard legacy of a crippled, outmoded tax system? The answer, of course, is that it is precisely the same group of Australians whom the Opposition is hypocritically defending here today. Someone had to make up the shortfall left by the tax cheats and the burden fell fairly and squarely onto the shoulders of the same low and middle income earners about which the Opposition now pretends to be concerned. It was those people and their families who saw their tax payments increase while the top few per cent of wealthy wheelers and dealers perfected their aims at the bottom of the harbour. It was those people, those low and middle income earners, who were amongst the very first people to receive direct assistance from the Hawke Government.

Let us look at what this Government with the assistance, I should add, of the world's best Treasurer has done for low and middle income earners in the reform of tax relief. First, there was the $7.60 tax cut in November 1984. Secondly, there was the enormous saving for low and middle income families when Medicare started in February 1984. Thirdly, there is the drop in marginal tax rates scheduled to take effect in September this year. Fourthly, there is the further reduction in marginal tax rates scheduled for July next year. What we are talking about are the biggest tax cuts in Australia's history-$4.5 billion worth of tax relief to ordinary Australian income earners.

No wonder the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and his shadow Treasurer are having trouble putting together their policies on tax. What do they offer as an appetiser? How are they planning to convince the Australian people that they could do better than $4.5 billion worth of tax relief? For a start, under the Opposition we know that there will be no wage indexation. That means no cost of living increase for income earners. There will also be no prices and incomes accord. That means no industrial peace and no social wage. There will be no Medicare, which means that health costs will once again go through the roof, especially for low and middle income earners. There will be no superannuation benefits which will put Australian workers back at the bottom of the heap compared with other industrialised countries. Most serious of all there will be no tax reform. We will be back in the mess in which we found ourselves in 1983 when the bulk of the tax burden fell squarely on the shoulders of the low and middle income earning families. The truth is that the Opposition is totally discredited, both in this place and in the wider Australian community. Its members would do well to study the tax package before they dare to come into this chamber and criticise the Government on such empty and spurious grounds.
