PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Barry Jones, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1986 which is now before the House contains significant amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1982. The Bill contains 10 Schedules which incorporate changes, firstly, initially introduced by Commonwealth of Australia Gazette notice and subsequently proposed in this House as Customs tariff proposals; secondly, introduced directly by Customs tariff proposals; or, thirdly, which are being introduced by this Bill.

Schedule 1 to the Bill is operative on and from 1 July 1985 and provides the mechanism for the restoration of duty free admission of certain parts used in the construction or modification of bountiable vessels.

The Government's October 1984 decision on the Australian shipbuilding industry provided for the removal of the 2 per cent revenue duty on imports of such ships' parts, making them duty free. This was intended to assist shipbuilders to hold down costs of inputs and improve their competitiveness against imported new vessels, which are duty free. At that time most ships' parts were admissible at 2 per cent under a Customs by-law. This by-law subsequently lapsed on 1 July 1985 when the old commercial by-law system was terminated. By ceasing to be eligible for the 2 per cent duty rate provided for by the Customs by-law they thus lost their eligibility for the further duty free concession. This nullified the intent of the shipbuilding assistance package.

The amendment in this Schedule re-instates the eligibility of the parts for the 2 per cent duty and consequently they will again become free of duty in accordance with the Government's shipbuilding assistance decision. Schedule 2 to the Bill, operative on and from the 2 August 1985, provides for the wool content level in the pile of carpets from New Zealand eligible for duty free entry to be reduced from 80 per cent to 78 per cent by weight. This relaxation of the wool content requirement has been agreed with New Zealand under the Australia-New Zealand closer economic relations trade agreement and takes effect from the date set out in the exchange of letters between the relevant Australian and New Zealand Ministers.

Schedule 3 to the Bill, operative on and from 21 August 1985, complements the Subsidy (Grain Harvesters and Equipment) Act 1985 which was passed in the 1985 Budget sittings. This schedule removes the 15 per cent general tariff rate previously applicable to grain harvesters and certain parts for these machines. Also included in this Schedule is a consequential amendment to maintain the duty treatment applicable to certain metal parts.

The changes contained in Schedule 4 to the Bill are operative on and from 11 October 1985 and implement most of the Government's decisions on the Industries Assistance Commission's report on telecommunications and related equipment and parts. The changes arising from this report are the first stage of the two-stage plan to revitalise Australia's communications equipment industry for growth into the 1990s and beyond. Under this first stage, the Government has accepted the IAC's recommendation that tariffs on most imported telecommunications products and components be reduced from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. These reductions are being phased in over a four-year period. The IAC's report on the industry had recommended reductions over a two-year period for most products.

In agreeing to a four-year phased reduction, the Government has sought the co-operation of the local industry in developing a comprehensive strategy to address the industry's long term problems. This strategy is expected to be announced by the middle of 1986. Issues which need to be addressed to enable the local industry to become more internationally competitive, export oriented and innovative include: The relatively small size of Australian companies; insufficient commitment to local research and development; fragmented market efforts; and restrictive regulatory procedures which act as a disincentive to growth. These broad issues will be tackled in the later package of measures. From the Government's side, the package would largely entail improved co-ordination of existing government activities, particularly in the areas of government purchasing, offsets, technology programs, regulation and trade strategies.

The Government's decision to handle the question of assistance in two stages was the result of extended consultation within government departments, with industry groups and other interested bodies, and with the Government's tripartite advisory council on the electrical, electronics and information industries. These groups are continuing to be actively involved in developing the package of industry development measures, within the framework of general Government policies.

As part of its decision on the IAC's report, the Government has accepted the recommendation for a 25 per cent value added production bounty to be paid on modems and multiplexors generally used with computers. This bounty is to apply from 1 July 1986 and the duty applicable to equivalent imported goods will be reduced to minimum rates from that date. In addition, preforms used in the manufacture of optical fibre are to be subject to a general tariff rate of 20 per cent from 1 July 1986. The relevant tariff changes are contained in Schedule 9 to this Bill.

Schedule 5 to the Bill is operative from 22 November 1985 and comprises most of the legislation to implement the Government's decision on the IAC's report on re-import concessions. The Government's decision results in considerable simplification of the provisions governing the concessional entry of goods which have previously been exported from Australia.

Goods and parts of goods which are returned to Australia without any change to the identity they possessed when they were exported are eligible for duty free entry. Unlike the previous concession, there is no requirement that the goods have not entered the commerce of another country; no time limit after which they are not eligible for duty free entry or that their ownership has not changed. The requirement that all Commonwealth taxes and charges due at the time of exportation from Australia have either been paid and not refunded, or, if refunded, are paid again prior to duty free entry being granted, does, however, remain. A new provision is being inserted into the Customs Tariff Act to allow the duty free admission of goods repaired overseas, or replaced, under a specific warranty applicable to previously imported goods.

One of the Government's decisions is not included in this particular Schedule to the Bill. Goods exported for repair or renovation which cannot be performed in Australia are to be eligible for duty free entry under commercial tariff concession orders made by the Comptroller- General of Customs.

New provisions are being inserted into the Customs Act 1901 by the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986 to enable such orders to be issued on and from 1 July 1986. The consequential amendment to the Customs Tariff Act 1982 is contained in Schedule 9 to this Bill.

A minor amendment is being made to the remaining provision relating to the concessional entry for goods returned to Australia after having undergone repair or renovation overseas. Provided that the goods retain the identity they possessed when they were exported, the duty payable on their return will be assessed on the value of the repair or renovation only, at the ad valorem rate applicable to the parent goods. In line with the IAC's recommendation, this provision does not apply to goods subjected to alteration overseas.

Schedule 6 to the Bill puts in place tender quota provisions associated with the post-1984 arrangements for passenger motor vehicles. This Schedule is operative on and from 1 December 1985. Following amendments made last year to the Customs Act 1901 it is now possible to depart from a rigid 12-month period for tender quota allocations. Accordingly, a period of 14 months is being provided for the one year quota to allow a one-month anticipation before the start of the calendar year and a one-month carry over after its conclusion. Similarly, the four periods involved in the four-year tender will each run from 1 December in a year to 31 January, 14 months later.

Vehicles imported under the single period tender quota scheme attract a general tariff tender quota rate of 81.5 per cent, a premium of 24 percentage points over the base quota rate. For the four-year tender quota scheme the tender quota rate is 68.5 per cent, 11 percentage points higher than the 57.5 per cent base quota rate.

Schedule 7 to the Bill is operative from 1 January 1986 and contains a variety of amendments. The amendment of Schedule 1 to the principal Act removes Portugal from the list of countries eligible for developing country preference. This action coincides with Portugal's becoming a member of the European Economic Community. Similar action was taken when Greece joined the Community. This Schedule puts in place the 1986 developing country preference and tender quota arrangements applying under the Government's textiles, clothing and footwear sectoral policy.

Included in these amendments are arrangements to allow for extensions of validity for textiles, clothing and footwear tender quota allocations. Also included in this Schedule are amendments removing redundant phasing rates of duty from Schedule 3 and Part II of Schedule 4 to the principal Act. This action has enabled further tariff simplification to occur as certain tariff classifications are amalgamated. In a similar vein, redundant phasing provisions in Schedule 5 to the principal Act, which covers New Zealand imports, are being removed.

The final amendment in Schedule 7 amends item 23 in Part I of Schedule 4 to the principal Act. This item was inserted in the Customs Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1985, which was passed in the 1985 Budget sittings. It has been found that the item is deficient in that it does not provide concessional admission for parts of the components designated in the item. Such parts for components were eligible for bounty payment under the previous assistance regime for heavy commercial motor vehicles and thus should receive the benefits of the provisions of item 23. The amendment of the item will achieve this objective. Schedule 8 to the Bill, operative on and from 18 February 1986, provides for the application of the principles of the Government's decision to implement a revised system of tariff preferences for developing countries to the goods covered by the Industries Assistance Commission's report on tableware and other goods of ceramics. The Government decided that, in accordance with the IAC's recommendation, the general tariff rate for the goods under reference should remain at 20 per cent.

I will outline the principles of the new developing countries preference scheme when I come to Schedule 9 of the Bill but in regard to goods of tariff item 69.11, covering tableware and other goods of porcelain or china, all developing country imports will receive a five percentage points margin. For tableware and other goods not being of porcelain or china-tariff item 69.12-the Republic of Korea and Taiwan Province will remain ineligible for the 15 per cent developing country rate until 1 July 1988.

Schedule 9 to the Bill contributes most to its size. Its operative date is 1 July 1986. This Schedule implements new preference arrangements for developing countries and for forum island countries. Under the revised developing countries preference scheme, the developing country rate will be five percentage points below the general tariff rate, where that general tariff rate is 5 per cent or greater. For goods subject to other than an ad valorem rate a margin equivalent to five percentage points is being provided. The new scheme will not apply to goods where there is no protective rate, or where goods only attract duties identical to Australian excise tariff rates. For goods incurring both excise and protective rates the new scheme will apply to the protective component but such rates have been structured so that in no circumstance will the rate be lower than the equivalent excise rate. Developing country quotas will be abolished except where they relate to textiles, clothing and footwear products where quotas will continue until 31 December 1988.

Under the new scheme there is no provision for graduating either products or countries from it. As a transitional measure, where action has been taken to exclude countries from the present scheme for particular products in the three years prior to 1 July 1986, they will continue to be excluded for a further two years. The scheme will apply to products covered by the textiles, clothing and footwear industries plan from the end of the current plan on 31 December 1988. It will apply to goods covered by the steel and motor vehicles sectoral policies from 1 July 1986. However, the current exclusions of certain countries for some cold-rolled steel products will continue until the end of the present steel plan on 31 December 1988 and quotas already allocated for the importation of motor vehicles will be continued at the existing margin of preference.

The existing developing countries scheme has distorted Australian industry policy, increased disparities in tariff assistance between like goods and created uncertainty about assistance levels for local manufacturers thereby hampering restructuring and business planning. It has also led to increasing friction with Australia's developing country trading partners. The revised scheme will be administratively simpler, more certain in application, and focus attention towards more constructive industry development and trade goals. The Government recognises that, as a result of the changes, preference margins will be created in some areas and increased in others. Overall this will be offset by significantly reduced margins in other areas of industry.

The Government considers that the application of a five percentage points margin of preference would not be large enough to cause any major difficulties for industry. However, reference to the Industries Assistance Commission remains where an industry is experiencing difficulties competing against imports from any source.

The Government's decision follows a thorough review of the system of granting preferential access to developing countries. As part of this review Professor Helen Hughes of the Centre for Development Studies at the Australian National University was commissioned to report on the scheme and her recommendations form the substance of the new approach. In the review the Government rejected such options as abandonment of DC preferences or adoption of trigger mechanisms to automatically graduate countries or products out of the scheme. The option adopted reaffirms Australia's commitment to the concept of developing country preferences. Australia was the first country in the world to introduce such preferences, which are now accorded by most developed countries.

The new scheme represents a significant improvement over the existing scheme. The new scheme provides Australian industry and all Australia's trading partners, both developed and developing, with a settled framework for development of investment and trading plans. Under the new system the developing country tariff rate and the general tariff rate will be set as a package and industry planning can proceed in this knowledge. Australian industry seeking to complement local production with external sourcing can plan with greater confidence than exists under the present arrangements. In discussions most of the developing countries in the Australian region have welcomed the broad thrust of the new system which incorporates important principles endorsed by the developing countries generally. Some disappointment has been expressed at the reduction that will be entailed in existing margins of preference for some items and a larger margin of preference than five percentage points was generally desired. The Australian Government considers that any disadvantage arising from margin reductions will be offset in the longer term by the guarantees of margins at any volume of trade in the situation where Australia's tariffs are moving towards lower levels of assistance.

The other initiative in regard to Australia's trading relations contained in Schedule 9 is the new Forum island preference scheme. Australia undertook a major review of the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement in 1985. Following this review the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) announced at the 1985 South Pacific Forum meeting in the Cook Islands that Australia would introduce a new scheme which would expand the duty free access entitlement for Forum island countries on and from 1 January 1987. The Prime Minister announced that duty free unrestricted access would be granted for all exports from Forum island countries, other than for those goods to which sectoral policies apply. The goods covered by these sectoral policies are textiles, clothing and footwear, steel, passenger motor vehicles and sugar. In addition, those products on which excise is levied when they are produced in Australia will be subject to a customs duty at the same rate as the excise duty.

The Government has now decided that, with the exception of passionfruit products, the introduction date of the new scheme will be brought forward to 1 July 1986 to coincide with the commencement date of the new developing countries preference scheme. The changes in regard to passionfruit products will take effect from 1 January 1987. The original operative date for passionfruit products is being maintained to allow a transition period for local producers because virtually all imported passionfruit products come from the Forum islands and these islands have a penetration of the Australian market in excess of 10 per cent.

Schedule 9 also includes those changes to operate from 1 July 1986 which arise from the Government's decision on the IAC's report on telecommunications and related equipment and parts. Certain modems and multiplexors are to become dutiable at minimum rates and optical fibre preforms are to be dutiable at a general tariff rate of 20 per cent.

An amendment is being made to item 3 in Part I of Schedule 4 to the principal Act which presently provides duty free entry for goods imported for the personal or official use of the Governor-General, the Governor of a State, a member of the family of the Governor-General or the Governor of a State or a member of the staff of the Governor-General or the Governor of a State, being a member of the staff who is not an Australian citizen. This concession goes back to the time when Governors and their staff were mostly appointed from outside the country. As this is no longer the case there is no justification for continuing concessions in relation to goods for personal use.

The concession is accordingly being restricted to goods for the official use of the Governor-General, the Governor of a State or a member of the family of the Governor-General or the Governor of a State. No concessions will be available for members of the staff of the Governor-General or the Governor of a State. The final amendment required to implement the Government's decision on the IAC's report on re-import concessions is also contained in Schedule 9.

Item 31 in Part I of Schedule 4 is re-drafted to allow the issue of commercial tariff concession orders for goods exported for repair or renovation which cannot be performed in Australia in the normal course of business. The opportunity has also been taken in this Schedule to remove all redundant phasing rates from the various Schedules to the principal Act. The final Schedule to the Bill, Schedule 10, is to operate seven days after royal assent to the legislation. This Schedule inserts a new legal note, note 12 to chapter 84 in Schedule 3 to the Principal Act, defining the term `of the track-laying type', which is used in connection with tractors and tractor bases.

Special provisions for goods of the track-laying type at minimum rates of duty have appeared in the customs tariff for many years. The concept of equipment incorporating tractor bases of the track-laying type attracting a separate duty on the tractor base arose out of an IAC report in 1974. It has always been considered that the provision only applied to the traditional tracked vehicles that can only operate when their tracks are attached.

A recent ruling by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal has applied the term in question to a loader which was imported with tracks which go over the wheels of the vehicle but which can operate as a wheeled vehicle without the tracks. This extension of the term has had the effect of lowering the level of assistance intended to be accorded the local manufacture of such machines.

The major local manufacturer has made representations to the Government concerning this loss of assistance. After consideration of this matter, the Government accepts that the intended assistance levels should be restored and, accordingly, an amendment is being made to the Customs Tariff Act.
Financial Impact

On 27 March 1985 the Treasurer (Mr Keating), in his statement on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure report on taxation expenditure, pointed out that the revenues raised by Customs duties are incidental to their prime purpose of assistance to industry. With this qualification in mind, it has been possible to make some estimates in regard to changes to Customs revenue for some of the changes contained in this Bill. The removal of the duty on grain harvesters and certain parts is expected to reduce revenue by $4.1m in 1985-86 and $8.25m annually thereafter. The general reduction in tariffs resulting from the Government's decision on the IAC's report on telecommunications and related equipment and parts is not expected to reduce government receipts. This conclusion is based on the knowledge that over 70 per cent of imported telecommunications equipment enters under concessional arrangements and that projected increases of dutiable imports of telecommunications equipment will more than compensate for the reductions in tariffs. In the case of outgoings the complementary amendments to the Bounty (Computers) Act in regard to modems and multiplexors is expected to cost $3.5m in 1986-87. This increase in outgoings is expected to be partly or fully compensated by increases in the level of dutiable imports of telecommunications equipment.

The changes made as a result of the Government's decision on the re-import concessions IAC report are basically designed to improve the administration of the concessions rather than vary their scope to any great degree. Thus, any financial impact will be minor. Similarly, the Government's decision on the IAC's report on tableware and other goods of ceramics is revenue neutral. It is difficult at this stage to quantify the financial impact of the revised system of tariff preferences for developing countries. It has, however, been estimated that, overall, the revised scheme will result in a slight increase in assistance. Estimates of any additional revenue to be gained by such an increase in assistance could only be calculated on existing import trends. In order to speculate on any such increase, an assumption would need to be made that these import trends will continue after the introduction of the revised scheme. The Government is not in a position, at this stage, to so speculate.

The proposed removal of tariffs on imports from the forum island countries is not expected to have a significant impact on revenue. Australian imports from the relevant countries amounted to only $217.5m in 1984-85 and 98 per cent of these were accorded duty free entry. In addition, the forum island countries have limited capacity to displace third country suppliers to the Australian market. All the other changes in the Bill are also expected to have minimal financial impact. There are no significant administrative costs associated with the Bill. A summary of amendments for each schedule to the Bill has been prepared. Copies are available from the Table Office. With extreme regret, I draw to the end of the speech and table the explanatory memorandum to the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS ADMINISTRATION (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1986

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —The House will recall that it agreed to a cognate debate on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1986, the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1986, and the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986. These Bills were debated when the House met this morning. After the cognate debate concluded, the House agreed to the second and third readings of all three Bills.

INTERJECT.PARA: It has been drawn to my attention that the third Bill in this group-the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986-was received from the Senate on 8 April and its second reading was made an order of the day for a subsequent sitting. Subsequently, the second reading should have been moved by a Minister but this did not occur. Therefore, when the order of the day for this Bill was called on earlier today, the second reading should have been moved by a Minister. This was not done. To ensure that the Bill is properly considered by the House, I believe the appropriate motions and questions on this Bill should be put again.
Motion (by Mr Barry Jones)-by leave-agreed to:

That the resolutions of the House this day on the Customs Administration (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1986 be rescinded and the order of the day for the second reading be called again.
Consideration resumed from 8 April.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Barry Jones) agreed to:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) read a third time.
Bill presented by Mr Cohen, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALKER.NAME: Mr COHEN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Bicentennial)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to establish the Australian National Maritime Museum. This exciting Museum will take its place alongside other collecting institutions operated by the Commonwealth such as the National Library, the National Gallery and the National Museum of Australia. In November 1985 the Government agreed to provide $30m to enable the construction and fit-out of the building for the Australian National Maritime Museum on a site at Darling Harbour provided by the New South Wales Government. The Federal Government will own and operate the Museum which will be the first national collecting institution to be located outside Canberra. The Government is committed to the Museum opening its doors to the public in 1988.

When the Labor Government first came to office in 1983 there were before us the proposals in the report of the Pigott Committee of Inquiry on Museums and National Collections-namely, that Australia should have three national collecting institutions-the Museum of Australia, the National Maritime Museum and the National Aviation Museum. Some time ago we made the decision, as the House will be aware, to establish the Museum of Australia, now to be known as the National Museum of Australia, in Canberra. We have now made a decision to build the Maritime Museum in Sydney. I am hopeful that in the foreseeable future we will implement the third leg of the Pigott report and establish a national aviation museum, probably in Victoria.

I digress from my prepared speech to say that the site selected for the National Maritime Museum at Darling Harbour is one of the most stunning sites in the world, and will be involved in the brilliantly conceived Darling Harbour redevelopment proposals which are now in the process of being completed by the New South Wales Government. I can tell those who have not seen the proposal that this is one of the great visions of the age. I commend the New South Wales Premier for his foresight in proposing that development authority. I am delighted that the Maritime Museum will be located there.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hobart would be a very nice site.
—I would say to the honourable member for Denison that there are many nice sites.
—Including Perth.

—Yes, and Perth. If the Canberra bureaucrats had had their way, it would have been at Lake Burley Griffin. It is sad that all these national institutions cannot be located in 10 different sites, but a site has to be selected and this site is brilliant. Already the conceptual design by the architect Philip Cox has been prepared, and if the final building is anything like the conceptual plans it will be stunning.
—Will you be putting the Australian Antarctic museum in Hobart?

—I do not usually answer interjections, but that was a good one. I mentioned earlier that there are three museums-two we now have under way, and I hope that the aviation museum will be added. I have said in a number of speeches recently that there is enormous pressure now on the Government for museums all over the country. These buildings are extremely expensive-we are talking of sums of $30m, $40m, and in some cases $100m. There are now proposals before the Government for two Antarctic museums, for a museum for sport, for an immigration museum, and for a motor museum in South Australia. They are only the tip of the iceberg. As a Government, we would love to be able to undertake all of them and, hopefully, in time that will happen. But this Government in a short space of time has probably done more in the area of national collecting institutions than has any other Government in history. So although one would want to follow up what the honourable member for Denison interjected about in respect of an antarctic museum, people must realise that there is a limit as to what we can do. So it is in the future, yes, but not the immediate future.

SPEECH.PARA: The need for an Australian National Maritime Museum, reflecting the significance of maritime activity in the history and cultural life of Australians, was recognised over a decade ago in the Pigott report. Possibly no other country has relied more on the sea and acknowledged this debt less. The present Government has affirmed the need for an institution to provide Australians with a central and comprehensive record of their past and present dependence on the sea. The Australian National Maritime Museum will provide a focus for our maritime history and an insight to its visitors of a major facet of our cultural tradition, until now little acknowledged.

The Bill will establish the Museum as a body corporate and its functions will be to develop Australia's national maritime collection; to preserve, acquire, recover and maintain maritime historical material and exhibit that material which is in the national maritime collection or otherwise both in Australia and overseas. The Museum will also be able to conduct, and assist in, research and to disseminate information relating to Australian maritime history.

Maritime historical material is defined in the Bill to mean material relating to Australian maritime history-which no doubt will come as a great shock to everybody present. Australian maritime history is widely defined to include the natural history of Australia, the history of the interaction of human beings with the Australian marine environment, and the history of sea travel for every purpose. The reference to Australian marine environment includes the sea above the continental shelf and the sub-soil of the continental shelf adjacent to the Australian coast. It also includes the environment of the lakes, rivers and internal waters of Australia. This allows the Museum effectively to acquire any material of a maritime nature provided it has a connection with Australia. A Museum Council is established by this Bill and the Council will ensure the proper and efficient performance of the Museum and determine its policy, subject to ministerial direction. I will speak shortly about its constitution.

The Bill empowers the Museum to develop a national collection of maritime historical material which shall be determined by its council as being included in the national maritime collection. Any such determination by its council shall be based upon criteria and made in accordance with guidelines approved by the Minister. The Bill provides for the Museum to purchase historical and other relevant material. It will accept gifts and bequests and it will acquire and operate vessels of historical interest and significance. It will collect maritime information in various forms, such as books, charts, manuscripts, log books, films, video tapes and sound recordings. The Museum will be subject to the law of copyright and to the laws relating to the preservation and use of archival resources, and to the rights of the public to have access to official documents of the Commonwealth Government and its agencies.

Much of Australia's historical material reflecting the involvement of its people with the sea has never been exhibited on a large scale. The creation of this Museum will correct that. The Government intends that the displays for the Museum will be based on a series of exciting and dramatic themes dealing with particular aspects of our links with the sea and Australian waterways. It will not be a mere collection of inanimate objects. I see that the honourable member for Denison has returned to the House. It might be worth mentioning to the people of the honourable member's State that simply because the museum is located in Sydney does not mean that exhibitions of the maritime museum cannot be displayed in part or in whole in other cities. Some of the ships may well be displayed, as with some of the other material collected, in Hobart or other cities.

TALK.START.PARA: —It will be a floating museum.
—Absolutely.
—I was not being rude; I was just fixing up the Antarctic museum with your colleague the Minister for Science.

—As long as the Minister for Science is paying for it out of his Department, the honourable member can go for his life. The Museum will be a place of public education, participation and enjoyment for all who enter-a dynamic, living complex of activities and interests.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is expressed to apply not only to the Australian mainland but also to its external territories, past and present. This is to ensure both the comprehensiveness of the national maritime collection and the respect accorded the heritage and culture of Australia's external territories. Material of significance from Australian external territories in the Pacific, Indian and Southern oceans and Antarctica would only be transferred to the national maritime collection after consultation with the Minister for Territories or the Minister for Science, as the case may be, and the local governing body of the relevant territory.

Whilst the Museum as a Government institution will be funded through the annual budgetary processes, the Bill also provides for the establishment of a National Maritime Museum Fund which will consist of money, or money from the disposal of gifts, bequests and the assignment of property-otherwise than on trust-to raise money for disbursement in accordance with the functions of the Museum. The Museum will be able to charge an admission fee and to operate a broad range of commercial activities. The Museum is required under the proposed legislation to prepare annual estimates of expenditure and shall not enter a contract for an acquisition exceeding $100,000 without the Minister's approval. The Museum will be subject to audit by the Auditor-General and will also be obliged to prepare an annual report by virtue of being subject to certain provisions of the Audit Act 1901. I am reminded of the fact that only a few weeks ago we made our first major purchase, by purchasing Ken Warby's Spirit of Australia for some $200,000, part of which was donated by Speedo Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You will not get any maritime Blue Poles for $100,000.

—No, but if I do I will make sure that the honourable member is up one of them. The Museum will not be subject to taxation under Commonwealth or State law. The Museum will be able to operate a restaurant and catering facilities on vessels or property which the Museum owns or controls, and for this reason the Bill provides for the Museum to supply liquor, so the honourable member will be able to visit it and feel at home. The Council of the Museum, which I referred to earlier, shall consist of a Chairperson, the Director and other members, appointed by the Governor-General, to be no fewer than seven nor more than 10. An appointed member is to be a person having knowledge and experience with respect to matters relating to Australian maritime history or such other areas of knowledge relevant to the affairs of the Museum. The day-to-day management of the Museum will be conducted by a Director who shall also be appointed by the Governor-General for a period of up to seven years. The Director shall have all the powers of a secretary of a department in relation to the staff of the Museum who will be employed under the Public Service Act. The management of the Museum by the Director will be subject to directions given, and policies formulated by, the Council.

SPEECH.PARA: The Museum will be encouraged by the Government to adopt an entrepreneurial outlook in organising its activities. For example, I would expect that the theatre proposed to be included in the Museum will be available for use by outside groups for film screenings, seminars and lectures. A publishing program will be developed and the Museum shop will sell books, toys and a whole range of quality goods and souvenirs. Might I add here that I think that one of the great benefits of travelling overseas and visiting many museums is to see how entrepreneurial many museums are, particularly those in the United States. I am somewhat critical of our own museums for not following the example set by American and continental museums. Largely because many of these museums have not depended on substantial government funding, they have had to be more entrepreneurial.

We also have a problem in our own set up in Australia where some of the museums being run by government simply lose the benefit of entrepreneurial activities because Treasury and Finance take it away from them. So there is not a lot of encouragement. That has happened under a Liberal administration and it has happened under our administration. I really think that it is something we need to look at in detail to encourage the management and councils of museums to be more entrepreneurial. As I have said, some of the museums in America-the Metropolitan, the Washington Museum and the American Museum of History-are just staggering in their entrepreneurial activities. These museums raise a very large proportion of their running costs from their own entrepreneurial efforts.

In addition to the Museum's attraction and affect on tourism, it also will support a number of people in related professions, trades and services. Its establishment and work will help to revive traditional maritime crafts and provide opportunities to pass on skills which would otherwise be lost. It is the Government's intention that the Museum place special emphasis on the young. This will be reflected in the practical exhibits. Educational and other facilities, in the focus of a section of the library on material for younger readers and on the goods for sale in the Museum shop. The Museum's curatorial and conservation laboratories will also be designed so that visitors can view the activities there, to see not only the skills required in preservation and in mounting displays, but also to appreciate the effort and expense incurred in preserving our maritime heritage. I would like to stress the national emphasis of the Maritime Museum; it will neither compete with existing institutions in the States or Territories nor duplicate their efforts. Rather, it will complement the collections of those institutions.

If I may digress once again, I also anticipate that we will develop a very substantial `Friends of the National Maritime Museum', because there are many people, such as those now working in the Sydney Maritime Museum, who do an enormous amount of work gratis for the preservation of our maritime history. I hope that that institution will become absorbed into our new museum and that these people play the same role with the National Maritime Museum that they have done in the past with the Sydney Maritime Museum. The establishment of the Australian National Maritime Museum by this Bill is a further development in this Government's unequalled record of achievement in the preservation and display of Australia's heritage. This record reflects the aspirations and concerns of the Australian people and their enhanced pride in their history and development. The National Maritime Museum will take its place alongside our other national cultural institutions as a lasting, living, record of the richness and diversity of our past and present achievements as a maritime nation.

I want to say that if I was asked a question about my proudest achievement in three years as a Minister I would say the preservation of our heritage. In three short years I have managed to achieve a start on the National Museum of Australia, the Maritime Museum and the National Film and Sound Archives. I am hopeful in the foreseeable future that I will be able to add to that with the National Aviation Museum. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Connolly) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration in the Committee of the Whole House at the next sitting.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I re-iterate the comments I made prior to the suspension of the sitting at 12.45 p.m. today. I am very reluctant to support this legislation which requires the Federal Government to pay out of Consolidated Revenue almost $125m to a number of oil refiners. The fault lies not with the oil refiners but with the Government. It is with a great deal of trepidation that I find that I have no choice but to support this legislation for the simple reason that the oil refiners were forced by the Government to incur a loss. It is a loss made not because of their commercial ineptitude or misjudgment or because of variations in the market, but because of the import parity pricing policy which forced them to purchase Australian crude oil at the world price and to sell it at a newly set domestic price. This Government's worshipping of import parity pricing at the high altar of taxation has led to a draining of $125m from Consolidated Revenue, an utterly unnecessary payout due entirely to the regulation imposed by this Government on the oil industry of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Mr Barry Jones): Can he assure the Parliament that this situation will not occur again in the future? I think that he cannot. It may well be that another dramatic drop in the world price of oil will mean further stock losses by oil refiners. Of course, this is predicated on the assumption that the Government will pass on such a drop to Australian motorists, farmers and fishermen in the first place. Certainly, if this Government's track record is anything to go by, that is a faint hope. The Government needs to move towards deregulation and a free market so that, firstly, taxpayers are not again forced to compensate the oil companies in this fashion and, secondly, lower international oil prices can be enjoyed by Australians. The bottom line is that Australians are paying too much for their petrol. They are needlessly paying an inflated price simply because of this Government's dependence up on the oil taxation excise revenue. Until the Government moves away from such heavy reliance, it will continue to be locked into the import parity pricing formula.

It is my belief that the drop in international prices can be passed on to Australians in full. But it will require a number of hard decisions by this Government. It will need to look at its monetary policy-its wages policy and its fiscal policy. In regard to fiscal policy it needs to look at its social security and social welfare programs. It needs to look at health. It needs to look at the waste and duplication. Whether it be the payout of over $1m for International Year of Peace projects, Priority One, the Community Employment Program, the drugs program, or the expansion of the public sector, waste and duplication are the highlights of these glossy, much publicised, self-promoting programs of this Government. So it is not true to say that this Government runs a tight ship. It is a Government bloated by excesses and unnecessary expenditure.

The Government must realise by now, if not some time ago, that Australia's competitiveness in international markets is declining. Sadly, it may well be that by 30 June 1986 our trading deficit will have hit $14 billion. None of us should take any delight in the embarrassment and hardship that that will cause the Government because it means, as a result, that Australia's standard of living is inexorably dropping. The Government needs to realise that the bulk of our export industries, which involve mineral extracts and primary produce, depend heavily on fuel as a means of keeping their prices down. For instance, it is estimated that 40 per cent of off-farm costs-not to mention on-farm costs-are related to fuel. Transport and handling charges are also a major component, but almost half of off-farm costs relate to fuel.

It is impossible to exaggerate or overestimate the importance of the price of fuel to our trading industries and thereby our international competitiveness, which by and large sets the standard of living in this country. It is true to say that fuel is not the only factor which relates to our international competitiveness. Obviously, one must look at monetary policy which-it seems to me this has been admitted by most Government members-has been squeezed as far as it can. The result of the monetary policy of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is record high interest rates. That also may well prop up the Australian dollar for the moment, but it is something which adds further to our decline in international competitiveness. We need to look at the wages policy, a rigid and inflexible system which not only hurts our international competitiveness but also shuts out the unemployed, including the young unemployed. In regard to fiscal policy, the Treasurer says that he seeks to achieve $1.4 billion in savings by 30 June. Yet, if Press reports are to be believed, the Government can find savings of only $300m. Our trade promotion is a ridiculous joke.

Fuel-the object of the legislation that is before the House-is of paramount importance to this nation, which is basically a trading nation. In my electorate of Gippsland one of the principal towns, and one of the centres of east Gippsland, is, of course, the city of Sale, which all members would know is the centre for the Esso operations in Bass Strait. It is often said that every cloud has a silver lining. Sadly, for the city of Sale, the recent drop in international fuel prices-however marginal it may have been, however unsatisfactory to motorists it may have been and however much it denies them their full entitlement-has meant a tightening of belts at Esso. It means that Esso has shelved the major proportion of its exploration program. This is having an effect on the city of Sale. The city of Sale is not dependent on Esso alone. It has, after all, a Royal Australian Air Force base. It has a number of service industries. It has a very large rural hinterland. Sale will however suffer hardship to a significant degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BARRY JONES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I will summarise some of the points that have been made in the debate by restating that this piece of legislation has been introduced to cover what we regard as an exceptional situation. Between the period from January to May-tomorrow being 1 May-the import parity price will have fallen 57 per cent. In January the IPP was $43.71, on 1 March it was $27.09, on 1 April it was $20.99 and the estimated price for tomorrow, 1 May, is $18.90. So from January through March there was a 38 per cent fall, from March to April a 22.5 per cent fall and from April to May a 10 per cent fall. When this happened and Australian producers were stuck with fuel that had been lifted, as they say, during a period of higher IPP, a commitment was given publicly by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), in a joint statement in February 1986, that the oil producers would not be stuck with the higher prices.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) asked me a question. He is no longer here but perhaps his friends can pass the answer on to him. He asked for an assurance that what is contemplated in this legislation will not recur. Of course, no categorical assurance can be given. I simply say that stock losses in April and May will be recovered from the market-place; that is, if the Prices Surveillance Authority is persuaded by the industry argument. But the Government certainly does not regard this payment as a precedent.

The size of the change, that is, a fall of 57 per cent since January, for which compensation is being paid, is quite beyond the everyday commercial swings and roundabouts. When prices were going up, the Prices Justification Tribunal, the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority and now the Prices Surveillance Authority did not permit oil companies to increase their wholesale prices until the lower priced stocks had been run down. I simply put it to the House that it would be inequitable, at a time when prices are going down, to force companies to bear the costs attributable to the higher priced stock.

Although it may be very difficult to persuade people out in voter land of this, from an international point of view Australia is really delivering comparatively cheap fuel. Of 15 nations listed in a table that I will seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard, most of them industrialised nations, the cheapest petrol price in terms of Australian cents per litre is in the United States of America where it is 42c a litre. In Australia the figure is 47c-that, of course, is the city price-which is the same as in Canada. The price here is considerably below that of the leaders on the list. In Italy, which is an oil producing nation, the price is 114c; in Japan, which is not an oil producing nation, the price is 110c; in Norway, which is a significant oil producer, the equivalent price is 102c. I seek leave to have the table incorporated in Hansard.
