TALK.START.PARA: —But, should the current level of oil prices persist, there would be very serious implications for the oil search industry in this country. It may be better for the consumer in the short term but in the long term it could have very serious effects. If the current level persists, the level of petroleum exploration and development activity will decline substantially below the historically high levels that have been achieved under this Government's policy in the last three years. It is the Government's objective to ensure that the exploration and development industry remains in a healthy state throughout the current period of low prices in order for it to be in a position to respond when prices again rise.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Resources and Energy has indicated that there will be a review of the Government's petroleum taxation arrangements. The submission that the Minister has received from the industry indicates that the focus of the review should be the replacement of production based taxes with profit based taxes, such as the resource rent tax for off-shore areas and the resource rent royalty for Barrow Island. That in turn means that taxation of on-shore petroleum discoveries through crude oil excise and State and Northern Territory royalties, both essentially production based, require careful examination.

I repeat what I have said in some earlier debates on similar subjects, that the current low world oil prices and, perhaps more importantly, the continuing state of uncertainty in the market are beginning to have substantial impact on the petroleum exploration and development plans of companies. I do not mean just here in Australia; I mean globally. Activity is being disrupted as companies wait for some order to return to world oil markets before finalising and implementing revised exploration and development plans. Companies have already deferred some activity because of reduced cash flow and uncertainty about the short to medium term prospects for a recovery in oil prices. On that basis, the Bureau of Mineral Resources has estimated that activity could fall by 40 per cent compared with the record low levels achieved in 1985. I remember when Jean-Claude Paye, the Secretary-General of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, was here some months ago, he indicated with great apprehension that there would be a very dramatic fall in oil prices world-wide, which at first people would welcome but this would then lead to an even more dramatic fall in the amount of exploration going on, which might then be followed by a series of short, sharp shocks with prices oscillating very rapidly, which could result in profound instability which could have very serious global consequences. I thank honourable members for their contribution to the debate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Message from the Governor-General recommending appropriation announced.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Barry Jones) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER HERITAGE (INTERIM PROTECTION) AMENDMENT BILL 1986

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 April, on motion by Mr Holding:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is highly unusual for the House to have to retrace its steps and to debate legislation of this nature. In the past we have had ministerial laws and regulations and matters relating to customs and excise, tariffs and so forth regularly before the House. But it is quite extraordinary that tonight we are debating once again, as we did in May 1984, legislation to amend the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Act. However, there is a significant difference. When the House debated the original legislation, it was for an interim protection; in other words, the legislation contained a sunset clause. Under that provision, which was passed by the House, it was proposed that the legislation would cease to operate as of 24 June 1986.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), who is at the table, was the Minister who introduced the original legislation. Back in May 1984 he emphasised that the very essence of the legislation was its interim character. It had been introduced into the House principally to make up the difference between a gap, as the Government then saw it, in the protection of Aboriginal sacred sites and Aboriginal property and the fact that there was no land rights legislation at the Federal level.

It must be remembered that this Labor Government went to the people at the last election, and the first election at which it was endorsed by the nation, with a clear and concise policy for national Aboriginal land rights. No member of this House, and I certainly know that no member of the Aboriginal communities throughout Australia, will ever forget the commitments which were made by this Minister and by his Government and which have now been totally abrogated. I think it is significant that, when that interim legislation was initially brought in, it was essentially as a means of enabling the parliamentary Australian Labor Party and, in particular, the Minister, to go to the forthcoming Australian Labor Party National Conference and say: `Ladies and gentlemen, we have done something specific. Yes, it is only interim legislation, but we have filled the gap. We have kept our promise'. I think it is most interesting that here we are, almost two years later to the month, debating once again exactly the same legislation because the Minister, once again, having failed to put into place his national Aboriginal land rights legislation, is desperately looking for a cork to put in his political bottle so that he can go off to the July conference and say: `All is well. I have a marvellous deal with all the States. I do not have a national Aboriginal land rights legislation but I have the next best thing. Everything is marvellous and, to boot, we also have the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander legislation covering their heritage and it is in place for all time'.

I want to go on record as emphasising the fact that the coalition parties, both in government and in opposition, have continually made clear their concern for the need to protect significant sacred sites. We believe that there is equally a need to preserve the integrity of Aboriginal culture and Aboriginal history. It was specifically for that reason that the Northern Territory's land rights legislation, which is the responsibility of this Parliament unlike so-called national legislation, includes specific references for the protection of Aboriginal sites. Regrettably, the Bill before the House does not refer to sacred sites and the areas around them which may need to be protected.

I am shocked that the opportunity which was afforded the Minister and the Government to amend seriously this legislation to achieve the very objectives which the Minister claimed were built in has not been taken. As I said earlier, we have the shortest explanatory memorandum I have ever seen attached to any Bill introduced into this chamber. Essentially, all it consists of is the removal of the word `interim' and repealing section 33 which limited the duration of the present Act to two years. This was an opportunity which has been missed. When the Minister could have looked at the major problems which the legislation has failed to address he could have considered, for example, the fact that there was a lack of definition of a significant Aboriginal area in the Bill; that there are no guidelines to define such an area; and, equally, that there are no limits on the size of such an area as gazetted. Aboriginals are not required to demonstrate traditional affiliation with the area under application. Certainly there is gross, excessive, discretionary ministerial power on the influences and effect on entry and on land use. This, in turn, is demonstrated by the Bill's lack of appropriate cover of inadequate notification and review procedures and no compensation provisions. Perhaps the most significant point of all is that is overrides State powers. In fact, when we go further we see that it unnecessarily supplements existing State and Federal legislation.

I have not the slightest doubt that the Minister is well aware of the record on this matter. Every State of the Commonwealth now has in place Aboriginal heritage legislation. It may not be exactly the same and often that is for very sound reasons because conditions do vary State by State. In Queensland, for example, we have the Aboriginal Relics Preservation Act. In the Northern Territory we have the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Act. In Western Australia we have the Aboriginal Heritage Act and the same title applies to the legislation in South Australia. In Tasmania we have the Aboriginal Relics Act, in Victoria the Archaeological and Aboriginal Relics Preservation Act and in New South Wales the National Parks and Wildlife Act. I show the Minister almost an inch of legislation on the books of the various Australian parliaments-legislation which adequately covers precisely the subjects which allegedly were the reasons why this legislation was put on the statute books some two years ago.

Yet the Minister has failed utterly to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the Opposition why there is a need to continue this legislation in its current form, having made no attempt whatsoever to redefine, redirect or improve what was at that stage a grossly unsatisfactory Bill. The only reason is clear; it is a political reason. It is a last desperate effort to say to the Aboriginal people: `Okay, we failed to get in place national land rights but at least we are doing something to protect your heritage'. It is a sleight of hand. It is little more than an advertising gimmick, but one more gimmick of a government which, in the last year in particular, has approached all its policy issues and problems through gimmickry.

But the Aboriginal people of Australia are not fools. They know the difference between a government that is genuine and serious about its intentions and one which believes that it can overcome problems by stratagems of this nature. For that reason the Government's manifest weaknesses and failures in its policy towards Aboriginal people will carry far more weight than the mere simplistic approach that it has taken to the reintroduction of this legislation.

I shall not be introducing amendments to the Bill in this House, but the Opposition will certainly be moving them in the other place. It is important that the opportunity be taken in the House of review to try to solve some of these essential weaknesses that I have already outlined which are contained in this legislation. Nevertheless, the Opposition will certainly be voting against this legislation in this chamber, as we did when it was originally introduced, and obviously for exactly the same reasons. As I have said, the Act was initially introduced as an interim measure to fill what the Government claimed to be a legislative gap pending the introduction of comprehensive legislation dealing with Aboriginal land rights and heritage protection. All that is history; it has all passed. The Government's record stands and it stands condemned.

The opposition to the legislation has been manifestly obvious. We have had opposition from the Australian Mining Industry Council, the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association, the Australian Archaeological Association, Aboriginal communities and many others. When the legislation was originally introduced, the Minister's response was to send copies of the Bill to the States and other interested parties, virtually at the eleventh hour, and present them with nothing more than a fait accompli. I have no doubt that he well remembers the fact that he was swamped at that time in criticism of this legislation. But let him not think that the relative silence on this occasion represents anything except the fact that most people are unaware that the Bill is being reintroduced in this form in the chamber tonight. The criticisms which were voiced so clearly then remain today as real as they were on that occasion.

As I said earlier, regrettably the Minister has failed to take this opportunity to consider the substance of those issues and to bring to the House a responsible set of amendments to the original Bill. For that reason we remain opposed to this legislation. The development of the legislation, characterised as it has been by secrecy, insensitivity and virtually a total lack of concentration is but typical of the Government's approach to most Aboriginal matters.

The legislation was rejected by the Cabinet when the Minister first brought it forward. Unfortunately it was ultimately passed. The indecent haste with which it was introduced then and the total inability of the Minister to make the necessary amendments now have brought into question whether the Minister and this Government are in the slightest bit interested in meaningful discussion and consultation with anybody about legislation of this type. As I said, it has to be seen in the context of the gross political failure of the Government in putting into legislative form the promises and commitments it made to the Aboriginal people in relation to land rights. We have warned the Government for three years that in a federation one has to live with political realities, that land management is essentially a State responsibility. But no, the Government knew better. It could ignore all of that. It proceeded with a totally irrational approach which ultimately saw the entire legislative package founder on the rocks of its own incompetence.

Our most fundamental objection to this legislation is that it usurps the responsibilities which the States have already more than adequately provided for. All the States and the Northern Territory have legislation which protects Aboriginal cultural heritage. In New South Wales we see an interesting illustration of this. The National Parks and Wildlife Act 1974 protects sites in New South Wales. Its major provisions are that it protects relics and Aboriginal places. Anyone who discovers a relic, whether it is the property of the Crown or not, must report it to the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. It is illegal to disturb, damage or destroy a relic or Aboriginal place without the Director's prior written consent.

Then there is the Environmental Planning and Assessment Act 1979 which requires a review of environmental factors or, in many cases, an environmental impact statement prior to development. It also provides a mechanism for local and regional environmental planning. That process enables the Service to advise local councils on the existence of and management requirements for any sites in their areas. In addition to that, there is the Aboriginal Land Rights Act 1983, which allows for claims on vacant crown land not needed for essential public purposes. But it does not protect sites, nor does it allow them to be claimed by Aborigines. All the States and the Northern Territory have similar legislation which adequately protects Aboriginal sites. This is more than adequately demonstrated by the fact that the Acts have been used at the Federal level only once. Surely the question the Minister has failed to answer is why Federal legislation in this area is necessary in view of the coverage already provided by the States.

The Opposition believes that adequate Commonwealth legislation also renders the Act of little value. The Minister will recall when he introduced recently into this House the Protection of Movable Cultural Heritage Bill 1985 which the Opposition was pleased to support. It also gave adequate protection not only to Aboriginal but to all Australian movable cultural heritage. This Bill duplicates the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975 which provides for the protection of sites of Aboriginal significance. The Opposition believes that the Government is acting outside its constitutional authority. It must be remembered that until the 1967 referendum the Commonwealth was denied the power to legislate in relation to Aborigines. The yes case for the referendum was unequivocal in stating that the power would be used only in consultation with the States. Yet, legislation of this type manifestly and obviously contains no effective consultation. There has been no change to the way in which the Minister either in 1984 or now has approached this legislation.

When the legislation was initially introduced the States were virtually unanimous in their opposition to the Bill. For example, Mr Wilson, the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the Western Australian Labor Government said:

The State Government was not convinced and it remains unconvinced of the need for this legislation. It continues to have doubts and concerns about the lack of consultation between the State Government and the Commonwealth with respect to this matter.

There are a number of defects in the Act which was very badly drawn up as a stop-gap measure and which is now being permitted to continue in this most unsatisfactory manner. The most fundamental defect is in section 4 which sets out the purposes of the Act. It states:

The purposes of the Act are the preservation and protection from injury or desecration of areas and objects in Australia and in Australian waters, being areas and objects that are of particular significance to Aboriginals in accordance with Aborigine tradition.

This provision is important because the Act leaves a great deal of discretion in the hands of the Minister. He has no obligation to balance any other interests against those of the Aborigines. Whilst there is provision in the legislation for those who wish to make nominations to note any other interests, there is no provision in the Act which requires that those considerations be taken into account, nor is there any provision which enables the review of the Minister's decision to give other people who may be so influenced the opportunity to present their case. All we are told is that once the Minister is satisfied that a significant Aboriginal area or object is under threat of destruction or injury the Minister has a total unfettered discretion to issue a declaration to prevent that injury occurring regardless of competing interests.

Another defect of the Act is the unsatisfactory definition of the word `Aboriginal', which we are told means a member of the Aboriginal race of Australia and includes descendants of the indigenous inhabitants of the Torres Strait Islands. But there is no provision in the original Act which draws a distinction between what may be the view of an Aboriginal community on the one hand in relation to the protection of an area of relevance to the community and, on the other hand, the position which may be adopted by individual Aboriginals or even a group of Aboriginals working outside the agreed position of the community. Yet, as the legislation stands, even an individual Aboriginal has the right to come forward and claim that there has been a breach or a possible breach of an interest which that person as an individual may claim to have, irrespective of the position taken by the community which he may be a member of. These are essential issues which the Minister should have approached and should have been prepared to consider in relation to amendments to this legislation. But, as I said, the effort was not made and the Minister has had the temerity to come into this chamber and ask us to extend this dubious piece of legislation simply as a means of getting him off the hot seat at the next July conference of the Australian Labor Party.
Section 3 of the Act defines whether an area should be considered under threat and makes frequent reference to the need for the Minister to pay attention to Aboriginal tradition.

Section 3 (1) defines `Aboriginal tradition' as `the body of traditions, observances, customs and beliefs of Aboriginals generally or a particular community of Aboriginals and includes any such traditions, observances, customs or beliefs relating to particular persons, areas, objects or relationships'.

But this definition does not require that tradition or belief should have any religious or mystical basis whatsoever and any belief held by any group of Aborigines would apparently seem capable of forming part of Aboriginal tradition for the purposes of this Act. Frankly, this is a dubious definition.

I refer to sacred sites, a term not used in the legislation-I emphasise that point-but clearly one of the most important elements of the issue of land rights. A site may be declared sacred and may well be sacred while there are Aboriginals who believe that site is sacred, but with the effluxion of time and the loss of traditions we will probably reach the stage when subsequent generations will say: `That site was sacred to my ancestors' and the archaelogists may well say: `That site is an archaeological site of significance'. However, we are running the very real risk of presuming that a site is sacred indefinitely when there are no living communities in that vicinity which accept that the site does have that sacredness and traditional relevance to that community. Traditional relevance by itself is not necessarily an indication of sacredness. These are very important issues; they are issues which are often difficult for a Western educated person to fully grasp. If there is an attempt to put them into legislative form, it is the responsibility of a government to try to get it right. I am intrigued as to why this legislation, which talks about areas, does not mention the term `sacred sites'.

The legislation is opposed by the Opposition because it is also confrontationist. As I have said, the Minister has the power, in clause 9, to override State control, and such intervention by the Federal Minister would be an obstacle to consultation and resolution of sacred sites issues between Aboriginals and State governments. It serves to further confuse and complicate the procedures for achieving protection of areas and objects of particular significance to Aboriginal communities. The confusion and the conflict inherent in competing Federal, State and Territory heritage laws are obviously wasteful of both public and private resources and a further example of excessive government regulation. The competing interests of heritage protection and economic development are not going to pass; they are with us. The States, through their own legislative processes have achieved a modicum of success in facing this difficulty. Yet here we see the Commonwealth, by a back door, essentially by a political strategy, trying to apply at the eleventh hour the continuation of some Federal jurisdiction which, up to now, it has failed to apply in respect of a national approach to Aboriginal land rights.

The legislation has a far broader application than sacred sites as it relates to the protection of significant Aboriginal areas, but there is no definition in the Bill as to what an area really means. The Bill fails to define guidelines upon which the Minister is supposed to assess the significance of an area. Surely this is a dubious element of this legislation which the Minister has a duty to fully explain to this House. Under the legislation the Minister has the power to prohibit people from entering the land or to limit its use in a manner that amounts to acquisition; yet there is no proposal that the land be purchased by the Commonwealth and there is no proposal that compensation should be paid by the Commonwealth. However, the legislation does propose that it is the responsibility of the owner of that land to fence it, to protect it and to keep everybody else out; and, at the end of the day, he can say: `I have nothing. I have lost whatever economic usage I may have had for this land simply because this Commonwealth legislation has put the onus of protection on me and has left no responsibility on the Commonwealth'. Clearly, the compensation provisions underlined in the Constitution are real and if the Crown, through its government, wishes to reduce the capacity of individual or corporate citizens to utilise their land I think there is a responsibility on the government of the day to see that adequate compensation is paid.

There is no limit to the land that can be claimed under the legislation and, to this degree, it could be used as surrogate land rights legislation. I have emphasised that throughout my speech. I deeply believe that is the political purpose of the decision by this Minister to remove the sunset clause from the Bill.

The legislation also suffers from inadequate review procedures for ministerial declarations and the excessive discretionary powers which have been awarded to the Minister. The legislation applies to all land and there is no adequate protection of private interests. Surely this was an opportunity for the Government to let the interim Act expire, to make significant amendments to it or at least to have the decency to continue with the interim arrangements for a period of, say, another two years. None of those alternatives was seriously considered. As I said, for political reasons we are now debating this legislation for the second time.

The extension of the Bill has the potential to adversely affect all land owners including pastoralists, farmers, miners and even urban populations by depriving them of access to or use of their properties without, as I said, adequate compensation. It is important that the first attempt to use the Act, in the Harding River controversy, proved that the legislation was badly drawn and would result in great conflict. Western Australian Aboriginals placed an application under the Act to stop the construction of a $13m dam. The application was made when the dam was two-thirds completed-not at the beginning and not when the plans were prepared-which clearly demonstrated that the national interest had been ignored by those who proceeded to use this legislation clearly for political ends. At that stage the white advisers of the Aboriginal Legal Service complained on behalf of two of the tribes involved. The application was rejected by the Department as an application should have been made prior to construction reaching the stage of ultimate finality.

It is significant that the Act has engendered a number of frivolous and vexatious claims. These include the Stradbroke Island mining application of July 1984 by Judith Wright to stop small sand mining leases on an island that had already been extensively mined. The Daintree application was rejected because no significant site was under immediate threat or injury. An application was made to stop the Swan River boat ramp and gas pipeline due to the belief that a mythical serpent lived in a cave under the river. Fortunately this claim was also rejected. We can only be thankful that the Minister has rejected all but one of the applications and that the Minister has had only one opportunity to exercise his unfettered discretion-and even then it was rather dubious. The history of the Act raises further issues about the possibility of exploitation, particularly by white extremists as in the Harding River dam case. The extent of ministerial discretion is simply too great. It is not acceptable that persons potentially adversely affected by its application have no protection from the ministerial whim. It is significant that out of 21 applications made under the legislation all but one have been settled outside of a ministerial declaration. The one application that required a declaration was over the sale of sacred items at a Sotheby's auction in 1985. It is worth noting that of the collection, which would now be covered by the subsequent legislation, lot 198 was referred to by the Sotheby's gentleman as follows:
The Government should be better informed concerning the rarity of such items. Had it been so, it would not have mistakenly included an item from Vanuatu . . . in the injunction.

The Government's approach to the protection of Australia's heritage is therefore largely limited to rhetoric. It seems that it has great difficulty in having legislation which is effective and at the same time protects Australian States rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gayler Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) indicated in his second reading speech, the effect of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Amendment Bill will be to make permanent an interim scheme to protect the heritage of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. This will be achieved by repealing section 33 of the existing legislation, the sunset clause of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Act 1984. That legislation was introduced on an interim basis to preserve and protect places, areas and objects of particular significance to Aboriginals and for related purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe it is relevant to note that the Act does not interfere with the existing responsibilities of the State and Territory governments. Those governments have legislation which requires them to identify, record, research, interpret and manage Aboriginal sites. As the Minister indicated in his second reading speech, the recording of the location of Aboriginal sites is simply one step towards later possible decisions as to which sites are to be protected. The basis for such decisions in the Northern Territory, for example, has normally centred on issues relating to university research on Aboriginal matters, although on other occasions such decisions appear to have been based on the aesthetic and educative value of the site. This applies particularly to rock art sites.

There is a clear indication within our community that Aboriginals and Islanders want a commitment that areas and objects which are particularly significant to them will be preserved and protected. One important aspect of the legislation now under debate is that it provides a means whereby Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders can have decisions by State and Territory governments reviewed. The legislation gives the Commonwealth authority to bring affected parties together to conciliate, mediate and negotiate in order to remove the threat of injury to a significant Aboriginal area or object. Declarations are needed only where such mediation fails to resolve the problem of a threat. A scrutiny of the provisions of the existing legislation, particularly sections 9 and 10, shows that they are clear in their intent: The declarations can be made by the Minister only where he is satisfied that either the area or the object is a significant one. I emphasise `significant'.

Without in any way suggesting that there are weaknesses within the legislation as it now exists, it is important to note that during the period of almost two years that it has been in existence it has not been necessary to make any declarations in respect of areas. However, the Minister has on one occasion used such a declaration in relation to significant objects. Notwithstanding that on 21 June 1985 the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs made a declaration in respect of a number of significant Aboriginal objects which were held by Sotheby's of Sydney for the purpose of sale by auction, negotiations continued between the auctioneer and the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council and subsequently on 29 July, some six weeks later, the New South Wales Aboriginal Land Council confirmed that it had acquired the objects. The fact that this issue was satisfactorily resolved, as was the case with many other applications, is clear evidence that the legislation is generally operating satisfactorily. To date 21 applications have been made under the provisions of the legislation. Seventeen of the applications sought protection for significant areas perceived as being under threat of desecration; two related to the protection of skeletal remains and sought the return of those remains to the Aboriginal community; and the final two sought protection of significant objects. The issue to which I have already referred is the only action on which the Minister found it necessary to make a declaration.

When this legislation first came before the House back in May 1984 strong objection was taken to it by such organisations as the Australian Mining Industry Council, the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association. They were supported in their objection quite strenuously by many of those opposite. It is interesting to note in hindsight some of the observations made in May 1984 by members of the National Party of Australia. I quote from Hansard what the shadow spokesman for Aboriginal affairs at the time, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), said in this House:

The next question is what area of land can the Minister declare under this legislation. In fact he can use this Bill as if it were land rights legislation and make a declaration as to unlimited areas of land within Australia.
He went on further to say:
Not only is all land claimable under this legislation but there is no limit on the amount of land that can be claimed.

Of course it has been shown since that Aboriginal and Islander people are responsible in making applications under the legislation and that the Minister in his role has been likewise responsible in assessing whether the criterion of significance to Aboriginals has been made out, and that is important in this regard as the key aspect of this legislation is the criterion of significance to Aboriginals rather than to other sectors of the community.

So the predictions of gloom cast over this legislation by the honourable member for Barker at the time of its introduction into the House have not eventuated, but if the rantings of the honourable member have been proved to have no base, they pale into insignificance compared to the comments made by none other than the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Hunt) during that same debate. The Deputy Leader of the National Party made reference to the legislation in the following terms:

The draconian provisions in this legislation vest in the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs extraordinary powers over the property rights of Australian citizens and in this society they are precious and important rights. These property rights range from a farm to a suburban allotment to a mine on a mining tenement. This legislation has the potential to inflame racial differences between Australians, black and white, and in certain areas could cause a racial backlash against Aboriginal people.
He went on further to say:
This legislation affects or could affect many Australians. I believe it is an attack on our most cherished democratic right; that is, the property right of people.

This legislation is riddled with blatant attacks on the rights of Australian people. The powers of the Minister to make declarations on sites and objects are retrospective. He is unfettered in applying these powers to existing farmland--
the farms come in for special mention again-
farm buildings, mines and all other objects on any land.

Now that the assumptions raised by so many of those opposite in the initial debate have been shown to be totally baseless, as a matter of fairness they should support the Bill before the House. Nowhere in Australia has farmland been affected, mining properties resumed or houses repossessed, and in fact no claim has been either made or acknowledged on the Melbourne Cricket Ground or the Sydney Opera House, as was adverted to at the time by another honourable member opposite, the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite).

The value of such legislation-that is, the reserve power in the Commonwealth-is readily apparent. A number of States have commenced reviewing their legislation and determination of matters such as how decisions on protection and management are taken. Aboriginal communities themselves are considering with greater care what is to be preserved and why, and are in a responsible manner seeking to extend these matters in a way which conveys wide respect and will gain support in our community. The preservation and protection of significant Aboriginal areas and objects, as now formally recognised, is a response to the views of many parts of the community and not simply the view of the Government. This legislation will allow for reasonable, rational and responsible implementation of such a process.

In conclusion, I make reference to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). It is clear from the tenor of his contribution to this debate that those opposite would not be in favour of implementing any legislation whatsoever if they were ever to be in government to protect the rights of Aboriginals. It is another indication of their stepping back from their responsibilities. The previous speaker, in speaking at such length in relation to possible amendments when it was quite clear that the Opposition would not introduce amendments, was trying only to mislead the Aboriginal community. As I said, it is interesting to note, and it should be placed on the record, that those opposite see no reason for such legislation. I believe that they are to be condemned for taking such an approach. It is with pleasure and with no hesitation that I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maher Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are dealing with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage (Interim Protection) Amendment Bill. Several years ago in this House we had an extensive debate on the original Bill, which contained a sunset provision. Tonight the House has heard from other speakers, particularly from the honourable member for Leichhardt (Mr Gayler), on the workings of this interim legislation and how only one order was ever made under the legislation, and how that order was to protect certain Aboriginal historical items and artefacts that were coming up for auction in Sydney. I feel it is quite significant that all of the hysteria that came forth in the original debate some years ago was proved to be wrong; that there were no outrageous, mischievous and nuisance claims or allegations. In fact, the legislation has worked very well.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight the Bill is being debated so that it can become a permanent piece of legislation to give the Minister responsibility for protecting items that are of great historical significance to Aboriginal Australians and items that are irreplaceable. I was sorry to hear the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), who led for the Opposition, say that the States could cover this area. This legislation before the House tonight is certainly in the nature of an appeal court; it sets up an appeal court where the Aboriginal community can take their complaints if they are not happy with what the States are doing. There have been, as the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) said in his second reading speech, a number of instances where Aboriginal communities have come to the Federal Government and there has been negotiation.

Various complaints have been handed to me and I have copies of them. The Albury and District Aboriginal Land Council sought protection of a burial site near Albury. That burial site was to be used as a quarry. Any Australian who knew that his forebears were buried in a certain area, perhaps in an old cemetery, and who heard that the cemetery was to be bulldozed and turned into some sort of sporting arena or something like that would complain and object. Why should not Aboriginal Australians come forward and complain to ensure that their burial sites, perhaps where their forebears have been for hundreds if not thousands of years, are buried, reserved as important areas for them? The Opposition says that the whole issue should be left to the States.

On 27 May 1967 the Australian people in a rather extraordinary and overwhelming fashion gave the Commonwealth jurisdiction over all Aboriginal affairs. Much to the surprise of everyone who had been involved in public life at that time a referendum was passed. The feeling was that the Australian people would vote against anything put up to them. On that occasion two questions were put to the Australian people: One was to break the nexus between this House and the Senate, which was overwhelmingly rejected. At the same referendum the Australian people voted to hand over all powers in constitutional matters, in all matters relating to Aborigines, to the Federal Government. Yet tonight we have the Opposition putting forward an extraordinarily weak argument that these matters should be looked after by the States. The Australian people have spoken on that issue, and let us have nothing further in that direction. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in his second reading speech has highlighted the actual nature of the legislation.

A key aspect of the legislation is the criterion of significance to Aboriginals rather than to other sectors of the community. The nature of the legislation is to give the Minister power to protect the areas and objects of particular significance to Aboriginals which are under threat of injury or desecration. It does not replace existing State or Territory laws, but is designed to be used where those laws are not providing--

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Tamils in Sri Lanka-Indonesia-Leisure Coast Tourist Association-Rural Australia-Mr Rodney Groux-Availability of Unemployment Benefits-Western Australian Fire Brigade: Occupational Health and Safety Measures-RAAF Guard Dog-Irian Jaya

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Recently a document was delivered not only to my office but also to all offices of members of this Parliament. I might say that it is quite a scurrilous document and one in which I figure quite prominently, as do my colleagues the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) and the honourable member for Lowe (Mr Maher). Why, might I ask, do we three members figure quite prominently in this document? It is because we have had the audacity to stand up and talk for a persecuted and a tortured minority in the world today. That minority is the Tamils of Sri Lanka. The three of us have spoken up on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Surprisingly, a group in Queensland-a very shadowy and strange group, I might say-called the Queensland Association for Sri Lankan Unity has taken offence at what the honourable member for Lowe, the honourable member for Hotham and I have said. The members of this group, I suppose at great expense to themselves, have produced this document. One might well ask where the funding came from to produce this document in which the three of us figure quite prominently. In the document the group talks about the coverage that the Tamil minority receives in this country and hints that the Tamils are being very well funded. If the Tamil minority had been so well funded and had received wide publicity, there would be no need for members of this House to draw attention to the denial of human rights and the atrocities that are being committed against these people.

I have never before had such attention devoted to any of my speeches in this House. Members of this group have gone through various adjournment speeches I have made. They have actually analysed them. They have also republished some correspondence I exchanged with them. They have very selectively quoted from my speeches, as they have selectively quoted what I wrote to them. If honourable members care to look at copies of Hansard they will see that when I speak on the Tamil situation I always say that I will always condemn violence wherever it occurs and will always speak up against the denial of human rights, whoever may be denying them. The members of this group did not bother mentioning that in this document. They also seemed to take offence at something I said when I called on the Sri Lankan High Commission to stop its stooges-I repeat, to stop its stooges-photographing Tamil people protesting against the denial of human rights in Sri Lanka. They ask where this has occurred. I will tell them where it has occurred. It has occurred at the last three meetings of the Australian Labor Party at annual conferences in Sydney, at which I have organised Tamil groups to hand out literature. It did not happen last year because the preceding three years the stooges directed by the Sri Lankan High Commission here in Canberra had arranged for these people to be photographed. They were mostly students in this country. I do not know what the Sri Lankan High Commission does with these photographs, but they were probably sent back to Sri Lanka where these people have families. One may well ask what will be the fate of these families.

I repeat that this group quotes very selectively. It does not mention anyone who is in favour of the Sri Lankan Government, but it goes on to make a serious attack on Amnesty International. Many members of this House are members of the Parliamentary Group of Amnesty International. I find it outrageous that this shadowy group in Queensland should attack a world-wide organisation devoted to the protection of human rights in the way that it has. Far from silencing me, such attacks will only strengthen my resolve to continue to speak out for the persecuted minority-that is, the Tamil minority in Sri Lanka. Rather than silencing me, they have only strengthened my resolve to speak out, and I will continue to speak out while ever the denial of basic human rights continues in Sri Lanka.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are living in most difficult times. I feel constrained to speak tonight in this Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia and to make the comment that, in view of recent events, there is no doubt in my mind that Indonesia regards our current Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as a 1986 version of Neville Chamberlain. For some ten years in this Parliament I have warned and warned again that a policy of appeasement of Indonesia will not work. I believe our Prime Minister and the Government must now clearly understand that a policy of appeasement of Indonesia will not work and that he who licks the boots eventually and inevitably gets kicked in the face.

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister's outrage over current issues is most commendable. I refer specifically to the outrageous action of Indonesia in cancelling the tourist visas of Australians who were scheduled to travel to Bali last week and the more recent action of the Indonesian Government within the last 24 hours of refusing entry to Indonesia of two Australian-born but Washington-based reporters travelling with the Press entourage of President Reagan. Whilst I concede that the Prime Minister's outrage over current issues is most commendable, I must ask rhetorically: Where was his outrage over the slaughter of over 150,000 innocent East Timorese by Indonesian military butchers, right on Australia's back doorstep, less than half an hour's flying time by military aircraft from Darwin?

I believe the Prime Minister must now demand that Indonesian strongman, the armed force commander, General Benny Murdani, unequivocally withdraw his provocative statement that Indonesia would certainly take further retaliatory steps in reaction to the Sydney Morning Herald article. For the information of the Prime Minister and of the House I now refer to a report which appeared in the Straits Times, a Singapore newspaper, of 22 April. The remarks of General Murdani are found in an article by Yang Razali Kassim, the Jakarta correspondent of the Straits Times. The heading reads: `Row over Sydney Morning Herald articles-Murdani blasts Aussie paper'. The story is by Yang Razali Kassim, Jakarta correspondent, and was filed in Jakarta. I will read the article to the point which I think will emphasise how serious the situation has now become. It reads:
Armed forces commander General Benny Murdani has broken his silence to condemn the Sydney Morning Herald for interfering in the internal affairs of Indonesia.
Press reports quoted the tough-talking military chief as saying that `we are deeply hurt and very offended' by the Herald's articles which alleged corruption by President Suharto.
Mr Deputy Speaker, the next words are important:
The general confirmed--
I repeat that this article is dated 22 April--
that Indonesia `would certainly' take further retaliatory steps in reaction to the offending articles. The reports did not elaborate.

General Murdani issued his broadside while attending a military ceremony in Yogyakarta, a city that in 1948 had to be heavily defended by the army of the then infant Indonesian Republic against a Dutch attempt to retake the country.
The general described the Herald's articles as a smear campaign against the head of state and his family.
Mr Deputy Speaker, listen to these words:

Comparing this attempt to the Dutch attack, Gen. Murdani said: `As in the case of 1948, the Indonesian armed forces also feel obliged to defend the honour of the Indonesian head of state and his family'.

So General Murdani is telling the Press of Asia-the Straits Times, one of the most reputable in Asia-that the armed forces of Indonesia stand by, as in 1948, to defend the honour of the Indonesian head of state and his family. If I or any other Australian were to ignore remarks such as those made by General Benny Murdani, strong man of Indonesia and chief of the armed forces, we would do so at our peril and at the peril of the defence of this nation. I think that is a most provocative statement. I call on the Prime Minister of Australia to stand up for this country and demand that General Murdani unequivocally withdraw his remarks and apologise for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Wednesday evening it was my pleasure to attend the annual general meeting of the Leisure Coast Tourist Association Ltd in Wollongong. Tonight, I am very pleased to be able to sing the praises of that organisation, which over the last three years has gone a great deal of the way to ensuring that the tourist potential of the Illawarra region has been recognised not only within the Illawarra but also in the wider sphere. It has also been a driving force behind stimulating the development of tourist activities on the coast, as my friend the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) would no doubt attest. In fact, 1985 has seen the consolidation of the activities of the Leisure Coast Tourist Association. About 1.5m people visited the Leisure Coast during that year and spent something like $150m. The visitors Information Centre located in Wollongong recorded over 54,000 counter inquiries and something like 17,800 telephone inquiries during that year, which represents about a 20 per cent increase over the figures for 1984. Interestingly, it has also been shown that during 1985 the promotion of Wollongong as a conference centre has been most successful. Conference business increased by about 10 per cent over the 1984 figures. Accommodation figures supplied by the Australian Bureau of Statistics clearly indicate a very healthy increase of about 51 per cent for the Leisure Coast in the 1984-85 fiscal year.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite clearly the promotion of the Illawarra region by this organisation has been most spectacular and has been helped by the development of a number of major tourist activities during 1985. I refer also to those that will commence in 1986. Some $3m worth of development is being carried out on the Wollongong Surf Leisure Resort, which is in my electorate. Extensions to Blackbutt Motel in the electorate of the honourable member for Throsby will amount to half a million dollars. The sum of $50,000 is being spent on the Open Hearth Hotel redevelopment at Warrawong. The Macarthur Estate Winery, again within my electorate, is being developed at a cost of $0.5m. Onkel Toms Hutte at Jamberoo, again in the electorate of my friend the honourable member for Throsby, is spending $750,000. That has all happened during 1985. During 1986 we will see the redevelopment of the Fisherman's Co-operative at Belmore Basin at a cost of $1.5m, the development of the Kiama Harbour Side Hotel at a cost of $3.5m,. and Easts Beach Motel in Kiama at a cost of $4.5m. The redevelopment of the Centre Plaza in Crown Street, Wollongong, will cost $4.5m, and so it goes on.

Quite clearly, these figures demonstrate that the tourist industry in the South Coast is being well and truly serviced by an influx of capital development, catering purely for tourists who come on day trips from the local area and for those who want to come to the South Coast for an extended period to take advantage of all the marvellous attractions there. We will probably see during the coming year that the facilities that are being developed will increase the attractiveness of our area.

In order to promote the area, the Leisure Coast Tourist Association is planning a great number of tourist promotions during 1986. I draw the attention of the House to the fact that during this year there will be an exhibition at Woden Square in Canberra showing all the activities and the various tourist facilities available on the Leisure Coast. I certainly ask all honourable members to take the opportunity to go along and have a look at that exhibition. For so long the image of the Illawarra region has been somewhat detrimental to encouraging tourists and visitors to go there. In recent times we have seen that this has gone well and truly by the board. People who come there see the great benefits of the area.

I would like particularly to pay tribute to the Chairman of the Association, Mr Harold Hanson, and his hard working committee members; to the Wollongong City Council, which contributes annually $90,000 for the ongoing costs associated with this Association; and, of course, to all the various local government representatives. Shellharbour Municipal Council has also contributed in a monetary sense, as has Kiama Municipal Council. I pay tribute to all the hard working people on the Association from right across the spectrum of local government representatives, those from private industry and those associated with the tourist industry itself.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the local member.
—Of course, the local members must also be congratulated for their ongoing support for this august body. That has been clearly demonstrated in this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hicks Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is more with sadness than with anger that I rise to speak about the statement on economic and rural policy presented by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) on Tuesday, 15 April. If the Government was ignorant of what is happening in rural Australia I could understand, but not excuse, the Minister for putting out such a policy. But it is not ignorant of the problems and this makes its digressions unforgivable. This Government is prepared to sacrifice rural Australia on the altar of its misguided monetary policy and its need to keep the iniquitous so-called accord in place. In other words, it is willing to consider as its constituents only the Australian Council of Trade Unions. It leaves the rest of the population, including farmers, small business people and those who depend on those groups for a living, to shoulder the load of Government mismanagement on their own.

SPEECH.PARA: I followed the self-congratulatory though misguided statement of the Minister through its 42 pages. Out of that, only a few paragraphs would have been of interest to rural Australia. Rural Australia is where Australia traditionally gained its character of toughness, resilience and honesty and the code of mateship which means caring for one's neighbour. Obviously, these characteristics have not passed on to the Government of the day.

I know that most people in rural Australia are proud people who do not lightly let others know of their problems. But I am sure they will not mind if today I put their cases before the Parliament to show how useless are these latest measures by which the Government will return to them $110m-and take five years to do it-from the $444m that has been taken from them since this Government came to office.

Let us look at the first case, which occurred in the Coleambally irrigation area, an area that has been built on hard work and enterprise by many dedicated farmers. I will quote from a letter forwarded by a bank to a young enterprising farmer in the area. It is typical of some of the letters that are being received. It states:
I am the Solicitor for the . . .-
it names the bank-

and I have been instructed to write to you in connection with your failure to comply with the terms of the above notice. I am now to take the legal action necessary to obtain vacant possession of the property being . . .
it names the property-
and then to submit same for sale at public auction.

You are therefore given notice that unless you quit and deliver up possession of the property within 14 days of the date hereof, steps will be taken to have you ejected according to law. I would warn you against removing or in any way interfering with fixtures or fittings on the property as the Bank is entitled to same under and by virtue of its mortgage.
The keys of the dwelling should be handed to the Manager of the Bank's . . .

It then names the branch. How many members of the Government who have young families have received an eviction notice to quit a property that has taken years of their parents' and their own toil to obtain? I will bet that not many of these Bollinger socialists have been in that position. Prior to receiving this notice, the young farmer had written to the Minister asking for help. In his reply the Minister blamed everything except the Government's heavy taxes and charges and its artificially propped up interest rates. I wonder how impressed my friend in Coleambally is with the latest 42-page statement by the Minister.

Another young couple north of Griffith who are in financial trouble approached me and asked for assistance. They had been turned down by the Rural Assistance Board and were very depressed. It took me a few weeks to investigate the situation and when I rang them back I was saddened to find that they had already been forced off the farm.

Then there is the farmer who was developing a mixed farming property in Yenda. This man and his wife are noted as efficient and capable farmers who had responsibly planned their finances. Along came this present Government's high interest rates and we now find that this family cannot meet the interest payments. One son at university has had to return home to seek work and it is doubtful whether the younger children at home will be able to continue to Higher School Certificate level.

Another case is of a young Victorian couple who came to the irrigation area full of hope and endeavour with $200,000 to invest. They acquired an irrigation property and planted a crop. Unfortunately, the crop failed and then along came this Government with high interest rates. The wife now lives in town with the two children and works part time to pay for food. The husband hardly leaves the property, working from daylight to dark. The debt is now greater than the $200,000 with which they started. Although farm has been up for auction, there have been no bidders. The interest rate is accumulating and the couple's health is deteriorating. They have nowhere to turn. Imagine how the farmers south of Nyngan who are presently receiving food parcels must feel as they sit reading the Minister's 42-page statement. I am certain that they would not gain any comfort either.

Last Sunday I visited a wine grape grower who for some years has been gradually trying to develop his property. This young man, his wife and four children and the whole family have worked on the property. Because of a downturn in the price of grapes and other commodities that he was growing, the farm has run into financial difficulty, but the main cause of the problem is this Government's high interest rates on his mortgage payments for the block. This farmer works wherever and whenever he can. His wife has worked in the field beside him and knows every vine planted. She has had hardly left the block in the last six months because the family cannot afford the fuel for their old vehicle-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honour- able members should be aware from the outset that this is a tragic human situation. I first came into contact with Mr Rodney Groux, a constituent of mine, in August 1983 when I was the member of the House of Representatives for Diamond Valley, when he phoned my office for help. At that stage his life had been threatened by some people whom I presume he had informed upon. The people who issued the threats were never detected. He was under 24-hour police protection at his house because of his involvement as a crown witness in the royal commission into the meat substitution racket. He was destitute, having lost jobs since that time because there were people who were content to make sure that he never worked again and hence drive him into financial ruin. His telephone had been disconnected because obviously without money he could not pay the bill. I checked out his story with the Australian Federal Police and was able to arrange for his phone to be reconnected, mainly for security reasons, if nothing else.

SPEECH.PARA: I obtained for Mr Groux his rights from the Department of Social Security and gave him some money from my own electoral allowance to put some food in his cupboard. At that stage his wife was pregnant and he had a young son who was one or two years of age, so he was in a desperate situation. Over a considerable period, with a lot of work by my staff and me, we were able to help him to regain some security and stability in his life. I believe we did no more than an ordinary representative in this House would do, in trying to protect and help their constituents as much as possible. We gave him some money on other occasions when the demand was very great.

I believe that Mr Groux was very seriously disadvantaged in not being able to obtain a livelihood because of his service to the Crown as witness. I wrote to the Government to see whether it could find some way in which it could help this person to find a job which would be secure from outside interference. Obviously every person needs work to maintain himself and his family, and Mr Groux was certainly in that category. In order to help Mr Groux to regain some of his self-esteem and because he wanted to help, on some occasions we allowed him to work in the office. He felt very obliged to me in that respect.

Over time, unfortunately, despite his well intentioned sincerity, he made continual promises to me about a variety of things, such as reading or writing things for me, but they were very rarely fulfilled. The organisation of parcels of food for poor people in the electorate was one such promise which was never fulfilled. That subsequently led me to question his reliability-not that I doubted his sincerity in what he wanted to achieve, but he was unable to deliver it properly. On every occasion, the people around Mr Groux and the people in this Government have tried very hard to help this person who was in trouble through no fault of his own but because of his role as a crown witness helping the Government and the people of Australia. As I have said, this is a tragic case. His behaviour subsequently is really a matter for separate consideration. This is a tragic case made even more tragic by the predilection of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) for crawling in sewers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burr Mr M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received what I consider to be a disturbing letter-it is disturbing to me-from Mrs Jennifer Willans who is the Secretary of the St Mary's District High School Parent and Friends Association. I point out that St Marys is a small township with a population of about 1,500 on the east coast of Tasmania and about 150 kilometres east of Launceston. I think the crux of the concern of Mrs Willans and her association is summed up in the first paragraph of her letter, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Our Association is concerned about the opportunities for our students to continue their education beyond Grade 10 and the disincentive that the availability of unemployed benefits has on encouraging young people to pursue their education.

I point out that the St Mary's District High School offers courses only to Grade 10 and if students wish to pursue their education beyond that they must then go to Launceston to pursue Grades 11 or 12 or go to a technical and further education college and pursue a technical course. The parents at St Marys are very concerned that the availability of the unemployment benefit is acting as a disincentive for the young people in that district to pursue their further education opportunities. Further in the letter Mrs Willans points out:
Fifty nine students left school at the end of 1985. Of these students, only 12 have proceeded to senior secondary or T.A.F.E. colleges.
She points out further:
Twenty three students (40 per cent) are unemployed and receiving unemployment benefits.

I point out that this is in a depressed rural area where there are very few employment opportunities. What Mrs Willans and her association are trying to point out to me, to the Government and, through this speech, to the House, is that we must recognise that the availability of the unemployment benefit is a positive disincentive for young people to continue with their education opportunities, whether they live in country areas or whether they live in city areas. The fact that young people, at the conclusion of Grade 10, have the opportunity to apply for and receive the unemployment benefit must be a disincentive for them to pursue further education opportunities no matter where they live in Australia.

I think all honourable members in this House should be big enough in their minds to recognise that this is terribly detrimental to the future prospects of this country. We all should recognise that if we are to progress in this country and if we are to develop the skills that are available in this country, we must fully develop the educational capabilities of our young people. It is essential that we use every possible opportunity to encourage young people to pursue their education to the maximum extent of their abilities.

We have great difficulties in persuading young people in country areas of Tasmania because not only is there a lack of opportunities available in their local district but also there are difficulties in their going out of their local area and living away from home which, at times, presents a great financial burden to their parents, in order for them to pursue their further education opportunities. On the other side of the coin, constantly available to these young people and to their parents, many of whom are experiencing difficult economic times, is the unemployment benefit. It is very easy for those young people, in some cases with encouragement from their parents, to go along and apply for social welfare, receive it and have no prospect of pursuing their educational capabilities. This is particularly so in depressed areas where there is little prospect of their finding useful employment.
In the last paragraph of Mrs Willans's letter she gives us food for thought when she says:

Our Association believes that serious consideration should be given to making an allowance similar to unemployment benefits available to all students after grade 10 or alternatively, raising the age from which unemployment benefits can be received.

I am aware of the budgetary problems that the Government faces and the impossibility of broadening the availability of the unemployment benefit, but I believe we all have a responsibility to acknowledge the second point that Mrs Willans raises and that is raising the age at which young people can apply for the unemployment benefit and therefore giving them more incentive to pursue education.
