SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charlesworth Dr R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a pleasure for me last week to visit the Western Australian Fire Brigade and present the 1985 Workfit Award for Western Australia. The award was established in 1982 in conjunction with Rydge Publications and the Commonwealth Department of Health and it recognises the efforts of those organisations which have a real concern for the health and wellbeing of their employees. Employee health is an important issue and those who run businesses should realise that it can be to their benefit to pay attention to employee health. The major causes of ill health in our population and, indeed, in our work force are largely preventable. The work place provides a unique opportunity for health promotion delivery. I am glad to say that the Western Australian Fire Brigade has taken the opportunity to provide that sort of assistance to its employees. The benefits of this are significant. There is increased staff morale, reduced absenteeism and an increase in productivity and efficiency of the employees.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government is aware of the preventive role in health and it has established the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission as a statutory body. Our hard working Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), who is at the table, was also responsible for the initiation of the Better Health Commission which will report on the major preventable health problems in the Australian community and will suggest strategies to reduce illness caused by these problems. Indeed, this Government recognises for the first time the role of prevention.

The Western Australian Fire Brigade has had an integrated approach for improving the health and welfare of its employees for a number of years. It pays attention to two particular aspects of the working environment-work place safety and the health and fitness of its employees. Not only must firemen be very fit to fulfil their tasks but office staff, administrative and ancillary staff are also involved in the program. The Brigade employs a full time fitness officer, Mr Rob Pickard, and his work has led to the Brigade's success in the award. The Fire Brigade provides first class facilities and it has initiated lectures on diet, lifestyle and other aspects of health and fitness. Other features of the program include the repetition strain injury prevention program for typists and keyboard operators and the counselling services which are provided in conjunction with the union, to which employees can take their problems. I take this opportunity to congratulate the Western Australian Fire Brigade for winning the award for the third successive year.

While I am talking about preventative measures, perhaps I should mention the enlightened approach of the Western Australian Government in its smoking and health policy. On 28 April that Government launched its third `Quit' program which will be co-ordinated by the Western Australian Health Department's smoking and health project group. This program will take five weeks and it will encourage improvement of the health status of Western Australians by giving up smoking. Over the past two years 50,000 Western Australians have quit smoking as a result of this program. Of course smoking is the major preventable cause of disease, morbidity and mortality in this nation and it is implicated in the premature deaths of 12,000 Western Australians annually. Yet 25 per cent of smokers still believe that their habit causes no illness or harm. I might add that the news media-the Press, radio and television-will be involved in this program but it is not possible to beat people over the head to convince them of the benefits of giving up smoking. However, we can provide the sophisticated sales and promotion techniques of the cigarette companies and I believe that this program does so. I congratulate the Western Australian Government. No doubt the `Quit' program for this year will be even more successful than it has been in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In September and October 1985 the fate of the Royal Australian Air Force german shepherd guard dog named Sheriff captured the imagination of the public of Victoria. The matter was raised on a number of occasions in the Parliament. Now, several months later, I have a number of questions to ask of the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) regarding the present state of Sheriff. I last spoke on this matter on 9 October last year. In my adjournment speech I warned the Government that if the so called inquiry that had just been announced by the Minister for Defence was nothing more than a sham, the matter again would be raised in the Parliament. Sadly, that so called inquiry by which the Minister sought to allay the fears of hundreds, if not thousands, of people amounted to nothing more than a sham.

SPEECH.PARA: I wrote to the Minister for Defence on 29 October and asked him a series of questions about who participated in the inquiry, the terms of reference of the inquiry, who gave evidence to it, and whether Mr Brendan Prendergast, the handler of Sheriff, or his family had the opportunity to put forward independent advice or even expert evidence. The reply received from the Minister on 12 November simply said that it was not appropriate to conduct an inquiry along the lines I had suggested and that instead it was an internal RAAF matter. I predicted on 9 October 1985 that if the Minister only asked the RAAF for advice on the fate of Sheriff, I could tell him what advice he would receive because it would be the same as I had been receiving for several weeks, that is, that the dog could not be released into the care of Brendan Prendergast on his leaving the RAAF. However, that matter belongs to the past. We know that whatever the cynicism and dishonesty of the Minister-

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member knows that he cannot say that.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I withdraw the words `dishonesty of the Minister'. Nonetheless, the cynicism and political opportunism of the Minister meant that the dog Sheriff was not put to sleep but was unable to be released into the care of Brendan Prendergast. I now ask the Minister: What is the location of the dog Sheriff? What are the plans for his future? What deprogramming has been initiated in regard to Sheriff? In what manner is he used at present? Who is handling the dog? I ask these questions because of the concern of Brendan Prendergast and his family as to the present fate of the dog Sheriff. It is difficult to get any information in regard to the dog's fate. It must be remembered that a large number of people are concerned about the fate of the dog.

SPEECH.PARA: I have one further question: How was the dog Sheriff transported to his present location? I am advised that a Hercules aircraft was especially sent to the Sale RAAF base to transport the dog to Toowoomba. I would be pleased to know from the Minister whether or not such an expensive form of transport was provided. I ask these questions because the Government realises the depth of feeling in regard to the fate of this dog and the emotions it has stirred up. It has been at pains all along to act only with an eye to the political repercussions of the matter rather than with any genuine interest in the fate of the dog or in the feelings of his handler, Brendan Prendergast. I would be grateful if the Minister would address himself to these questions and provide me with a comprehensive statement as to the location, fate and plans for the dog Sheriff so that I am able to advise not only my constituent Brendan Prendergast but also the great many Gippslanders and those further afield who still remain vitally interested in this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kent Mr L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night, in an adjournment speech, my colleague the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Charles) used his five minutes to attack Mr Mark Baker, a journalist from the Melbourne Age. As my name was brought into the matter, let me say that Mr Charles's statement was somewhat inaccurate and most unjust, as, to my knowledge, Mr Baker's reports were accurate. To put the record straight, I wish to state that I have a high regard for Mr Baker's integrity and I regret the unprovoked and unjust attack on him by my colleague.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I would now like to turn to the fact that from time to time honourable members on both sides of the House rise during adjournment debates to criticise-and rightly so-the human rights situation in the Soviet Union, 15,000 miles away. I rise today to draw the attention of the House to human rights violations only a couple of hundred miles from our border, in West New Guinea, now called Irian Jaya. It seems odd to me that while so many of our members are so eager to raise their voices in response to human rights violations in countries far from us, so few are willing to protest against the cultural genocide being committed against the Melanesian population in Irian Jaya by the Indonesian Government.

As a member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence I visited Papua New Guinea last week. When the report of the Committee is tabled in this House, I certainly intend to voice my opinion about events which occurred on our visit. However, as an individual member of this Parliament, I am bound by my conscience to raise the plight of Melanesian refugees from West New Guinea at the first opportunity. There are more than 10,000 refugees in camps in Papua New Guinea who fled because of the brutality of the Indonesians. Until now, many of my colleagues have been delighted to refer to those thousands of people as `boarder crossers'. It amazes me that the same colleagues of mine do not call the Afghan tribesmen who crossed into Pakistan `border crossers'. They call them-quite rightly-refugees. Yet, when it comes to the unfortunate Melanesians, whose very existence is threatened by the Indonesians, they are referred to as `border crossers' to appease the Indonesian Government.

We visited two camps on the Indonesian border and I spoke to the so-called `border crossers'. Let me assure the House that they are not some wandering tribesman, but villagers-men, women and children-who abandoned their meagre possessions and ran for their lives from Indonesian brutality. They are refugees alright. They are the product of Indonesian brutality and the Javanese transmigration. The Indonesian Government embarked on a policy to transfer hundreds of thousands of Javanese into West New Guinea so that they will outnumber the indigenous Melanesian population in a few years. The Javanese are taking over the land that has been inhabited by the Melanesians for generations, without any provision for compensation by the Indonesian Government.

The Indonesians completely disregard the Melanesian culture and traditions. The indigenous population, the Melanesians, regard the land as a communal possessing which provides insurance for the survival of present and future generations. The land also links them with their ancestors and is part of their daily life. To deprive them of their land is to deprive them of their past as well as of their future. To forcibly break the Melanesians' ties with their land is an act of cultural genocide against them. The transmigration program is actually the Javanese colonisation of West New Guinea, and together with the brutal oppression of Melanesians by the military and the police, it is the main reason why these people have had to abandon their serene way of life and flee across the border to Papua New Guinea.

It is obvious that, as long as Indonesia persists with its policy of colonisation of West New Guniea and the oppression of the indigenous Melanesian population, we will have a growing refugee problem right on our borders. It will also create tensions between Indonesia and Papua New Guinea. However, I reject the contention that the problem is basically one for Indonesia and Papua New Guinea to resolve alone.

When human rights violations occur, it is the duty of the civilised countries-and we count ourselves amongst them-to speak out and protest against it. It is time that we showed more concern for the fate of our fellow human beings in West Irian, no matter what colour their skin is, and that we raise our concern, firstly with the Indonesian Government, and, if necessary, in world fora so that pressure is brought on the Suharto regime to respect human rights and stop the cultural genocide of the Melanesian people in West New Guinea.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 March 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there an absence of tax concessions to persons who are financially supporting elderly parents or relatives in nursing homes and does this represent the Government's policy.

(2) Has his attention been drawn to a form of blackmail which sometimes applies whereby people who are financially supporting elderly parents or relatives are advised that those people in care will be evicted unless payments in addition to the nursing home benefits are met; if so, what steps can the Government take to alleviate the situation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are at present two taxation provisions providing assistance to persons who are financially supporting elderly parents or relatives. These are the invalid relative rebate and the parent rebate. For 1985-86 the maximum value of these rebates is set at $376 and $749 per annum respectively.

An invalid relative rebate is payable in respect of a person who is 16 years of age or more and who is a child (including a step-child, adopted or illegitimate child), brother or sister of the taxpayer and who is in receipt of an invalid pension (or equivalent rehabilitation allowance) or certified permanently incapacitated.
For the purposes of the parent rebate the definition of parent is taken to cover the parents of the taxpayer or the taxpayer's spouse and includes the parents of a de facto spouse.

As in the application of all dependent rebates, the actual value of these rebates is reduced where in a particular case the separate net income of the dependent person exceeds $282 per annum including, generally, income from social security pensions.

I would also point out that substantial assistance is provided by the Government on the outlays side of the Budget in respect of the elderly and infirm and those residing in nursing homes (eg age and invalid pensions, domiciliary nursing care benefits and the Commonwealth nursing home benefit mentioned below).
(2) In relation to this part of the honourable member's question I have sought advice from my colleague, the Minister for Community Services, who has provided the following response:

``All patients are required to pay at least a statutory minimum patient contribution towards the cost of their nursing home care, in addition to the amount of nursing home benefit. This statutory minimum patient contribution is equivalent to 87 1/2 per cent of the sum of the maximum single rate pension plus supplementary assistance.

To ensure that patients retain the benefit of the Commonwealth nursing home benefit, and to prevent proprietors charging unwarranted levels of fees, the Commonwealth has, since 1973, been approving the scale of fees to be charged patients.

Nursing home fees generally reflect the cost structures of individual nursing homes. Where an individual nursing home's fees are in excess of the sum of the statutory patient contribution plus the maximum Commonwealth nursing home benefit, the patient is responsible for meeting the excess.

Individual cases where patients are being unduly pressured, or where fees in excess of the approved scales are being charged, should be brought to the attention of the State Offices of the Department of Community Services.''

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 14 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are there any rules or criteria covering the provision of discount air fares for groups such as sporting teams; if so, who (a) established the rules, and (b) polices them.
(2) What role has the Independent Air Fares Committee had in the matter.
(3) Has the Committee been or is it contemplating becoming involved in the issue; if so, in what way.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Prior to the establishment of the Independent Air Fares Committee (IAFC) in 1981, the Minister was responsible for approving all domestic air fares and associated conditions. Since its establishment in 1981, the IAFC has been the sole Commonwealth authority responsible for air fare approvals. Group fares for sporting and other groups introduced prior to 1981 were Ministerially approved fares. Late last year the IAFC approved common interest group fares which replaced the previous Ministerially approved discount fares for sporting and other groups.

(2) and (3) The present legislative arrangements governing domestic aviation were introduced in 1981 by the previous Government. The Independent Air Fares Committee Act 1981 gives responsibility for approving all commercial air fares and discounts to the IAFC. Under the provisions of the IAFC Act, the initiative rests with operators to propose discount fares for approval and the Committee is required to approve, or reject, a proposal in the form as submitted.
Before approving a request from an airline operator for a discount fare, the IAFC must be satisfied that
(a) The proposed discount fare is likely to improve the profitability of the operations of the applicant
(b) The proposed discount fare is unlikely to result in economy air fares of any trunk route operator being increased
(c) The proposed conditions (if any) are reasonable and will be applied without discrimination between persons or classes of persons who can comply with the conditions.

I understand that in July 1985, following receipt of legal advice to the effect that certain ministerially approved discount fares were no longer valid, the Committee requested Ansett and TAA to initiate action to bring the ministerially approved Apex and group fares within the provisions of the IAFC Act.

Both airlines took the opportunity to seek changes to the existing group fares and IAFC approval was given in December 1985 for the new terms and conditions for common interest group discount air fares.

The airlines have advised me that the new common interest group discount fares offer a number of advantages over the previous group discount fare, including for travel by sporting and charitable groups. In particular, the minimum number of passengers required to qualify for the group discounts has been reduced from 15 persons to 10.

While the fare previously available to sporting and charitable organisation officials travelling individually will no longer be available, there is now a greater range of discount fares available than at the time the previous group discount fares were introduced. The new discount fares, which include Apex, Flexi-Fare/Excursion 45 and standby, offer reductions of up to 45 per cent in the cost of air travel on the domestic airlines' networks. This means there is now greater opportunity for people to travel at substantially less than economy fares, particularly when they have advance knowledge of their travel requirements.
I have referred the representations I have received on this matter to TAA and Ansett for their consideration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Reserve Bank of Australia still require statistics of trading bank activities on a weekly basis; if so, do these statistics cover (a) overseas or offshore borrowings and (b) State bank as well as non-State bank offshore borrowings.
(2) What amount has been paid to overseas lenders, in addition to the original loan total, in the form of exchange rate adjustment in the 6 months to 30 November 1985.
(3) Is he able to say whether our trading banks are embarrassed financially by the fall in the value of the Australian dollar earlier in 1985.
(4) Does he expect interest rates to remain high until the trading banks have recouped any losses sustained as a result of dollar manipulation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Trading banks, including State banks, provide the Reserve Bank each week with a statement of their foreign currency assets and liabilities. Foreign currency liabilities include deposits by residents and non-residents, other borrowings and balances due to related corporations. Aggregate statistics are published monthly in the Reserve Bank Bulletin (Tables C7 and C8).

(2) The effect of depreciation of the Australian dollar on the $A cost to borrowers of repayment of foreign currency loans depends on many factors, including the extent of movement in the particular currency concerned and whether forward cover or other hedging has been taken out. The overseas lender receives the same amount of foreign currency he lent and therefore gains no additional receipt from depreciation of the $A.

(3) Australian banks have sizable assets in foreign currencies which substantially match their foreign currency liabilities. Their net exposure to potential loss (or gain) from currency fluctuations is therefore quite small. The Reserve Bank monitors the foreign currency exposures of the various banks.

(4) See answer to Question 3. The future course of interest rates depends on a wide range of factors, such as interest rates abroad, the Government's economic policies and general economic and financial conditions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 November 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there evidence of lower rates of price increases of products which have been subject to surveillance by the Prices Surveillance Authority, compared with products not subjected to surveillance.
(2) Can this evidence be quantified; if so, in what ways.
(3) Is there evidence that surveillance by the Prices Surveillance Authority has resulted in a lower rate of increase in prices than would have been the case in the absence of such surveillance.
(4) If so, what is the nature of that evidence and can it be quantified.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) There is no reason to expect that prices for goods and services subject to surveillance should necessarily show lower rates of increase than other goods and services. Prices for individual goods and services are influenced by factors such as the costs of raw materials and other inputs, the relative intensity of their use of capital and labour, and conditions of demand and supply in product markets. These affect different goods and services differently so that, over any given period, prices of some goods and services can be expected to be changing more rapidly, and others less rapidly, than the average rate of price change throughout the economy. Goods and services selected for surveillance need not be ones experiencing lower than average cost increases; indeed, the opposite may well apply.

The role of the Prices Surveillance Authority is not necessarily to reduce prices or proposed price increases, but to scrutinise prices in areas of the economy where effective competitive disciplines are absent and where price or wage decisions have pervasive effects throughout the economy. The Authority is bound by its statutory guidelines to have particular regard to the need to maintain investment and employment, to discourage the abuse of market power, and to discourage cost increases arising from breaches of the wage fixation principles.

It is the Government's intention the Authority should encourage price restraint in areas that are not currently subject to surveillance, as well as in areas that are. The Authority monitors pricing behaviour in some major areas of the economy and the knowledge that excessive price increases could lead to declarations under the Prices Surveillance Act should act to discourage companies from taking advantage of market power in setting prices. In addition, the ``Guidelines for Pricing Restraint'' which the Authority promulgated in August 1985, offer a voluntary framework that businesses in both the public and private sectors may adopt.

(3) and (4). It is not possible to say with certainty how prices for goods and services currently subject to price surveillance would have moved in the absence of such surveillance. Proposed price increases notified to the Authority are likely to be influenced by the knowledge that they are subject to examination by the Authority and proposals may therefore be lower than they would otherwise have been. Nevertheless, some price increases endorsed by the Authority have been lower than those proposed by the companies or public authorities concerned, and some price reductions have been effected following public inquiries by the Authority:

The maximum wholesale ``marker'' price of motor spirit set by the Authority in June 1984 was approximately 1.27 cents per litre lower than the average of the maximum prices for the individual oil companies previously established by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. On two occasions since then, reviews by the Authority have resulted in maximum wholesale prices for motor spirit lower than the companies proposed.

In public inquiries into the principal charges of Telecom and Australia Post in 1984, the Authority broadly accepted the approach to pricing taken by each of the Commissions, but rejected the anticipation of anomaly-based wage increases and recommended lower increases in certain charges than those that were proposed. These recommendations were accepted by the Commissions.

In November 1985, in an inquiry into cigarette prices, the Authority proposed that the manufacturers reduce their average wholesale prices exclusive of excise or customs duty by 0.5 per cent and that the adjustment be applied when the companies next submit cost-based notices of general price increases. The Authority also indicated an intention to adjust future excise over-recoveries by an imputed interest factor.

ANSWER.PARA: (i) The Commonwealth makes a substantial contribution towards research in universities in the form of both recurrent grants and funds allocated for specific activities, provided through the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Acts. The internal allocation of general recurrent grants is a university responsibility and so total expenditure on research and the nature of that research is a matter for them to determine.

The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission (CTEC) uses the widely accepted measure of Total Identifiable Research Expenditure (TIRE) to assess the total research effort of universities. TIRE includes research funds provided from Commonwealth sources other than the CTEC and from non-Commonwealth sources. TIRE measures that expenditure which universities are able to identify as having been incurred directly on research activities, such as the scholarships, research equipment and maintenance expenditure on research projects. However, TIRE does not include any imputed amounts for the research component of such significant items of expenditure as the salaries of teaching-and-research staff. Moreover, the CTEC's data do not attempt to distinguish between pure and applied research.
Commonwealth grants to universities and university records relate to calendar and not financial years.
In 1984, the latest year for which figures are available, TIRE from Commonwealth sources amounted to some $194.5m in comparable cost levels (estimated December 1984), the figure for 1982 was $170.7m.

(ii) The Commonwealth does not provide specific funding for research in colleges of advanced education. CAEs were, however, eligible to apply for funding from the $1 million provided under the Key Centres of Teaching and Research program introduced in 1985. (Comparable data on total identifiable research expenditure for the advanced education sector is currently being collected for the first time).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aviation, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Have there been any cases of air crew on duty on Australian civil aircraft being intoxicated during any of the last 10 years; if so, what are the details.
(2) Are air crew breath tested before coming on duty; if not why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. However that answer must be qualified in relation to the use of the word ``intoxicated''.

The relevant Air Navigation Regulation 247, makes it an offence for a pilot to be a crew member whilst his capacity to act is affected by alcohol, to consume alcohol within a period of eight hours immediately preceding a flight, and to consume alcohol whilst crewing an aircraft. However the Regulation does not provide a blood alcohol content limit or a definition of intoxication. A pilot could therefore commit an offence under this regulation without needing to have a blood alcohol content approaching the levels commonly used as a measure of intoxication in motor transport legislation.

Departmental records for the past 10 year period show that there were eight occasions in which an accident to an aircraft or an incident involving its operation occurred where the capacity of the pilot was impaired to some degree by alcohol, although this impairment may not have been the prime cause of the accident. Three of the accidents involved fatalities.
During the same period eight successful prosecution actions were taken against pilots for contravention of Regulation 247 and action was taken against a pilot's licence in four cases.
These figures are not cumulative in that in some cases the pilot involved in the accident was subject to both prosecution and/or licence action.
(2) No. There is no legal power under the Air Navigation Act or Regulations to conduct such tests nor is there a blood alcohol content specified against which such a test could be applied.

However my Department is undertaking a general review of the legislation in this area and as part of that review is studying recent changes in the United States. These include the introduction of a defined acceptable blood alcohol level for pilots but do not provide for breath testing prior to flight. As part of its review my Department will be consulting widely with overseas aviation authorities, State Motor Transport Authorities, the Aviation Industry and the appropriate industrial organisations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blunt Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 February 1986:

(2) Did this disclosure result in a rumour throughout money markets and foreign exchange dealers.

(3) Is he able to say who the Canberra economic adviser was who reportedly made the comments about the current account deficit being approximately $850 million or less, at a Tuesday lunch meeting of business economists as reported in The Australian of 12 December 1985.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 13 February 1986:

(2) If mess uniforms are not supplied to females will he run a competition to select appropriate dress.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Recreation and Tourism, upon notice, on 18 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is Australian taxpayers' money being expended on training New Zealand residents at the Australian Institute of Sport (AIS).
(2) How many residents from other countries have been trained at the AIS in the last 3 years and from which countries were they.
(3) What funding has been received from other countries towards the costs of training students in the last 3 years.
(4) To what extent did funding from Australia's overseas aid program contribute towards training students from developing countries in the last 3 years.
(5) Did Auckland tennis player Edith Tatana (a) train at the AIS and (b) tour overseas with an institute team; if so, how were expenses met for her training and touring.
(6) Will he investigate the 1986 application for entry to the AIS of Queensland junior tennis player Neil Borwick and, if funds are available, endeavour to have him included in the 1986 intake.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) When New Zealand athletes attend the AIS their personal costs are met by sources other than the Institute.
(2) The following teams and individuals have used the Institute's training facilities in the last three years
Kenya: 1 weightlifter, 1 track and field athlete
New Zealand: 2 netball teams, 1 basketball team, 2 gymnastics teams, 3 tennis players, 9 weightlifters
Papua New Guinea: 1 track and field athlete

(3) In many of the cases listed above, reciprocal arrangements exist for AIS athletes when they tour overseas. There has been no other funding contribution from overseas countries towards training overseas athletes at the AIS over the past 3 years.

(b) Yes, but all touring expenses were paid by her or the NZ Tennis Association. She also contributed 25% of her tournament winnings to the AIS.

Unless vacancies occur in the current number of tennis players on scholarship at the Institute he will not be further considered for a scholarship in 1986. (3) Is it proposed to refurbish the office at 2 Elizabeth Street to accommodate the Bureau, until March 1987; if so, what costs will be incurred in the refurbishment.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: World Commission on Environment and Development

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, upon notice, on 20 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did UN General Assembly Resolution 38/161 welcome the establishment of the World Commission on Environment and Development.
(2) What is the nature of the work of the Commission.
(3) Will the report of the Commission be submitted to the UN General Assembly in 1987.

(4) Is Australia a participant in the works of the Commission; if not, what action does he propose to take to facilitate Australian Government involvement in and support for the work of the Commission.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cohen The Hon B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The work of the commission is directed towards achieving the following objectives:
(i) to re-examine the critical issues of environment and development and to formulate innovative, concrete and realistic action proposals to deal with them;

(ii) to strengthen international co-operation on environment and development and to assess and propose new forms of co-operation that can break out of existing patterns and influence policies and events in the direction of needed change; and
(iii) to raise the level of understanding and commitment to action on the part of individuals, voluntary organisations, businesses, institutes and governments.

The Commission is also expected to consider ways and means by which the international community can deal more effectively with environmental concerns and define shared perceptions of long-term environmental issues and a long-term agenda for action during the coming decades.

(4) Australian support for the Commission is currently being considered. Discussions are continuing between my Department and the Commission concerning a proposal for an Australian analytical contribution to the work of the Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What information is available to the Government on the extent of the use of antibiotics to influence growth of livestock and poultry in Australia.
(2) Is he able to say whether any research is being done on the consequences of the use of antibiotics in animal and poultry feed for (a) the animals and (b) humans.
(3) What regulations are in force in Australia to control this use of antibiotics.
(4) Is he able to say what methods of regulating the use of antibiotics in animal and poultry feed are in use in other countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable member's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The only significant use of antibiotics in stockfeeds in Australia is in the intensive animal industries involved in production of poultry and pigs. The exact extent of use in these industries is not known.

(2) A vast amount of research has been carried out overseas during the last 15 years but no clearcut answers have emerged. In the absence of any clearly defined evidence of a significant human health hazard, regulatory authorities have deemed it prudent to assume that a hazard exists and to institute appropriate precautions.

(3) Only a small range of selected antibiotics may be purchased over-the-counter for growth promotant use. The antibiotics approved for open sale must have a low propensity to induce resistance and must not be used in human medicine. Antibiotics used for prevention or treatment of animal disease are available only on veterinary prescription.
The antibiotics approved for open sale do not leave detectable residues in meat when used in accordance with the directions on the registered label.

Veterinarians understand that they should prescribe feed antibiotics for prophylactic or therapeutic purposes only when their use is clearly indicated. Although stimulation of growth may be obtained as a fringe benefit, the antibiotics should not be prescribed primarily for this purpose.

Use of approved growth promotant antibiotics in accordance with approved conditions of use is a perfectly legitimate exercise and does not need to be discouraged in any way. Regulatory control is mainly directed towards the prevention of misuse. This is achieved principally by means of State legislation governing availability, labelling and advertising. The Commonwealth plays a coordinating role through the agency of Australian Agricultural Council and the National Health and Medical Research Council.

(4) Other countries regulate the use of antibiotics in animal and poultry feed in much the same way as Australia. The range of approved antibiotics may vary slightly from one country to another but will generally approximate the recommendations made by FAO/WHO. Penicillin and tetracyclines are still permitted in the United States but have been disallowed in Australia for some 6 or 7 years.

All feed additive use of antibiotics for growth promotion was banned in Sweden from 1 January, 1986. This was not a bureaucratic decision but was the result of an initiative taken by Swedish farmers themselves.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Purchase of Plastic Pistols by President Gaddafi

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he investigate allegations that (a) the President of Libya is engaged in negotiations to purchase a large number of plastic pistols which are said to be virtually undetectable by airport and other security staff, (b) the weapon is a 9mm Glock 17 pistol made in a village near Vienna, Austria, (c) a United States security expert has alleged that this weapon twice passed through security controls undetected at a United States airport and (d) the plastic pistols can easily be smuggled past airport security as only the barrel, spring and one other small part are metal.
(2) Is he able to say whether European and United States anti-terrorist squads believe President Gaddafi will supply the Glocks to Abu Nidhal's terrorist and Palestine Liberation Organisation gunmen.
(3) Is he also able to say whether the Austrian Government is reluctant to block the sale as President Gaddafi has suggested that he might purchase Austrian-made tanks and artillery.
(4) Will he take steps to investigate the allegations.

(5) Will he formally lodge an objection with the Austrian Government asking them to take action to ensure that these weapons are not produced and exported, particularly to terrorist organisations or to countries which support terrorist organisations.

(6) Will he draw the matter to the attention of (a) international organisations which deal with counter-terrorist investigations and activities and (b) all security organisations at shipping, airport and other embarkation ports to ensure that surveillance equipment and practices will be able to cope with the logistics of this weapon.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Young The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (5) I am advised that the 9mm `Glock 17' semi-automatic pistol is manufactured by the Austrian company, Glock. I am advised also that the Glock company has stated that it would not export the ``Glock 17'' pistol to Libya. Exports of the pistol are subject to the normal export controls of the Austrian Government.

Tests carried out on the `Glock 17' pistol by Austrian authorities and the United States Federal Aviation Administration have shown that the weapon cannot pass undetected through airport x-ray screening devices. I understand that tests were conducted on a prototype of the pistol by the Austrian authorities prior to its commercial manufacture. The pistol is 83 percent steel and 17 percent polymer and as a result is readily detectable under x-ray screening. Were the steel parts to be removed, scanning devices would still indicate an x-ray outline of a pistol.

(6) Australian security authorities have the question of possible terrorist threat to Australia and consequent preparedness under constant review. This process includes wide consultation with security agencies of foreign governments who share Australia's concern about international terrorism.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Blanchard Mr C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many persons in Western Australia receive a part Australian pension and an overseas pension.

(2) What is the cost of administering (a) payment of a part Australian pension to recipients of overseas pensions and (b) provision of Pensioner Health Benefits and concession cards to pensioners in receipt of Australian and overseas pensions who regularly lose their eligibility for the card due to fluctuations in the currency exchange rates.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The number of pensioners in Western Australia at 13 December 1985, who were receiving less than the maximum rate of Australian pension and had income from overseas pensions, was 7767.

(2) (a) Approximately 4 staff years are required in Western Australia to administer the payment of a part Australian pension to recipients of overseas pensions. Approximately 26 staff years are required to do this throughout Australia. Administering costs would be in the order of $0.1m and $0.7m respectively.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Housing and Construction, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the Australian Bureau of Statistics found that the increase in engineering construction in Australia over the previous year was 19.3%, 31.1% and 10.3% in 1980-81, 1981-82 and 1982-83, respectively.
(2) Is it also a fact that it declined by 16.9% and 10.1% in 1983-84 and 1984-85, respectively.
(3) Is engineering construction estimated to fall by 12.8% in 1985-86.

(4) Do the figures indicate a continuing loss of confidence by the construction industry in Government policies as compared to the policies of the Liberal-National Party Coalition Government of 1980 to 1982.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Yes. Figures quoted are derived from the quarterly Australian Bureau of Statistics' survey of Engineering Construction Activity by Contractor, which covers about 40 per cent of total engineering construction activity (the remainder is undertaken primarily by public sector workforces). The changes are expressed in real terms.

(3) The Australian Federation of Construction Contractors in the February 1986 edition of its ``Construction Industry Prospects'' publication forecast a 12.8 per cent fall in engineering construction work done by contractor in 1985-86. The Construction Forecasting Committee, on which the Federation is represented, has forecast a 7 per cent real fall in 1985-86. This forecast, which is a consensus of the views of all members of the Committee, was published in the December 1985 report ``Prospects for the Non-Residential Construction Industry''. Both the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors and the Construction Forecasting Committee have forecast that the decline in engineering construction activity by contractor will bottom out during the course of 1985-86. Neither forecast includes engineering construction activity undertaken by public sector workforces. This major component is forecast by the Committee to fall by 3 per cent in 1985-86.

(4) The surge in engineering construction activity that peaked in 1982-83 reflected the so-called ``resources boom'' in mining, mineral processing, electricity generation, and related infrastructure. The optimistic forecasts issued by the then Federal Government played a significant part in whipping up the ``boom''.

In the event, there was no boom, world economic conditions and commodity prices deteriorated. Engineering construction activity fell, and this Government was faced with restoring the fortunes of the engineering construction industry.

As an immediate response, the present Government greatly increased expenditure on capital works, both directly and through programs such as the National Roads Program. In the case of my own Department, around 90 per cent of works are undertaken by private contractors. Through these actions, the present Government, ensured that conditions facing engineering construction contractors were less severe during this difficult period. The Government also put in place sound economic policies that have laid the foundations for sustained economic growth.
The Government welcomes the signs that, as a result of these policies, the engineering construction sector will experience renewed growth in 1986-87.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has action been taken to reduce concessional expenditure rebates for (a) education in respect of children under 25 years and (b) self-education; if so, why.
(2) Is a more equitable approach to the granting of sales tax exemptions to students purchasing equipment and materials for use in their courses in higher education being considered; if not, why not.

(3) Is it a fact, as claimed by the Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee, that applications for sales tax exemptions for microcomputers are taking up to 4 weeks to process; if so, will he ensure that the delays are reduced.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Prior to 1 July 1985 certain expenditure on the education of a student under 25 years and on self-education, up to a maximum of $250 per student, qualified as concessional expenditure for rebate purposes. The concessional expenditure rebate, which was available at a rate of 30 per cent, only applied to that part of total qualifying expenditure in excess of $2,000. Because of this requirement only a small proportion of taxpayers (approximately 6 per cent in 1983-84) gained any direct benefit from the rebate.

On 17 July 1985 I announced, as part of the Government's tax reform package, that it had been decided to replace, from the 1985-86 income year, the concessional expenditure rebate with a medical expenses rebate. From 1 July 1985 expenses relating to education, therefore, ceased to qualify as rebatable expenditure.

In announcing this decision I indicated that the rebate has been of benefit to only a small section of the community, comprising mainly those on higher incomes, and the Government considered it no longer represented an equitable or efficient form of assistance for the items it covered. In relation to education expenses I specifically noted that:

`...[to] provide more effective assistance to education, the Government has already significantly increased direct funding of schools and tertiary education, and has entered into long term commitments to further expand direct funding in these areas.'

This and other tax reform measures introduced by the Government are part of a major restructuring of the tax system designed to improve its equity, efficiency and administration. The measures will also contribute towards financing the substantial reductions in personal income tax rates which form part of the tax reform package and which will benefit all taxpayers.

(2) The Government is not considering providing sales tax exemptions to tertiary students for equipment and materials purchased for use in their courses. A conditional exemption of this type would rate poorly on equity grounds and would be difficult to administer in a way which confined exemptions to the purpose intended.

Sales tax exemption is generally not the most equitable way of providing assistance. It is of greatest benefit to those with the means to spend most on the taxable goods in question. It does not assist those who purchase second-hand goods.

There are real difficulties in administering an exemption for a particular purpose for a particular class of persons in relation to goods that have a variety of uses or which are used in a variety of contexts. In particular, it is close to impossible to prevent abuses in the form of people gaining student status, perhaps as a part-time student, simply in order to acquire goods free of tax, or in the form of students purchasing goods for relatives or friends.

(3) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that it is possible that the processing of applications for sales tax exemptions for microcomputers may take up to four weeks. There are situations, however, when the applications are processed in a shorter period of time. He advises that some delays are caused by the large volume of correspondence handled by the Australian Taxation Office and at other times because of a need to gather more information to substantiate the validity of applications received.

The Commissioner has informed me that he has considered means of reducing the time taken to process these applications and at present new procedures have been adopted in some Branches with the result that the processing time is being reduced.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to confirm that the Soviet Union has now deployed more than 135 SS-20 intermediate range missiles in central Siberia and East of Lake Baikal.
(2) What is the range of the SS-20.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Soviet Union does not normally make such information about its forces public. The Government has seen statements to this effect by a number of senior United States Administration officials and has no reason to dispute them.

(2) No information is available from Soviet sources but publications such as the SIPRI Yearbooks, the United States Defense Department's Soviet Military Power and NATO and the Warsaw Pact: Force Comparisons (NATO Information Service 1984) place the range of the SS-20 in the vicinity of 4400-5000 kilometres.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Dag Hammarskjold Library at the United Nations Headquarters been under the charge of Soviet directors since 1964.
(2) What proportions of the $15,085,000 budget does the Australian Government pay for the upkeep of the Library.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. There have been four Soviet Directors of the UN Library since 1964. While there have been gaps of up to six months between these directors, no other nationals have been appointed to the position in the period.
(2) Australia contributes 1.66 percent of the 1986/87 UN Budget of which the costs of the UN Library form a part. Australia therefore pays a notional 1.66% of the budget of the UN Library.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to allegations that the UN Dag Hammarskjold Library has been exploited and misused for Soviet purposes; if so, is there any substance in the allegations.
(2) Are there 39 listings under democracy and 110 under communism in the subject catalogue.

(3) Is he able to confirm that under Freedom of Speech nothing is listed for the Soviet Union, but under Freedom of Speech-Israel the catalogue lists one title, Restrictions on the Freedom of Expression of the State Employee in Israel, and under Freedom of Speech-United Kingdom the catalogue lists The Recent Decline and Fall of Freedom of the Press in English Law.

(4) Under the subject catalogue heading of Peace are there twice as many listings for the USSR than for the United States, while under the heading of Chemical and Biological Warfare there are more than twice as many listings for the United States than for the USSR.
(5) If so, what action will he take to ensure a more balanced and objective collection of library material.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. A Soviet Director would be in a position to influence Library policy, but I am not aware of convincing evidence to support these allegations. Of the 63 professional positions in the UN Library, 23 are filled by United States citizens and 8 by Soviet citizens.
(2) I am informed that there are 65 listings under `democracy' and 41 under `communism'.
According to the UN Library, its data bases, catalogues and indexes reflect the agenda items and resolutions of various UN bodies.
Subject index items are decided by a Committee comprising the following nationalities: Chinese (1), French (1), Jamaican (1), Japanese (1), Soviet (1) and United States (7).

(4) There are 6 references listed under ``Peace: United States'' and 13 under ``Peace: USSR''. There are 11 references under ``Chemical and Biological Warfare: United States'' and 6 under ``Chemical Warfare: USSR''.

(5) The policy of the UN Library on the selection and retention of material is determined by a panel of professional staff on which Western countries are well represented. There are no Soviet representatives on the Monographs or Serials Committees which decide acquisitions and retention policy. This suggests that allegations of deliberate bias are not well founded.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what basis (a) was he able to express an understanding of the interception of an Egyptian aircraft conveying suspected terrorists by American airforce planes and (b) did he deplore the recent Israeli airforce planes' interception of Libyan aircraft suspected of conveying terrorists.
(2) Is he able to say how the interception of a civil aircraft in international air space can be justified.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Government was able to express understanding of the interception of an Egyptian aircraft on a non-scheduled flight by American airforce planes following the Achille Lauro incident on the basis that the United States was apprehending and helping to bring to justice persons known to have just committed specific acts of terrorism against United States citizens on the high seas.

(b) I deplored the interception by Israeli airforce planes of a Libyan civil aircraft suspected by Israel of carrying persons whom the Israelis suspected of having committed acts of terrorism, on the basis that such action could be regarded as a precedent jeopardising the lives and safety of perfectly innocent passengers and crew, which is our paramount concern.

(2) It is not possible to state in a general way how or when the interception of a civil aircraft in international air space may be justified. Much will always depend on the prevailing circumstances at the time.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is he able to say whether Libyan intelligence operatives are active on islands in Oceania.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Libyan officials have visited the South Pacific on a number of recent occasions. I am not able to give precise information about their status or activities, although I understand that part of their purpose has been the development of links with the New Caledonian Kanak independence movement (FLNKS).

The Australian Government has publicly expressed its concern about Libyan links with the South Pacific. It has made it very clear to Libya and the FLNKS that Australia and others in the region would look with considerable disfavour on any training or other activity which would pose a threat to the present peaceful political process in New Caledonia. The Australian Government will remain particularly concerned about any action which would lead to the use, or threat of use, of violence and terrorism in New Caledonia or elsewhere in the region.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has he or his Department received a copy of the publication entitled The 72 Hour Document: The Sandanista Blueprint for Constructing Communism in Nicaragua.
(2) Does he accept the authenticity of this document.

(3) Has his attention been drawn to the US' State Department's view that it demonstrates that, from the time of the revolution, the Sandanistas were intent on converting Nicaragua into a Marxist-Leninist State closely aligned with the Soviet Bloc.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The publication, produced by the United States Department of State, is of a document originally entitled ``Analysis of the Situation and Tasks of the Sandanista People's Revolution''. It is an analysis along Marxist lines of Nicaraguan history and events leading up to the overthrow of the dictator Somoza. It also sets out to identify the tasks ahead of the ruling party, the FSLN, in maintaining power and improving its organisational base.

(2) I am not in a position to be able to verify the authenticity of the document. Its contents indicate that it probably is authentic and I am not aware of any attempt by the Nicaraguan Government to disown it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether in recent months Sandinista armed forces have intensified military activities in the northern quarter of Nicaragua and the south-central region against democratic resistance forces.
(2) Is he also able to say whether the Soviet manufactured MI-24 HIND-D attack helicopter has been introduced in the Sandinista offensive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Fighting between the Nicaraguan armed forces and anti-government Nicaraguan insurgents known as Contras intensified in the first quarter of 1986. The fighting has been concentrated in the northern part of Nicaragua, near the Contra bases across the border in Honduras. The intensification of the fighting appears to have been part of a Nicaraguan offensive designed to drive the Contras back into Honduras. Contra activity has also been reported in the Central Nicaraguan provinces of Boaco and Chontales.
(2) The Nicaraguan Armed Forces possess several MI-24 (HIND-D) helicopters. I understand that these aircraft have been used in action against the Contras.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Further to his answer to my question No. 1730 (Hansard, 30 November 1985, page 4066), which specific Central American Governments have a worse record on human rights than the Nicaraguan Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: It is generally considered that Guatemala and El Salvador have a worse record on human rights than the Nicaraguan Government. While there have been improvements recently and while the return to democratic governments is encouraging, the history of politically motivated killings and disappearances in Guatemala and El Salvador is atrocious.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Vanuatu: Links with the Kanak Independence Movement

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has his attention been drawn to a report in the Journal of Defence and Diplomacy of September 1985 stating that Vanuatu is offering military assistance to the Kanak independence movement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the peace movement had some striking recent successes in (a) the shooting down of the MX missile test assistance proposal and (b) the forcing of the Government to support the freeze resolution in the UN.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to my question No. 1682 (Hansard, 11 October 1984) pages 2217-8 concerning allegations that Iraq has used nerve gas and mustard gas in the war against Iran, is it a fact that a recent report from a team of United Nations investigators has confirmed Iraq's use of these toxic gases.
(2) If so, is this the first occasion that a country has been named for violating the 1925 Geneva Protocol banning the use of chemical weapons.
(3) Will Australia condemn Iraq's actions in the strongest possible terms at appropriate international forums.
(4) Will he seek an agreement with other relevant governments to ban the export of chemicals that could be used in the manufacture of chemical weapons by Iraq.

(5) Will he call upon the United Nations to request the investigatory team to visit countries involved in the conflict to enable verification as to whether stocks of chemical weapons exist and to seek the support of these governments in allowing access.

(6) Will he call upon the governments of Iran and Iraq and those that can be affected by the conflict seeking their assurances (a) that they will not use chemical weapons, (b) that all existing stock of chemical weapons will be destroyed and (c) that they will comply with their obligations under the Geneva Protocol of 1925.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1986 Report of the Mission Despatched by the Secretary-General to Investigate Allegations of the Use of Chemical Weapons in the Conflict between Iran and Iraq, which visited Iran from 26 February to 3 March 1986, concluded on the basis of investigations in 1984, 1985 and 1986 that:
(a) on many occasions Iraqi forces have used chemical weapons against Iranian forces;
(b) the agent used has mainly been mustard gas, although on some occasions nerve gas was also employed.

(2) There has been a number of allegations of use of chemical weapons-some verified and others not-since the Geneva Protocol was concluded in 1925. Some of these instances of use involved Parties to the Protocol while others concerned non-Parties. As far as the Government is aware, however, the conclusions of the 1986 Report of the Mission despatched by the United Nations Secretary-General constitute the first occasion since the Protocol was concluded that a Party to the Protocol has been named by an independent panel of experts established under appropriate international auspices as being in violation of the Protocol.

(3) The Government has already strongly condemned Iraq's use of chemical weapons in a statement issued by me on 16 March 1986 and in statements to the United Nations Security Council and the Conference on Disarmament. The Government has also made its views known directly to the Government of Iraq.

(4) The Government is committed to the early conclusion of a Comprehensive Chemical Weapons Convention which would ban the production, stockpiling and use as well as the transfer of all chemical weapons. Australia has taken a leading role in negotiations to this end in the Conference on Disarmament in Geneva. As an interim measure pending the conclusion of the Convention, the Government has itself instituted controls on the export of chemicals which could be used to manufacture the chemical weapons used by Iraq. It has also taken an initiative to convene a number of meetings with Western countries which have instituted similar controls to see whether there is scope for cooperation to make these controls more effective.

(5) The Government does not consider that much would be gained by investigating whether stocks of chemical weapons exist in Iran and Iraq, especially since a United Nations investigation has already confirmed that Iraq has used chemical weapons and therefore must possess stocks of chemical weapons. Moreover, possession of stocks of chemical weapons is not prohibited under existing international law. See also my answer to part 4 of Question on Notice No. 1682 (Hansard, 11 October 1984), pages 2217-8.
(6) The Government had made it clear on several occasions to both Iran and Iraq that:
(a) it considers the use of chemical weapons abhorrent;

(b) it is committed to the early conclusion of a Comprehensive Chemical Weapons Convention as described in (4) above which would, inter alia, require the destruction of all existing stocks of chemical weapons;
(c) it attaches the utmost importance to the strict observance of the 1925 Geneva Protocol.
