ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United States Citizens Employed At Joint Facilities

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Staples Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, and the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 10 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In what way do conditions and regulations of entry of US citizens visiting or employed at Australia-US joint facilities in Australia differ from those applying to Australians on re-entry or to the entry of other nationalities.
(2) Under what statutes or policy directives administered by the Minister's Department are these exemptions allowed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The following answer to question No. 2117 was tabled on 14 February 1986. This answer was, in fact, submitted with the concurrence of the Ministers for Industry, Technology and Commerce, and Health in response to question Nos. 2116-2118:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Members of the United States forces or members of the civilian component i.e. civilian employees of the United States Government, and their dependants travelling to or staying in Australia under the Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) between the United States and Australia do not require visas for Australia, or entry permits, provided they hold a movement order or certificate of status. However, employees of private American companies working at joint facilities in Australia are required to meet normal requirements for entry to Australia, including being issued with visas and entry permits.

In addition, dependants of SOFA personnel admitted under the exemptions set out above are not subject to the restrictions on employment in Australia which are imposed on the dependants of other temporary residents. This concession is granted on a reciprocal basis i.e. dependants of personnel of the Australian Armed Forces in the USA are also permitted to work.

People travelling to Australia on Australian or New Zealand passports do not require visas and are not issued with entry permits (except for New Zealanders who would otherwise be prohibited non-citizens under Section 16 of the Migration Act).

With a few limited exceptions (e.g. members of the Royal Family, members of the armed forces of Commonwealth countries) nationals of other countries are required to obtain the appropriate visa for travel to Australia and are issued with an entry permit on arrival which would allow either an indefinite stay or a specific limited period of stay appropriate to their purpose of entry.

(2) Paragraph 8 (1) (e) of the Migration Act 1958 provides for a person to be exempted, by instrument under the hand of the Minister, from the entry permit requirements of the Act. Paragraph 11c (1) (b) of the Migration Act 1958 makes similar provision in respect of visa requirements. SOFA personnel and their dependants are included in a class of persons so exempted. The absence of employment restrictions on dependants of SOFA personnel accords with the concessions available to dependants of personnel of the Australian Armed Forces in the USA. The guidelines are contained in the Temporary Entry Handbook Part 1, section 9.2 and Annex 23.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 October 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the address at the International Criminal Law Congress in Adelaide by Mr John Sulan, in particular, his reference to the need for the appointment of specialist judges and assessors to preside over the prosecution of extremely complex commercial crime.

(2) Is he pursuing comments reported to have been made by the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Ian Temby, QC, as reported in The Age of 15 October 1984, to the effect that whilst juries could comprehend straight forward cases, such understanding might not be possible in a major fraud trial or one involving complex technical evidence.

(3) Will he investigate the need to amend the Judiciary Act 1903, the Crimes Act 1914, the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983 and the Special Prosecutors Act 1982, so as to enable complex commercial crime to be presented before a specialist of the Federal Court.

(4) Will he investigate the applicability of the recommendation in the UK Lord Roskill Report and the debates concerning the UK Financial Services Bill, as a means for combating the escalation of complex commercial crime in Australia.

(5) Will he investigate the recommendations of Queensland, New South Wales and Victorian Law Reform Commissions' inquiries into the role of the jury in criminal trials as they could affect the prosecution of offences under Commonwealth law.
(6) Has he considered there is an urgent need to re-appraise structures by which ``pin-stripe crime'' is dealt with in the legal system.

(7) Will he take steps to set up a separate commercial division within the Federal Court to deal with extremely complicated commercial crime and will he consider that such a Court should compromise specialist judges and expert assessors in prosecutions for breaches of commercial law, rather than State Courts vested with federal jurisdiction.

(8) Is there any constitutional barrier to a commercial division of the Federal Court being comprised of both expert judges and assessors, provided the latter take no part in the final decision; if so, would technically qualified or experienced assessors be of invaluable assistance in interpreting complex commercial evidence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) I am aware of the comments to which the honourable member refers. I believe that the appropriate solution is to find better ways of equipping juries to comprehend and analyse such evidence effectively. The jury system is fundamental to our criminal justice system and indeed vital to our democratic society, and any reform in this area should leave the jury's role undiminished.

(3) The current practice of investing State courts with federal criminal jurisdiction is one of long standing. The general policy, subject to some exemptions, is not to confer criminal jurisdiction on the Federal Court. Amendment of the Acts referred to in the question is not, therefore, considered necessary.

(4) The report on Reform of Fraud Trials prepared by the U.K. Government Committee under the chairmanship of Lord Roskill was published on 10 January 1986. A copy is being forwarded to my Department which will examine it, when it becomes available, to ascertain whether any of the recommendations made by the Committee may be applicable in Australia. I note, however, that the U.K. Criminal Bar Association, the Law Society Criminal Law Committee, and the British Labour Party are opposing the proposal to remove the right to trial by jury in complex fraud cases.

The issues arising under the U.K. Financial Services Bill are ones which also arise in Australia. The Bill will be closely examined not only in relation to matters involving complex commercial issues but also in respect of other matters such as deregulation of financial markets.

(5) The role of juries in criminal trials is primarily a matter for the States. My Department is examining the New South Wales Law Reform Commission's Report on Jury Trials at the request of the Commission. This Report includes detailed proposals on means of assisting juries in complex trials. The Department also has a copy of the Queensland Law Reform Commission's working paper on the role of juries in criminal trials, and will obtain and examine a copy of the Victorian Law Reform Commission's background paper on juries when it is published.

(6) and (7) The Government is keeping under review the criminal justice system in which persons charged with offences of a commercial nature are dealt with. However, I do not consider that there is a need at this stage to vest jurisdiction in a special division of the Federal Court to try offences of a criminal nature. I see no reason to change the policy referred to in (3) above.

(8) This question calls for an expression of legal opinion which it is not necessary to consider at the present time. Whether any particular proposal involving the use of assessors or a modified form of jury trial would be constitutional would have to be considered having regard to the details of that proposal.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 18 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Minister's Department, or any statutory authority responsible to the Minister, provide grants to organisations operating in the Australian Capital Territory.

(2) Do such grants have a requirement that any organisation so funded be registered under the Australian Capital Territory Association Incorporation Ordinance 1953; if so, what steps are taken by the Minister's Department to ensure that the funded organisation has complied with the Ordinance before any grant is made.
(3) Does the Minister's Department or statutory authority carry out a search of the register at the Australian Capital Territory Corporate Affairs Commission.

(4) If the search discloses a failure to comply with the Australian Capital Territory Associations Incorporation Ordinance, what steps are taken to ensure that the matter is remedied by those responsible for administration of the Ordinance, or the incorporated association.

(5) Have all incorporated associations within the Australian Capital Territory funded by the Minister's Department or statutory authority complied with the Ordinance requirements for lodging particulars of financial affairs and balance sheets annually.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA): Yes; Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC): Yes; Australian Institute of Aboriginal Studies (AIAS): No.

DAA: No. The Australian Capital Territory Corporate Affairs Commission has advised that such organisations do not have to be incorporated under the Australian Capital Territory Associations Incorporation Ordinance 1953.
ADC: No. However, a requirement for a grant is that the organisation must be a body corporate.
ADC: No. However, a requirement for a grant is that the organisation must produce its Certificate of Incorporation.

ADC: Not applicable. However, where an organisation fails to show that it is a body corporate, those responsible for administration of the organisation are advised that the organisation must have corporate status before a grant can be provided.
DAA and ADC: All incorporated organisations which receive grants have to comply with the requirements of the legislation under which they are incorporated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 26 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the present position of the Government's undertaking to extend telephone interception powers to State police in relation to drug trafficking, made at the special Premiers' Conference on drugs in April 1985.
(2) Have any States formally requested such powers; if so, (a) which States and (b) what was the outcome of the requests.
(3) Have any problems arisen with implementation of State proposals; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A Bill to amend the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 is being prepared. The Bill will make telecommunications interception powers available, subject to stringent safeguards, in relation to drug trafficking offences to certain police officers of those States and Territories that request such powers. The Bill will be forwarded to State Premiers for their approval prior to introduction.

(2) The States and the Northern Territory will not be in a position to request interception powers formally until the proposed Commonwealth legislation is enacted, and the respective States and the Northern Territory have taken the necessary legislative measures to ensure effective safeguards. In response to a letter from the Prime Minister, however, Queensland, South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory have indicated that they will request interception powers.
(3) No specific proposals have yet been received from the States.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 27 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will he explain the apparent contradiction between his answer to part (3) of question No. 1187 (Hansard 8 October 1985, page 1426) and information contained in the handwritten memorandum by a member of his Department appearing on pages 181 and 182 of the book The Price of Affluence: Dilemmas of Contemporary Japan and referring to the inclusion of a Japanese police record on Professor Hidaka's file.
(2) Further to his answer to part (6) of the question, what consultation takes place between the Australian and Japanese Governments prior to the awarding of grants by the Japan Foundation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hurford The Hon C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The answer given to part (3) of question No. 1187 is correct. I am aware of the reasons behind the honourable member's question, but I would like to assure him that there is and was no Report from the Japanese Police on the file.

(2) My colleague the Minister for Foreign Affairs informs me that no consultation takes place between the Department of Foreign Affairs and the Japan Foundation prior to the awarding of grants by the Japan Foundation.
Similarly, my Department is not party to consultations with the Japan Foundation prior to the awarding of grants.

As set out in the answer, the Department of Foreign Affairs does not undertake consultations with the Japan Foundation, however, whether the Japan Foundation undertakes consultations with any other Government Department is not known to Foreign Affairs or this Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: Under what Commonwealth laws are class action procedures currently available.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Class action procedures of the kind available in the United States are not currently available under Commonwealth laws. A limited form of class action, known as a representative action, is available under the Rules of the High Court (Order 16 Rule 12) and the Federal Court (Order 6 Rule 13). Briefly, those rules provide that where numerous persons have the same interest in a proceeding, one or more of them may sue or be sued as representing the others. As, under these rules, the represented parties must have the same interest the representative action does not, unlike the United States system, assist parties seeking damages in respect of numerous separate torts of the same nature.

Representative action by the Trade Practices Commission to obtain redress on behalf of particular named persons who have suffered loss or damage because of the conduct of a corporation or person in breach of the consumer protection provisions in Division 1 or 1A of Part V of the Trade Practices Act is provided for in clause 55 of the Trade Practices Revision Bill 1986 which proposes amendments to section 87 of the Act. Under this section the court will not be empowered to make awards of damages to a class of persons but only to the particular named persons. I mentioned that the desirability of having class actions in Australia is currently under consideration by the Law Reform Commission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 29 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister able to say in what States and Territories education authorities still permit corporal punishment in schools.
(2) What action has been taken since March 1983 by the Commonwealth to (a) prevent and (b) discourage the use of corporal punishment by State and Territory education authorities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Commonwealth Government considers corporal punishment to be inappropriate and unnecessary and opposes its use in schools. In the Australian Capital Territory, where the Commonwealth administers the school system, the ACT Schools Authority discourages the use of corporal punishment and urges schools to move toward its abolition. Other State and Territory education authorities determine their own discipline policies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coleman Mr W.P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 12 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has there been a wage increase awarded as a result of the renegotiation of the Australian Oil Refining-Australian Lubricating Oil Refinery Industrial Agreement at the Caltex Kurnell refinery; if so: (a) what was the nature of the increase, (b) what were the reasons for the increase and (c) does the increase fall within the guidelines for the Prices and Incomes Accord.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Industrial Agreement between the Australian Workers' Union (New South Wales Branch) and Australian Oil Refining Pty Ltd and Australian Lubricating Oil Refinery Ltd was renegotiated late last year.
The new Industrial Agreement applies to operators and storemen at the Caltex Kurnell refineries and contains provision for wage increases based on alleged changes in work value.

The Agreement was registered with the New South Wales Industrial Registrar under Section 11 of the New South Wales Industrial Arbitration Act and took effect on 15 January 1986, remaining in force for two years.

In early December 1985, I contacted Caltex to express the Government's view that the Industrial Agreement should be fully tested in terms of the wage fixation Principles of the New South Wales Industrial Commission. In proceedings before Mr Justice Macken of the Commission on 16 and 20 December 1985 the Commonwealth intervened to argue that the Industrial Agreement be tested against the Principles. In a statement of 20 December 1985, Mr Justice Macken noted the importance of having the Agreement tested and indicated his intention to review the impact of the alleged work value changes on each classification.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 12 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to the Treasurer's answer to my question No. 11 (Hansard, 19 November 1985, pages 3178-81) concerning the investigation of the transfer of management of the Bishopsgate Insurance Aust. (Merchant Bank) to the investment company of a Bishopsgate director, Mr Stathis, by Mr Stathis without the approval of his co-directors has the investigation by the New South Wales Government into that transfer been completed.

(2) If the investigation has been completed, has it revealed (a) a breach or breaches of the Companies Act; and (b) any deficiencies in company law; if so, has the matter been raised at the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities and what action will be taken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) I understand that the New South Wales Government investigations are continuing. The matter has not been raised with the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Acoustic Laboratories: Electoral Division of Hinkler

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Conquest Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a decision been made to reduce (a) the frequency of visits and (b) the range of services offered by officers of the National Acoustic Laboratories (NAL) to cities in the Electoral Division of Hinkler.

(2) What aural testing and associated services are available to those eligible hearing-affected pensioners in the Electoral Division of Hinkler who reside in country areas not visited by NAL officers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) Yes. The visits by NAL technicians to Gladstone and Bundaberg in the Electoral Division of Hinkler were discontinued because the number of hearing aid repairs undertaken was insufficient to justify such visits. As a more economical measure clients are requested to return their aids by post to Brisbane for repair. This should in most cases result in a quicker and better service. Clients will not have to wait with a non-functioning hearing aid until the technician visits the region and repairs will be carried out in a fully equipped technical facility.
(b) No. There will be no reduction in the range of clinical services available in the area.

(2) In the electorate of Hinkler, Bundaberg and Gladstone are the only visiting hearing centres and both of these are equipped with audiometric booths and full test facilities. The number of man days spent in Gladstone and Bundaberg by an NAL audiologist during 1985-86 has shown a substantial increase over 1984-85. Clients in the electorate are offered the full range of audiological services including hearing assessment, hearing aid selection and rehabilitation at these centres.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Hague Conference on Civil Aspects of International Child Abductions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 18 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Further to his answer to my question No. 3 (Hansard, 19 April 1985, page 1544) has Australia ratified the Hague Convention on International Child Abductions.

(2) What procedures would be followed in (a) Australia and (b) overseas under the terms of the convention in the event that a child domiciled in Australia is improperly removed from Australia to another country which has ratified the convention.
(3) Would the child be held as a ward in the country where it has been taken; if so, for how long.
(4) What financial assistance is available to an Australian parent from whom a child is improperly removed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australia has not yet ratified the Hague Convention on the Civil Aspect of International Child Abduction. However a final draft of the necessary regulations, prepared after considerable consultation with the States has been forwarded to the Attorney-General of each of the States and the Northern Territory. It is envisaged that these regulations will be made in the near future. Once the regulations are made and the instrument of accession had been deposited it will be a further three months before the Convention will enter into force for Australia. This three month delay is created by Article 38 of the Convention.

(2) Where a child has been removed from Australia to another country, which is a party to the Convention, the person entitled to the custody of the child in Australia would apply through the Secretary of my Department for the return of the child. This application would then be transmitted to the necessary Authority in the country to which the child had been taken. The Receiving Authority would then arrange for proceedings to be taken as soon as possible under the Convention for the immediate return of the child to Australia.

(3) The Convention does not specify that the child become a ward of the Court although it may be necessary from time to time for a court to place the child in the custody of an appropriate person or institution pending the outcome of proceedings. This will depend upon the legislation implementing the convention in each country.

(4) The parent may be eligible for assistance under the Commonwealth's Overseas Custody (Child Removal) Scheme. This is an administrative scheme whereby the Attorney-General is authorised to grant financial assistance to a parent, ordinarily resident in Australia, instituting or proposing to institute legal proceedings overseas for recovery of any child of such parent removed from Australia by the other parent. In considering an application under the scheme the Attorney-General takes into account the questions whether it would involve financial hardship to the applicant if assistance were not granted and whether it is reasonable in all the circumstances that the application should be granted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 11 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it possible for an individual to import tear gas into Australia; if so, what requirements need to be met.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The importation of `chemical warfare gas and devices and apparatus designed for use with that gas' and `Warfare Weapons and Appliances' and `Gases and liquids designed for the purpose of killing or incapacitating persons . . .' is prohibited under Regulation 4 (1) of the Customs (Prohibited Imports) Regulations, unless the written permission of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has been granted.

The Departments of Foreign Affairs and Defence advise that Australia and a number of other countries do not regard riot control agents such as tear gas as a warfare gas or as a chemical agent comprehended by the Geneva Protocol of 1925 (which prescribes the use in war of biological and chemical agents, popularly termed `war gases').
The importation of tear gas is therefore permitted subject to normal Customs entry and clearance procedures.

The Department of the Special Minister of State has confirmed that State and Territory weapons control legislation generally regulates the possession and/or use of products such as tear gas. Intending importers should check with the relevant police authority before ordering tear gas from overseas.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Processing of Passengers through Customs and Immigration: Perth

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 13 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Is it a fact that (a) air passengers entering Australia at Perth are processed partially through customs and immigration at 3 a.m. and (b) customs and immigration formalities could be more easily and quickly conducted at Sydney or any other international airport in Australia at which the flight is terminating; if so, why are the formalities conducted in Perth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) No passengers are partially processed through Customs and Immigration at Perth Airport. Those passengers who disembark from international flights and subsequently leave the international terminal are fully cleared through Customs and Immigration.
(b) Passengers who remain on international flights for disembarkation at another Australian airport are processed through Customs and Immigration at the airport where they finally disembark.

However all international passengers arriving at Perth Airport, including those whose journey terminates at another Australian airport, are processed in accordance with health requirements by officials from the Department of Health.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 13 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What progress did he make during his meetings in Spain and Portugal towards convincing the Ministers responsible for commerce and industry, agriculture, energy and foreign affairs of the need to adopt a more rational system of international trade in agricultural goods.
(2) What progress did he make in Madrid towards promoting Australian exports of (a) coal and (b) agricultural machinery and manufactures.
(3) What progress did he make in Lisbon towards promoting Australian participation in the development of the proposed coal unloading facility at the Port of Sines.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) During my visit to Spain and Portugal, between 3 and 8 February 1986, as part of a wider visit to Europe the opportunity was taken to press forcefully Australia's concerns with the excesses of the Commonwealth Agricultural Policy (CAP) of the European Communities (EC) and to reaffirm the importance of resolving the serious problems in markets for agricultural products during the New Round of Multilateral Trade Negotiations.

Spain and Portugal, along with Italy and Greece, believe there is a bias in the CAP which favours many of the temperate agricultural products produced in northern Member States. In particular, it was pointed out that a greater share of the EC budget is going to agriculture in Northern Europe. Spain and Portugal, of course, would like to gain a larger share of the CAP expenditures but they recognise that price support alone would not be adequate to develop their agricultural regions. Hence, they are seeking, in the context of CAP reform, a change in direction towards structural assistance for the poorer regions of the EC which are mainly Mediterranean.

I indicated that, from Australia's perspective, there was some degree of complementarity with the Mediterranean perspective of CAP reform in that we face a number of problems arising from the CAP, especially in temperate products and sugar.

I outlined the consequences of the CAP for Australia in depressing world agricultural prices and displacing some of Australia's exports with subsidised EC exports in third markets. I also indicated that the CAP had numerous and large hidden costs to the Community at large, such as the loss of jobs in other sectors and that it would be in their interest to seek reforms of the CAP.

Several of the Spanish and Portugese Ministers and Officials indicated a desire for reform of the CAP and I believe these countries could eventually have a significant influence in promoting reform within the EC. It was, however, also recognised that the first question which needed to be addressed was whether genuine reform of the CAP could be seriously tackled at the political level in Europe.

(2) During my visit to Madrid I had extremely useful discussions with Senor Major the Spanish Minister for Industry and Energy, Senor Solchaga, the Minister for Economy and Finance, Senor Pena, the Deputy Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Food, and Senor Rami, the Secretary of State for Trade.

(a) I registered Australia's strong interest in increasing its exports of coal to Spain, which were valued at $61.3m in 1984-85. Spanish Ministers noted that Spain's energy policy is directed towards self-sufficiency in coal for power generation, and imports account for only 20 per cent of consumption. However, Australia's share of this import market could increase further if Spanish purchasing strategies shift away from South Africa in line with EC policy guidelines. I also raised the possibility of Australia establishing a coal stockpile in Spain for additional sales in the Mediterranean. The Spanish authorities indicated they would welcome the stockpile initiative if it proves feasible. For its part, Spain is also interested in involving Australian companies in coal exploration and development in the Balearic Islands and Indonesia.

(b) On agricultural machinery, I pointed out that there is considerable scope for Spanish agriculture to benefit from the use of Australian agricultural equipment and technology, and that our undoubted expertise in dryland and shallow cultivation techniques would be particularly appropriate to Spanish conditions.

On manufactures, I also registered Australia's keen interest in increasing its sales of high technology manufactured goods. Opportunities will increase in Spain as Spain's tariffs on such items are gradually reduced to the much lower EC rate.

(3) During my visit to Lisbon I discussed the proposed development of the port of Sines with a number of Portuguese Ministers, including the Minister for Commerce, Mr Martins who has Ministerial responsibility for the project. Also participating in the discussion with Mr Martins was Mr Girard, a member of the the Joint Coal Board who accompanied me on my visit to both Madrid and Lisbon.

Sines is one of a number of prospective port developments in Europe which the Joint Coal Board has been investigating and in 1985 the Board registered its interest in the development and use of the proposed coal receival and stockpiling facility at Sines.

Mr Martins informed me that the project to develop the port and a related coal centre was still under active and detailed consideration. He told me that following a recent restructuring of management of the project a decision would soon have to be made by the government on whether the project should proceed and, if so, on what basis.

Mr Martins welcomed Australia's interest in the project and said that if it proceeded he hoped Australian companies could be included in consortia which he expected would tender for it. Mr Girard confirmed the Board's continuing interest in the project and following agreement between Mr Martins and myself later held further discussions with officials about the technical aspects of the project.

Following Mr Girard's visit to Spain, Portugal and a number of other potential sites, the Joint Coal Board is now assessing the various possibilities of establishing a coal stockpile facility in Europe.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Bureau of Transport Economics: Assessment of Australian Railway System

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 19 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Bureau of Transport Economics undertake an assessment of the Australian railway system similar to its 1984 assessment of the Australian road system; if not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Significant studies of Australia's rail system have already been carried out in recent years. They include the `1981 Report on Rail' by the Australian Railway Research and Development Organisation and the `Action Plan for National Railway Development' endorsed by the Australian Transport Advisory Council in 1983. A major conclusion of these studies was that investment measures alone are not sufficient to solve the problems facing the rail systems and that other measures were also required.

The deficits of the rail systems have increased from less than $790m in 1979/80 to more than $1.4 billion in 1984/85. Difficult decisions have to be taken to improve their financial performance. This will require the strong commitment of all parties-governments, rail authorities and unions-to major changes to improve rail's efficiency.

The Government therefore considers that it is more appropriate to establish the proposed Railway Industry Council (RIC). RIC will provide a forum for all parties involved in the industry to develop appropriate strategies embracing both investments and other measures, to revitalise the railways and improve their financial performance. It may be that RIC in determining its work program and priorities will consider what further studies it believes should be initiated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 20 March 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is he able to say whether, beginning in September 1985, the Sandinistas sharply intensified the campaign of repression against internal groups such as the Catholic Church, evangelical groups, political parties and the private sector.
(2) Has he made representations to the Nicaraguan Government concerning the denial of such human rights.
(3) If so, when and to whom; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The human rights situation in Nicaragua deteriorated in 1985, with the Sandinista Government showing decreasing tolerance of Legitimate dissent, but occasionally making efforts to discuss differences with their political opponents.

On 15 October 1985, the Nicaraguan Government reimposed a State of Emergency which suspended a large number of civil and political rights. The Government defended its action by claiming to be in a state of war and pointing out that other countries in such situations had historically resorted to similar restrictions on individual rights.

However, it became clear that the emergency powers were being used, inter alia, to harass opposition political and economic groups and to restrict the freedom of action of the Catholic Church. Amnesty International's 1985 Report cites arrests, interrogations, short-term detentions, severe press censorship and restrictions on freedom of assembly directed against groups in Nicaragua dissenting from the Government's policies. The report also cited more serious human rights violations by the anti-Government insurgents or Contras.

(3) I raised Australian concerns about the State of Emergency with Nicaraguan Foreign Minister d'Escoto during his visit to Canberra in late November 1985. Formal representations on the matter were made by Australia to the Nicaraguan Government through its Embassy in Mexico City on 30 November 1985. Officers of the Australian Embassy in Mexico City (accredited to Nicaragua) had, on my instructions, previously made representations in Managua, on behalf of imprisoned trade unionists.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Nicaragua and Honduras: Proposed Peace-Keeping Force

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 9 April 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has he received a request to contribute to or support any peace keeping force on the Nicaraguan/Honduran border under the Contradora Process; if so, will the Government accede to the request.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australia has not received a request to contribute to or support any peace keeping activities in the Nicaragua-Honduras border. Following an incursion by Nicaraguan troops into Honduran territory in the third week of March, the Nicaraguan Government called for the establishment of an international force for supervision and control of the Nicaragua-Honduras border. I am not aware of any response to this proposal from Honduras or from the Contadora countries.

I note that the current draft of the Contadora Treaty, which is still under negotiation, contains provisions for a Verification and Control Commission whose duties would include investigating border incidents and whose area of responsibility would cover all five Central American countries. Establishment of such a commission would depend on signature and ratification of a Treaty.

There have been several low-key and tentative approaches from Latin American countries seeking to gauge Australian interest in some unspecified form of participation in such a commission is it were set up.

If a formal request were received, the Government would consider it in the light of its policies towards Central America and peacekeeping activities as well as financial and other foreign policy considerations. I would not wish to speculate on the outcome of such consideration.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: University of New South Wales: Socio-Economic Groups

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 11 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to figures reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 17 December 1985 concerning the socio-economic background of first year students at the University of New South Wales in 1985; if so, has the Minister concluded that universal free university education represents a subsidy to the upper socio-economic groups in the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The press article to which Dr Klugman refers was drawn to my attention. I have not however reached the conclusion suggested by Dr Klugman.

As with most data derived from surveys of this type the results need to be used with caution. I understand for instance that only 53 per cent of commencing students responded to the survey. Without a comparison based on general characteristics of the total group of commencing students it is possible that results include significant bias towards full-time school leavers who are in general more likely to respond to such surveys than part-time or mature age students. A number of other points of detail could also be made concerning interpretation of data on parental occupation and what constitutes a valid measure of socio-economic status.

The Government recognises that there are groups in society, including those of low socio-economic status, who are under-represented in higher education and has introduced measures to increase the access to and participation in higher education of members of these groups. For example, the higher education Equity Program provides funding for institutions to introduce programs to assist disadvantaged students to enter and succeed in higher education. In 1985, a number of projects including some at Nepean CAE, La Trobe University and Footscray Institute of Technology were funded to encourage students from lower socio-economic groups to undertake higher education. In 1986, particular emphasis has been placed on projects which include special admission procedures to overcome the bias already present in the student population by the end of secondary schooling. In this context, it is interesting to note that mature age students are generally more representative of the socio-economic composition of the general population than are those who enter higher education direct from school.

ANSWER.PARA: It should, however, be noted that under the old Rural Adjustment Scheme, which terminated on 30/6/85, the funds made available to States broadly represent funds available to farmers. Under the new scheme most of the funds made available to States are an interest rate subsidy and therefore made much greater levels of assistance available to the rural sector. For example, in 1985-86 after meeting commitments carried over from the previous Rural Adjustment Scheme the Commonwealth has set aside some $8.2m which, as well as providing household support and administration expenses, will allow loans of the order of $58m to be subsidised under the provisions of the present Agreement.

(2) Under the Rural Adjustment Scheme Agreement reserves are not required. Under previous schemes funds were provided to the States with highly concessional terms and it was possible for a State to generate surpluses from the operation of the scheme. I have written to the States seeking information on the surplus funds generated from the Rural Adjustment Scheme and its predecessor the Rural Reconstruction Scheme.

(3) Exact rates are tailored to individual cases, and, further, there is a requirement under the Agreement that States raise applicants' interest rates towards commercial rates as soon as circumstances permit. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tickner Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 19 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: What progress has been made in the development of an enforceable code of practice for financial institutions operating electronic funds transfer systems.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In December 1985 the Treasurer announced that the Government had received and endorsed a Report of a Working Group of officers established in June 1984 to examine the need for, and scope of, more formal arrangements to cover the rights and obligations of users and providers of electronic funds transfer systems (EFTS). The Report recommends improvements in a number of areas including terms and conditions of contracts between financial institutions and cardholders so as to more equitably reflect the interests of cardholders. The Report did not support legislation or a code of conduct at this stage but recommended that financial institutions be given the opportunity to respond to and implement the types of measures it has proposed. Financial institutions generally responded positively to the Report and are being consulted regarding implementation of the recommendations. The Government will receive another report from the Working Group in mid June 1986 on progress in implementing changes in this area.

On 20 September 1985, the Standing Committee of Consumer Affairs Ministers announced the preparation of a draft code of practice for EFTS. It also announced that the exercise would complement that being undertaken by the Commonwealth. In January 1986 a draft code was sent by the New South Wales and Victorian Governments to financial institutions and consumer groups for comment.
Consideration is currently being given to means by which the Commonwealth and State/Territory exercises might be co-ordinated.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can he direct or request Telecom to provide concessions to subscribers in special need.
(2) Is the provision of a telephone service a necessary means of contact with emergency services and neighbours for blind persons living alone.
(3) What telephone concessions are provided to blind persons.
(4) Will he introduce a new concession so that no telephone installation fee is applied to blind persons living alone.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Telecommunications Act 1975 empowers the Minister for Communications to provide any concessional rentals or charges that should, in his opinion be, provided.
(2) Access to a telephone can be expected to be of particular importance to blind persons who live alone.
(3) Blind persons already receive a reduction in telephone rental charges.

For an automatic telephone service, persons who are permanently blind receive a 36 per cent reduction in the applicable normal rental charge. For a manual telephone service the concession is 42, 43 or 44 per cent reduction according to whether the service is, respectively, an exclusive, a two party, or a three or more party service.
(4) This part of the question falls within the responsibility of the Minister for Communications.
As the honourable member has addressed a similar question to the Minister for Communications, I refer him to the answer to that question. (House of Representatives Question No. 3282)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 14 February 1986:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there any fresh brie or camembert cheese sourced from the Besnier Export Company of France imported into Australia; if so, has any action been taken to ensure that it is not of the type found in the US to be contaminated with Listeria monocytogenes which has been alleged to have caused the deaths of 85 people in California.
(2) Are there any procedures to verify that fresh cheeses imported into Australia are made from pasteurised milk; if not, will a procedure be implemented such as is now required by the US.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, there is both fresh brie and camembert cheese sourced from the Besnier Export Company of France imported into Australia. On 17 February 1986 following receipt of advice from Paris of the problem with contaminated cheese in the USA my Department initiated an urgent check to ensure that the cheeses named by the USA were not imported into Australia. This check confirmed that the specific brands named by the USA were not imported into Australia.

Despite the above, a list of Besnier brie and camembert cheeses which are imported into Australia was provided to the Department of Health for on-forwarding to the State Departments of Health for appropriate action.

(2) Australia's current quarantine requirements for the importation of cheese allow unrestricted importation from countries free from foot and mouth disease. Cheeses from other countries must be manufactured from milk pasteurised to acceptable time/temperature levels (commonly 70*C to 72*C for 15 seconds) and reach a PH of 6 or less after maturation, or serve a quarantine period of 120 days at a temperature not lower than 2*C after arrival in Australia. These requirements are considered adequate to inactivate foot and mouth disease virus and are for animal health rather than human health reasons.
The human health considerations associated with imported cheese are a matter for individual States under State food legislation.
